title: K. E. Little and the Texas STARBASE Experience
abstract: 25 fifth grade students from Bacliff, Texas will be participating in a hands-on interactive science education experience called Starbase Texas at Ellington Field January 9th-February 6th.
author: Bonett, D.; Whittemore-Smith, G.

title: Making Earth and Space Science and Exploration Accessible
abstract: Most US students with disabilities must achieve the same academic levels as their non-impaired peers. We are working with NASA product developers and educators from exceptional needs settings to make earth and space science more accessible.
author: Runyon, C. J.; Guimond, K. A.; Hurd, D.; Heinrich, G.

title: Informal Science Education + Planetary Missions = Increased Public Support and Space Science Literacy
abstract: Planetary missions provide a ready-made audience for successful science education public programming. Museums/science centers provide informal science education that links the mission to a wide and diverse audience.

title: Astrobiology Night at the Ballpark — Science Outreach to Non-Traditional Audiences
abstract: The University of Wisconsin Geology Museum with funding from the NASA Astrobiology Institute is targeting new audiences who don't typically seek out science outreach events. In 2009 these partners sponsored an Astrobiology Night at the Ballpark.
author: Norsted, B. A.

title: Methodological Aspects of Astrobiology as a Multidisciplinary Science
abstract: The paper presents wide range of diversity in astrobiology research including methodology, philosophy of science and linguistics. The main purpose of my article is to analyze and confront relationships of interchangeably used notations related to astrobiology.
author: Czyzewska, U. K.

title: Astrobiology in an Urban New York City High School: John Dewey High School's Space Science Academy
abstract: John Dewey High School's participation in NASA's MESDT and DLN projects and other partnerships provide opportunities for our diverse population, focusing particular attention to under-represented and under-served groups in the field of Space Science.
author: Fried, B.; Dash, H. B.

title: An Astrobiology Experience at Puerto Rico Public Schools
abstract: One hundred and thirty students from grades 7 to 9, plus 10 teachers participated in the Discover Astrobiology Activity. This type of activity increases the interest of student in science with an interdisciplinary perspective.
author: Serrano, Y.

title: Interdisciplinary Teaching, a First Step Toward Interdisciplinary Astrobiology Research
abstract: An interdisciplinary elective workshop for third year undergraduates, on the Astrobiology of Planet Earth, is described. It puts planet Earth and the appearance, evolution, survival and future of life and humanity as the central theme.
author: Gale, J.

title: Gas Chromatography and Mass Spectrometry Measurements and Protocols for Database and Library Development Relating to Organic Species in Support of the Mars Science Laboratory
abstract: An organic contaminant database and library has been developed for use with the Sample Analysis at Mars (SAM) instrumentation utilizing laboratory-based Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry measurements of pyrolyzed and baked material samples.
author: Misra, P.; Garcia, R.; Mahaffy, P. R.

title: Astrobiology Program in Colombia: A New Educational Tool
abstract: In search of answers to the educational paradigms, in action to educate and inspire students in science and technology, and if each activity where the word educa-tion is relevant to define each process that human beings develops in interaction with knowledge.
author: Amezquita, W. A. G.; López, G. A. S.; Prieto, J. E. B.

title: A Case Study of the Opportunities and Challenges Presented by Integrating Authentic Data into Diverse High School Classrooms
abstract: This presentation is a case study of the ASC curriculum development project's goal to increase the use of authentic scientific data by translating data from NAI team researchers into scientific data sets suitable for analysis by high school students.
author: Arino de La Rubia, L.; Butler, J.; Gary, T.; Pfiffner, S.; Kuner, S.

title: The Astrobiology in Secondary Classroom (ASC) Curriculum Development Project: Focusing Upon Diverse Students and Teachers in the Pilot Testing Process
abstract: The ASC curriculum guide is designed to address the learning styles present in diverse classrooms by incorporating research-based teaching strategies that increase participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields.
author: Butler, J.; Arino de La Rubia, L.; Gary, T.; Kuner, S.; Ceballos, R. M.; Pfiffner, S.; Brown, S.

title: DNA Repair Genes Expression Analysis of Acute Dose Charge Particle Radiation
abstract: This study will present gene expression changes induced by positively charged particle in four categories i.e. 0 Gy, 0.1 Gy, 1.0 Gy and 2.0 Gy in nine different DNA repair genes from testes of mouse using qPCR analysis.
author: Tariq, M. A.; Shishodia, S.; Ramesh, G. T.; Sodipe, A.; Jejelowo, O.; Pourmand, N.

title: Stable Isotope Astrobiology at Hispanic Serving Institutions: Si Se Puede!
abstract: A "crawl-walk-run" strategy has been used to create a strong, sustainable program in stable isotope geochemistry with an emphasis on astrobiology. The result was the creation of a vibrant program addressing the record of early life on Earth.
author: Melchiorre, E. B.; Lopez, A.; Velasquez, C. M.

title: Astrobiology Program in Colombia: A New Educational Tool
abstract: In search of answers to the educational paradigms, in action to educate and inspire students in science and technology, and if each activity where the word education is relevant to define each process that human beings develops in interaction with knowledge.
author: Bueno, J. E.; Gonzalez, W. A.; Moreno, A. N.; Sarmiento, G. A.

title: The NASA Astrobiology Institute — Minority Institution Research Support Program: Supporting the Next Generation of Astrobiologists
abstract: This presentation discusses ways in which astrobiology research programs can participate in the NAI-MIRS program as well as the successes and challenges in identifying talented researchers who inspire the next generation of astrobiologists.
author: Gary, T.; Butler, J.; Kirven-Brooks, M.; Bell, B.; Bradford, K.; Kuner, S.; Arino de La Rubia, L.

title: `Impact' of the NAI-MIRS Program on Astrobiology Research at a Minority Institution: Connecting Univ. of Puerto Rico to South Africa to Univ. of Wisconsin to NASA
abstract: This abstract describes the outcome of the research and student-related activities at the University of Puerto Rico that resulted from the NAI-MIRS award I received in 2009.
author: Cavosie, A. J.

title: Science Inquiry Learning in Classrooms — Montana Style
abstract: Montana's ABRC is working with rural school teachers in southwestern Montana. Astrobiology is a new and exciting subject for the teachers and its inter-disciplinary nature is very useful and rewarding for the teachers and their students.
author: Brelsford, M. A.; Peters, J.; Grimberg, B. I.

title: Diversity in Astrobiology: Surviving Financial, Institutional and Technical Extremes
abstract: We discuss the development of an astrobiology program at an undergraduate institution, South Carolina State University, a HBCU in a rural setting. Included are successes and barriers to developing curriculum, research and outreach programs.
author: Walter, D. K.

title: Building 21st Century Explorers: Learning About Astrobiology Exploration Interactively
abstract: We report a collaboration between researchers and a major museum in an attempt to teach the public about interdisciplinary exploration, both interactively and immediately responsive to new discovery.
author: Conrad, P. G.; Phillips, K. E.; Sohus, A. M.

title: The Native American Astrobiology in the Secondary Classroom Initiative
abstract: Astrobiology as a platform to engage Native American K-12 Students into the sciences and mathematics with the intent of helping them change any negative views of science and mathematics into possible future educational goals and career paths.
author: Berthelson, M.; Morales, C.; Ceballos, M.

title: Student Perspectives to Conducting Astrobiology Research at Primarily Undergraduate Institutions
abstract: The student-centered challenges, concerns, and benefits to conducting astrobiological research at minority-serving primarily undergraduate institutions will be discussed in this session.
author: McCoy, K. B.; Derecho, I.; Dallal, F.; Venkateswaran, K.; Mogul, R.

title: Studying Planetary Habitability After a NASA Astrobiology Institute MIRS Sabbatical
abstract: The NASA Astrobiology Institute Minority Institution Research Support (NAI-MIRS) opened an opportunity for professors and students to study planetary habitability at the University of Puerto Rico.
author: Mendez, A.

author: Jolliff, B. L.; Robinson, M. S.; Watters, T. R.

title: ORION/MoonRise: A Human and Robotic Sample Return Mission Concept from the South Pole-Aitken Basin
author: Alkalai, L.; Solish, B.; Wlliott, J. O.; Mueller, J.; McElrath, T.; Parker, J.

title: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter: Plans for the Extended Science Mission and Next Steps for Lunar Science and Exploration
author: Vondrak, R. R.; Keller, J. W.; Chin, G.; Garvin, J. B.; Petro, N. E.

title: Man Made Elements Periodic Table, Astronomical Periodic Table, Geographic Periodic Table-Dimitri Mendeleev Imitation in the 21st Century
abstract: A man made elements periodic table, including every single current element not just synthetic elements can be built differently than the naturally occurring element periodic table. Implications for knowing producible elements in space travel.
author: Struck, J. -T.

title: Microbial Community Development in Deep-Sea Hydrothermal Vents in the Earth, and the Enceladus
abstract: We estimate bioavailable energy potentials in mixing zones between hydrothermal fluids and seawater in the Enceladus subsurface ocean. The results suggest that abundant living ecosystem should be present in the Enceladus ocean.
author: Takai, K.; Shibuya, T.; Sekine, Y.; Russell, M. J.

title: Interaction of the Sleeping Chironomid with Microorganisms: ``Uchi-Soto'' in the World of Anhydrobiosis
abstract: In the current paper we outline our current knowledge about interaction of microorganisms and an anhydrobiotic insect in the acquiring desiccation resistance and in the processes related to it.
author: Gusev, O.; Shagimardanova, E.; Bosch, T.; Okuda, T.; Kikawada, T.

title: Evolution and Adaptation of the RNA Coupled with an Artificial Life-Like Self-Replication System to a Severe Translational Environment
abstract: We adapted the RNA in a severe environment in which early life could have been through a life-like self-replication system which allows Darwinian evolution. The results show how powerful evolution is and what problems early life might have overcome.
author: Mizuuchi, R.; Ichihashi, N.; Usui, K.; Yomo, T.

title: Complex Organic Molecules in the Interstellar Medium in the Era of ALMA
abstract: Sgr B2(N) is one of the key sites to search for new complex organic molecules in the ISM. I will describe the techniques used to decipher its molecular content. I will discuss the perspectives offered by ALMA in this context.
author: Belloche, A.

title: Possibility of Environmental-Electro-Ecosystem (E3) Around Deep-Sea Hydrothermal Vents
abstract: We used in situ electrochemical analyses to demonstrate that deep-sea hydrothermal vents have the ability to generate electricity. Some chemolithotrophic microbial components living in chimney may directly utilize the electrons as an energy source.
author: Yamamoto, M.; Nakamura, R.; Oguri, K.; Kawagucchi, S.; Suzuki, K.; Hashimoto, K.; Takai, K.

title: Absorption Features of CH_3NH_2 Towards SgrB2(M)
abstract: We surveyed CH_3NH_2 toward star-forming regions in April 2013 by the Nobeyama 45m telescope. We detected three low-energy CH_3NH_2 lines in clear absorption towards SgrB2(M). This would suggest that CH_3NH_2 is widely distributed in cold molecular clouds.
author: Ohishi, M.; Hirota, T.; Kaifu, N.; Suzuki, T.; Motoki, Y.; Ozeki, H.

title: Unique Late Archean Atmosphere due to Enhunced Volcanic and Biological Activities
abstract: Late Arcehan may be characterized by increasing continental volume and large igneous provinces as well as by onset of oxygenic photosynthesis.
author: Ueno, Y.; Danielache, S. O.; Endo, Y.

title: Perspectives of ELSI Projects: The Origin of the Earth and the Origin of Life
abstract: Earth-Life Science Institute (ELSI) has been recently established at the Tokyo Institute of Technology based on the World Premier International Research Initiatives (WPI) program and is going to study the origins of the Earth and life.
author: Hirose, K.

title: Comet Impacts as a Driving Force of Glycine Oligomerization
abstract: We suggest that comet impacts can readily account for the oligomerization of glycine to form the precursors of life on the early Earth. Since comet impacts are ubiquitous phenomenon, they play an important role in organic chemical evolution.
author: Mimura, K.; Sugahara, H.

title: The Possible Interplanetary Transfer ofMmicrobes: Assessing the Viability of Deinococcus spp. Under the ISS Environmental Conditions for Performing Exposure Experiments of Microbes in the Tanpopo Mission
abstract: In the Tanpopo mission, we have proposed to carry out experiments on capture and space exposure of microbes at the ISS. In this paper, we have examined the survivability of Deinococcus spp. under the environmental conditions in ISS in orbit.
author: Yuko, Y.; Yinjie, Y.; Narutoshi, K.; Keisuke, S.; Masako, T.; Issay, N.; Katsuya, S.; Hirofumi, H.; Kazumichi, N.; Yoshiaki, Y.; Yoh-hei, Y.; Maiko, T.; Tomohiro, S.; Yuta, Y.; Yasuyuki, S.; Satoshi, Y.; Kensei, K.; Shin-ichi, Y.; Yamagishi, A.

title: ``Contact'' with Extra-Terrestrial Life: An Astronomer's View
abstract: From astronomical point of view contact with extraterrestrial life (in whatever situation) may occur within the coming half century. In case of life on exosolar planets the “contact” will happen by astronomical observations.
author: Kaifu, N.

title: Experimentally Testing the Hypothesis of a Limited Amino Acid Repertoire in Primitive Proteins
abstract: It has been argued that a fewer amino acids were used in primitive proteins and later the repertoire increased up to 20. To test this hypothesis experimentally, we restricted the amino acid usage of a reconstructed, ancestral protein to reduced sets.
author: Akanuma, S.; Nakajima, Y.; Yokobori, S.; Yamagishi, A.

title: Evolution of Interstellar Organics to Meteoritic and Cometary Organics: Approaches by Laboratory Simulations
abstract: We examined possible formation of amino acids and nucleic acid bases (or their precursors) from possible interstellar media, and alteration with high-energy photons, particles and hydrothermal reactions to study their fates in the solar system.
author: Kobayashi, K.; Kawamoto, Y.; El-Masry, W.; Eto, M.; Tokimura, H.; Kaneko, T.; Obayashi, Y.; Mita, H.; Kanda, K.; Yoshida, S.; Fukuda, H.; Oguri, Y.

title: Fluorescent Dye Handling System for MELOS1 Life Detection Microscope
abstract: Dye solution handling system for the microscope in MELOS1 mission will be reported. The effect of metal foil treatment on the solution drop will be discussed.
author: Nishizawa, M.; Sasaki, S.; Miyakawa, A.; Imai, E.; Yoshimura, Y.; Honda, H.; Sato, T.; Yamagishi, A.

title: Method for Biological Contamination Monitoring During Aerogel Cutting Process in Tanpopo Project Using Bioluminescent Bacteria Photobacterium Kishitanii
abstract: A novel method to monitor biological contamination of the aerogel during the cutting procedure is reported. The advantage of using bioluminescent bacteria for the monitoring will be presented.
author: Kiyonaga, Y.; Sasaki, S.; Odashima, T.; Okudaira, K.; Imai, E.; Yano, H.; Kawaguchi, Y.; Yamagishi, A.

title: Exposure Experiments of Organic Compounds on the JEM, ISS, in the Tanpopo Mission
abstract: In order to discuss the possibility of delivery of organic compounds from space, alteration of prebiotic compounds in space environments should be clear. Therefore, we will expose some organic compounds on the exposure facility at ISS-JEM.
author: Mita, H.; Hashimoto, H.; Higashiide, M.; Imai, E.; Kawaguchi, Y.; Kawai, H.; Kawamoto, Y.; Kanda, K.; Kobayashi, K.; Nakagawa, K.; Narumi, I.; Okudaira, K.; Tabata, M.; Yabuta, H.; Yamashita, M.; Yano, H.; Yoshida, S.; Yokobori, S.; Yamagishi, A.; Tanpopo Working Group

title: Toward Characterization of Exoplanetary Surface Environment
abstract: How and how much can we potentially know about exoplanetary surface environment with future direct imaging observations? We discuss planetary scattered light as a probe of surface materials as well as clouds, which are relevant to habitability.
author: Fujii, Y.

title: Evolution of Intelligence in a Network of Chain Reactions
abstract: This report presents a concept of network of chain reaction which represents activities. Concurrently activated portions are able to link by intermolecular bond via thermal motion of molecules. Annex system makes possible to replay similar reaction.
author: Karasawa, S.

title: Limits of Life in the Deep Subseafloor Biosphere: New Insights from IODP Expedition 337
abstract: The Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP) Expedition 337 provides an unprecedented opportunity to explore how life persists and evolves in the deep subseafloor ecosystem and to expand our knowledge of habitability and limits of life on Earth.
author: Inagaki, F.; Hinrichs, K. -U.; Kubo, Y.; IODP Expedition 337 Scientists

title: Near-Infrared Circular Polarimetry in Star Forming Regions: Implication for Astrobiology
abstract: We show results from deep imaging linear and circular polarimetry of the massive star-forming region NGC 6334-V as well as our first CP survey results in star forming regions, supporting the extraterrestrial origin of homochirality of life on Earth.
author: Kwon, J.; Tamura, M.

title: Moelcular Phylogenetic Analyses of G1P Dehydrogenase and G3P Dehydrogenase Suggest the Late Origin of Archaea-Type Membrane
abstract: Phylogenetic analyses of G1PDH and G3PDH suggested that the common ancestor of Bacteria/Archaea had cellular membrane with G3P formed by G3PDH. The archaeal ancestry acquired G1PDH, and then the membrane with G3P was replaced with that with G1P.
author: Yokobori, S.; Nakajima, Y.; Akanuma, S.; Yamagishi, A.

title: Deuterium-Hydrogen Exchange Between Organic Matter and Water: Implications for Chemical Evolution During Asteroidal Processing
abstract: Laboratory simulations of D-H exchange between organic matter and water were conducted considering; (1) IOM polymerization process starting with formaldehyde in the presence of water, and (2) D-H exchange between IOM and water.
author: Kebukawa, Y.; Cody, G. D.

title: Astrobiology Research on Board of the International Space Station as part of the European Space Exploration Initiative
abstract: Exposure facilities on board of the ISS have provided unique opportunities to study a variety of questions of astrobiology importance. ESA has developed several astrobiology facilities (BIOPAN, STONE, EXPOSE-E, EXPOSE-R, EXPOSE-R2) for such studies.
author: Horneck, G.

title: Technological Challenges for the Advanced Study of Deep Subseafloor Life
abstract: We have accumulatively developed techniques to analyze deep subseafloor life. The systematic analytical scheme and its current application to some representative deep-biosphere samples will be shown.
author: Morono, Y.; Terada, T.; Ito, M.; Hoshino, T.; Inagaki, F.

title: Enceladus' Hydrothermal Activity: Another Habitable World?
abstract: Water plumes with sodium salts erupting from the south-pole region of Enceladus suggest the presence of an interior ocean. We show experimental results of water-rock reactions in Enceladus, which suggest the presence of hydrothermal activity there.
author: Sekine, Y.; Shibuya, T.; Postberg, F.; Hsu, S.; Suzuki, K.; Masaki, Y.; Kuwatani, T.; Tachibana, S.

title: The Energetics of Amino Acid Synthesis and Polymerization as a Function of Temperature and pH
abstract: This study performed thermodynamic calculations for amino acid synthesis and polymerization as a function of temperature and pH. Results showed that favorable environmental conditions for the two reactions are different.
author: Kitadai, N.

title: Polarized Space Radiation and Biological Homochirality
abstract: A most attractive scenario of the origin of terrestrial biological homochirality is that the single-handedness phenomenon was originated by asymmetric chemical reactions stimulated by polarized space radiation.
author: Takahashi, J.

title: Formation and Early Evolution of Atmosphere and Ocean on the Earth
abstract: We would like to review mechanisms of supply and loss of volatiles on the terrestrial planets. Additionally, we will discuss the cooling of magma ocean and formation of ocean. These processes are highly related to the habitability of planets.
author: Genda, H.; Hamano, K.; Abe, Y.

title: Interplanetary Migration of Eucaryotic Cell, Spore of Schizosaccharomyces Pombe
abstract: The Tanpopo mission to examine possible interplanetary migration of microbes is progressing. Spore of Schizosaccharomyces pombe are considered as the exposed samples. In this paper, results of preliminary experiments for the exposure are shown.
author: Hayashi, N.; Nosaka, J.; Ando, R.; Hashimoto, H.; Yokobori, S.; Narumi, I.; Nakagawa, K.; Yamagishi, A.; Tohda, H.

title: Dried Colony in Cyanobacterium, Nostoc sp. HK-01 — Several high Space Environment Tolerances for ``Tanpopo'' Mission
abstract: A cyanobacterium, Nostoc sp. HK-01, has high several space environmental tolerance. Nostoc sp HK-01 would have high contribution for the “Tanpopo” mission in Japan Experimental Module of the International Space Station.
author: Tomita-Yokotani, K.; Kimura, S.; Kimura, Y.; Igarashi, Y.; Ajioka, R.; Sato, S.; Katoh, H.; Baba, K.

title: Polarimetric Signatures of the Earth Extracted from Earthshine Observations
abstract: We present the results of Earthshine polarimetry. Observed wavelength dependence in phase variation of polarization spectra might be a signature pointing toward Earth-like atmosphere. We also compare polarization difference between ocean and land.
author: Takahashi, J.; Itoh, Y.; Akitaya, H.; Okazaki, A.; Kawabata, K.; Oasa, Y.; Isogai, M.; Niwa, T.

title: Astrobiological Research on Tardigrades: Implications for Extraterrestrial Life Forms
abstract: Tardigrades have been considered as a model for astrobiological studies based on their tolerance to extreme environments. Future research on tardigrades might provide important insight into the possibilities of existence of multicellular life forms.
author: Horikawa, D. D.

title: Bioimaging by X-Ray Laser Diffraction at SACLA
abstract: The XFEL facility, SACLA is soon expected to be useful for new bioimaging method with an accuracy on the order of ten femto-seconds. We recorded coherent X-ray diffraction patterns from intact Microbacterium cells in solution at SACLA.
author: Bessho, Y.

title: Search for Habitable Planets Around Low-Mass Stars Using the InfraRed Doppler Instrument
abstract: We present strategies and plans for a new Doppler exoplanet survey of late-M dwarf stars to search for Earth-mass planets in the habitable zone around low-mass stars using a new near-infrared instrument for the Subaru telescope (IRD).
author: Omiya, M.; Sato, B.; Harakawa, H.; Kuzuhara, M.; Hirano, T.; Narita, N.; IRD Team

title: Silica Aerogel for Use in Cosmic Dust Collectors Utilized in the Tanpopo Mission
abstract: We are developing silica aerogels for use in cosmic dust collectors utilized in the Tanpopo mission. In this paper, we present the recent development of a box-framing aerogel in contamination-controlled environments.
author: Tabata, M.; Yano, H.; Kawai, H.; Imai, E.; Hashimoto, H.; Yokobori, S.; Yamagishi, A.; Tanpopo Working Group

title: Conditions of Surface H_2O of Snowball Planets with High-Pressure Ice
abstract: We discuss the conditions that terrestrial planets must satisfy for an internal ocean to exist by considering the effects of ice under high pressure (high-pressure ice). Such high-pressure ice is likely to affect the habitability of the planet.
author: Ueta, S.; Sasaki, T.

title: Tanpopo: Astrobiology Exposure and Micrometeoroid Capture, a Sample Return Experiment to Test Quasi-Panspermia Hypothesis Onboard the ISS-Kibo Exposed Facility
abstract: As the first Japanese astrobiology experiment in space, the Tanpopo will test key concepts of the quasi-panspermia hypothesis by sample returns of microbe and bio-orgaincs exposure and micrometeoroid capture onboard ISS-Kibo Exposed Facility ExHAM.
author: Yano, H.; Yamagishi, A.; Hashimoto, H.; Yokobori, S.; Kobayashi, K.; Yabuta, H.; Mita, H.; Tabata, M.; Kawai, H.; Higashide, M.; Okudaira, K.; Sasaki, S.; Imai, E.; Kawaguchi, Y.; Uchibori, Y.; Kodaira, S.; Tanpopo Project Team

title: Global Census of Microbial Life in Marine Subsurface Sediments
abstract: Using newly developed molecular ecological approaches, we are conducting global census of microbial life in marine subsurface sediments and provide us a new information of absolute quantify of the microbes in the deep subseafloor biosphere.
author: Hoshino, T.; Tsutsumi, M.; Morono, Y.; Inagaki, F.

title: Metamorphosed Clasts in the CV Carbonaceous Chondrite Breccias Mokoia and Yamato 86009: Evidence for Strong Thermal Metamorphism on the CV Parent Asteroid
abstract: We describe the mineralogy, petrography, and O-isotope compositions of the metamorphosed clasts in the CV chondrites. Obtained data suggest that the clasts formed by thermal metamorphism of heavily-altered chondrites on the CV parent asteroid.
author: Jogo, K.; Krot, A. N.; Nagashima, K.

title: Puzzles of Biochemistry of Extraterrestrial Life
abstract: Biological exclusion principles are briefly explained. The author would like to discuss whether or not the exclusion principle can also be applied on biochemistry and molecular biology of extraterrestrial life.
author: Oshima, T.

title: Ultra High Spatial Resolution Ion Imaging with a NanoSIMS Ion Microprobe: Applications to Astrobiology
abstract: NanoSIMS ion imaging is a powerful tool to investigate elemental and isotopic distribution with ultra high spatial resolution for variety of samples. We will present overview of current researches on microbiology and cosmochemistry using NanoSIMS.
author: Ito, M.

title: Brown Dwarfs Atmospheres Revealed by 2.5-5.0 µm AKARI Spectra
abstract: Brown dwarf atmospheres cannot be determined by models with simple radiative equilibrium and solar metallicity. By comparing AKARI data with our improved models, we attempt to understand the complicated structure of brown dwarf atmospheres.
author: Sorahana, S.; Yamamura, I.; Suzuki, T. K.

title: Abiogenic and Biogenic Chiral Amino Acids for Further Enantiomer-Specific Isotope Analysis (ESIA)
abstract: Abiogenic and biogenic chiral amino acids for further enantiomer-specific isotope analysis (ESIA).
author: Takano, Y.

title: Studies of Exoplanets with SPICA
abstract: We present an introduction to SPICA, a coronagraph instrument for SPCIA, and exoplanet studies with SPICA. SPICA will be a powerful tool for such studies thanks to advantages of a space-based large (3m class) cryogenic IR telescope.
author: Enya, K.

title: AKARI Observations of Interstellar Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons
abstract: We review the results from AKARI observations of PAHs. We also discuss our future prospect for this study using the next Japan-led infrared space mission, SPICA.
author: Ishihara, D.; Kaneda, H.; Oyabu, S.; Kondo, T.; Yamagishi, M.; Yasuda, A.

title: Overview of Japan's MELOS1 Mission: Mars Exploration for Life/Organism Search
abstract: We overview the current plan of Japan's MELOS1 Mars mission which we would like to launch early 2020's. The sceintific target, its significance in broader areas of science, and a brief summary of probe system and mission scenario will be presented.
author: Satoh, T.; Kubota, T.; Fujita, K.; Okada, T.; Iwata, T.; Imamura, T.; Oyama, A.; Ogawa, N.; Yamada, K.; Miyamoto, H.; Yamagishi, A.; Komatsu, G.; Usui, T.; Hashimoto, G. L.; Demura, H.; Senshu, H.; Sasaki, S.; Ishigami, G.

title: Intact Capture, Aerogel, SOCCER, Stardust and LIFE
abstract: In order to definitively determine many complex exploration curiosities, we must bring samples to terrestrial laboratories for detailed analyses by collaborating laboratories and analysts. We report this endeavor in SOCCER, NEARER, Stardust and LIFE.
author: Tsou, P.

title: Can Terrestrial Microbes Grow on Mars?
abstract: Recent work in our laboratory has concentrated on investigating the possibility that prokaryotes from Earth could either (i) live on Mars in their current form, or (ii) evolve the ability to live under Mars conditions.
author: Nicholson, W. L.

title: Aqueous Activity on Chondrite Parent Asteroids
abstract: Aqueous alteration is a fundamental process in the early solar system that affected most groups of chondritic meteorites.
author: Krot, A. N.; Doyle, P. M.; Nagashima, K.; Jogo, K.; Wakita, S.; Ciesla, F. J.; Hutcheon, I. D.

title: Hayabusa Asteroid Sample Return Mission
abstract: Hayabusa executed scientific observation of asteroid Itokawa between September and October 2005.
author: Kuninaka, H.; Hayabusa 2 Project

title: A Strategy for Sample Retrieval and Possible Onboard Biosafety Controls: Perspectives
abstract: Investigation of biological quarantine for planetary protection against both forward and back-contamination.
author: Takano, Y.; Yano, H.; Sekine, Y.; Funase, R.; Takai, K.

title: Why Life? Origins of Life Elsewhere in the Universe
abstract: Given life as we know it, we ask how it originated and how it transitioned from chemical to biological.
author: Hut, P.

title: The Faint Young Sun Problem — How Can Early Earth and Mars be Warmed?
abstract: We will review the new progress related to the faint young sun problem of Earth/Mars and link it to the habitability of known exoplantets.
author: Tian, F.

title: The Pure System for Artificial Cells
abstract: The ultimate goal of biology is to obtain the answer to the question, "what is life?" We have two approaches to reach the goal: analytical and synthetic.
author: Ueda, T.

title: Simplification of the Genetic Code: Restricted Diversity of Genetically Encoded Amino Acids
abstract: We will show the generality of our method for the simplification, by constructing other types of further simplified codes including a 16-amino-acid code.
author: Amikura, K.; Kawahara-Kobayashi, A.; Kiga, D.

title: RNA and the Nature of the Last Common Ancestor
abstract: It is possible to reconstruct some of the characteristics of the last universal common ancestor or cenancestor.
author: Becerra, A.; Islas, S.; Hernandez-Morales, R.; Lazcano, A.

title: Darwinian Evolution in a Translation-Coupled RNA Replication System Within a Cell-Like Compartment
abstract: The construction of an artificial cell or model protocell is hypothesized to provide important insights into the emergence of life from an assembly of non-living molecules.
author: Ichihashi, N.; Usui, K.; Yomo, T.

title: Variation of Genetic Alphabets of Nucleobases
abstract: Nucleic acids are unique biopolymers, which work as both genetic information materials and functional molecules, such as a catalyst and ligands.
author: Kimoto, M.; Hirao, I.

title: "Deep Habitat" in the Icy Moons: Structure and Evolution of the Internal Ocean
abstract: Outer solar system may have a potential habitat of extra-terrestrial life.
author: Kimura, J.

title: Did Oceanic Biogenic Methan Cycling Regulate the Evolution of Early Earth Atmospheric Chemistry?
abstract: One of the most remarkable changes in the Earth surface chemistry of our planet history was the biologically induced pervasive oxygenation of the ocean and atmosphere between 2.45 and 2.32 Ga.
author: Thomazo, C.

title: From Origin of Life to Systematization to Astrobiology
abstract: Our proposed research is one of the biggest mysteries in science: "The Origin and Evolution of Life."
author: Maruyama, S.

title: Toward Detections and Characterization of Habitable Transiting Exoplanets
abstract: The Kepler mission led by NASA has discovered dozens of possible habitable explanets by the transite survey method.
author: Narita, N.

title: Exploration of Jovian System by ESA-JUICE-Mission: Participation of Japanese Teams
abstract: JUICE (Jupiter Icy Moon Explorer) is the ESA's first large-class mission of cosmic vision 2015-2025 program.
author: Juice Japan; Saito, Y.; Fujimoto, M.; Sasaki, S.; Kimura, J.; Namiki, N.; Kasai, Y.; Kasaba, Y.; Asamura, K.

title: NASA Science4Girls and Their Families: Connecting Local Libraries with NASA Scientists and Education Programs to Engage Girls in STEM
abstract: NASA Science4Girls and Their Families utilizes research-based approaches to effectively engage girls in NASA STEM content in partnership with local libraries.
author: Bleacher, L. V.; Meinke, B.; Soeffing, C.; Hauck, K.; Spitz, A.

title: OSIRIS-REx, JWST, and Girl Scouts Partner with Local Libraries for Women's History Month and Beyond
abstract: The OSIRIS-REx mission partnered with JWST, the Girl Scouts of Southern Arizona, and the Pima County Library System beginning with Women's History Month in 2013.
author: Spitz, A. H.; Lebofsky, L. A.; Higgins, M. L.; Dubois, R.; Dykhuis, M.; Braun, A.; Walter, J.

title: Determining the Magnitude of Neutron and Galactic Cosmic Ray (GCR) Fluxes at the Moon Using the Lunar Exploration Neutron Detector (LEND) During the Historic Space-Age Era of High GCR Flux
abstract: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter was launched during an era of minimum solar activity that also gave rise to historically high Galactic Cosmic Ray flux. Simultaneous LEND observations determine the scale of emergent lunar neutron flux unambiguously.
author: Chin, G.; Sagdeev, R.; Millikh, G. M.; Usikov, D.; Su, J. J.; Boynton, W.; Golovin, D.; Harshman, K.; Litvak, M.; Mitrofanov, I. G.; McClanahan, T.; Livengood, T. A.; Evans, L.; Starr, R.

title: Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generators (RTGs) for Lunar Exploration
abstract: A Multi-Mission RTG (MMRTG) is powering the Curiosity rover and was designed as a compact, rugged power source capable of landing on other bodies. NASA is considering development of an enhanced MMRTG and Advanced RTG. More info presented here.
author: Woerner, D. F.

title: Lunar Gene Bank for Endangered Species
abstract: The concept of a gene bank in the lunar polar craters provides a permanent solution to the menace of endangered species and the failure of the prevailing strategies to protect them. This is one vital, technologically viable yet cost effective option.
author: Swain, R. K.

title: Space Mission to the Moon with a Low Cost Moon Probe Nanosatellite: University Project Feasibility Analysis and Design Concepts
abstract: This paper discusses the possibility of launching a 10 kg nanosatellite moon probe with a joint university effort along with industrial partners for a low cost mission to the moon. It will allow for vital experiments to take place.
author: Guven, U. G.; Velidi, G. V.; Datta, L. D.

title: Lunar Proton Albedo Anomalies: Soil, Surveyors, and Statistics
abstract: We see several regional features in the map of lunar albedo protons. We consider several natural sources for the features, as well as man-made anomalies and statistical artifacts.
author: Wilson, J. K.; Schwadron, N.; Spence, H. E.; Case, A. W.; Golightly, M. J.; Jordan, A. P.; Kasper, J.; Looper, M. D.; Mazur, J. E.; Petro, N. E.; Robinson, M. S.; Stubbs, T. J.; Zeitlin, C.; Blake, J. B.; Smith, S. S.; Townsend, L. W.

title: Deep Space Cubesat Orbiter and Compact Broadband IR Instrument to Determine the Systematics of Lunar Water
abstract: We have applied the CubeSat Paradigm to science requirements-driven deep space exploration mission, referred to as a LunarCube, and are developing a compact 'workhorse' instrument for a high priority science application.
author: Clark, P. E.; MacDowall, R.; Reuter, D.; Mauk, R.; Didion, J.; Patel, D.; Farrell, W.; Cox, R.

title: An ALSEP-Like Lunar Surface Science Package in a Cubesat Form Factor?
abstract: How scalable is the thermal design developed for the ALSEP-like LEMS (without RTGs or RHUs) concept for Project Constellation to a cubesat form factor package?
author: Clark, P. E.; Didion, J.; Cox, R.

title: Small Payloads and Advanced Concepts for Exploration (SPACE) Early Mission Design Tool
abstract: This tool allows scientists and engineers in early phases of mission development to select a compact instrument for a science application and find initial estimates mass, power, volume, and bandwidth for a specific nanosatellite mission.
author: Leiter, R. M.; Himwich, Z.; Natarajan, A.; Rosenthall, J.; Clark, P. E.

title: Lunar Surface Models in Raised Relief
abstract: Lunar surface models in raised relief give the user a tactile impression of the terrain shown on the map.
author: Fink, H.

title: Evidence for Surface Volatiles on the Moon and Mercury: A Planetary Comparison
abstract: The Moon and Mercury both have shadowed regions featuring temperatures low enough to preserve water and other volatiles. We compare LRO and MESSENGER laser altimeter data sets to look for evidence of polar volatiles on these two solar system bodies.
author: Siegler, M. A.; Lucey, P.; Neumann, G.; Hayne, P. O.; Paige, D. A.; Greenhagen, B. G.

title: Can Solar Wind Volatiles Survive the Day Inside a Lunar Pit?
abstract: We use a new three-dimensional illumination and heat diffusion code to characterize the daily heating cycle inside a lunar pit. This allows a detailed assessment of volatile stability in adjacent shadowed regions such as prospective lava tubes.
author: Zimmerman, M. I.; Bussey, D. B. J.; Hurley, D. M.

title: Evidence for Exposed Water Frost in the Moon's South Polar Regions from LRO Ultraviolet Albedo and Temperature Measurements
abstract: We use data from LRO Diviner and LAMP to show that the distribution of surface water frost appears to follow the coldest temperatures within the lunar polar cold traps.
author: Hayne, P. O.; Hendrix, A.; Sefton-Nash, E.; Lucey, P. G.; Retherford, K. D.; Williams, J. -P.; Siegler, M. A.; Greenhagen, B. T.; Paige, D. A.

title: The Space Launch System and the Proving Ground: Pathways to Mars
abstract: The SLS provides a critical heavy-lift launch capability enabling diverse deep space missions including human exploration, planetary science, astrophysics, heliophysics, planetary defense, and commercial space exploration.
author: Klaus, K.

title: Lunar Polar Surface Frost: The View from LOLA
abstract: LOLA shows that permanently shadowed regions are systematically more reflective than illuminated areas. Several percent water ice and increased porosity can account for the reflectance anomalies at 1064 and 122 nm.
author: Lucey, P. G.; Neumann, G. A.; Smith, D. E.; Zuber, M. T.; Bussey, D. B.; Cahill, J. T.; Mazarico, E. M.; Paige, D. A.

title: ARTEMIS Observations of the Space Environment Around the Moon and its Interaction with the Atmosphere and Surface
abstract: ARTEMIS observations reveal both the effects of the plasma environment on the lunar surface and atmosphere, and the perturbations to the plasma environment caused by the presence of the Moon.
author: Halekas, J. S.; Artemis Team

title: Spectral and Thermophysical Properties of Lunar Swirls from the Diviner Lunar Radiometer
abstract: Diviner Lunar Radiometer observations support the solar wind standoff model for lunar swirl formation. Spectral and thermophysical data are consistent with retarded or abnormal space weathering at the swirls.
author: Glotch, T. D.; Bandfield, J. L.; Lucey, P. G.; Hayne, P. O.; Greenhagen, B. T.; Arnold, J. A.; Ghent, R. R.; Paige, D. A.

title: Accessing and Assessing Lunar Resources with PROSPECT
abstract: PROSPECT is a package in development by ESA to assess the in-situ resource potential of lunar regolith. PROSPECT will: obtain sub-surface regolith samples, extract volatiles, identify chemical species, quantify abundances, and characterize isotopes.
author: Carpenter, J. D.; Barber, S.; Cerroni, P.; Fisackerly, R.; Fumagalli, A.; Houdou, B.; Howe, C.; Magnani, P. G.; Morse, A.; Monchieri, E.; Reiss, P.; Richter, L.; Rizzi, F.; Sheridan, S.; Waugh, L.; Wright, I. P.

title: Lunar Exploration in ESA
abstract: We report on current ESA plans and activities in the area of lunar exploration.
author: Carpenter, J. D.; Houdou, B.; Fisackerly, F.; De Rosa, D.; Patti, B.; Schiemann, J.; Hufenbach, B.; Foing, B.

title: Investigation of Ionized Volatiles and Interior Structure of the Moon: Implications from Restored Apollo Magnetic Field Data
abstract: The restored Apollo magnetic field data have revealed ion cyclotron waves that suggest the presence of ionized volatiles from the Moon. Further restoration of the Apollo-era data can help probe the electrical conductivity of the lunar interior.
author: Chi, P. J.

title: Solar Wind Implantation into Lunar Regolith: Hydrogen Retention in a Surface with Defects
abstract: Hydrogen implantation and subsequent retention is found to highly dependent on both temperature and activation energy at the H-implantation/defect site. We specifically explore the latter variable herein using a statistical approach.
author: Farrell, W. M.; Hurley, D. M.; Zimmerman, M. I.

title: Lunar Polar Illumination Modeling to Support Data Analysis
abstract: We show that illumination modeling at the lunar poles can be useful to support calibration and analysis of lunar datasets such as the neutron data, in particular when studying time­variable effects and correlation with time of day.
author: Mazarico, E.; Nicholas, J. B.; McClanahan, T. P.; Neumann, G. A.

title: The Search for a Diurnal Effect in Lunar Hydrogen Abundance
abstract: We studied the LP data exhibit diurnal variations of the same magnitude as those reported by Livengood et al 2014, however the LPNS variations are systemically anti-correlated with instrument temperature.
author: Teodoro, L. F. A.; Lawrence, D. J.; Elphic, R. C.; Eke, V. R.; Feldman, W. C.; Maurice, S.

title: High-Spectral Resolution, May 2013 Ground-Based Observations of the Lunar Sodium and Potassium Exosphere
abstract: Fabry-Perot spectroscopy line profiles measurements of lunar exospheric Na D2 (5889.951 A) and K D1 (7698.965 A) emissions were obtained from the National Solar Observatory McMath-Pierce telescope during the May 2013 first to third quarter periods.
author: Oliversen, R. J.; Mierkiewicz, E. J.; Kuruppuaratchi, D. C. P.; Derr, N. J.; Gardner, D. D.; Lupie, O. L.; Roesler, F. L.

title: Arne — Sublunarean Explorer
abstract: We propose a simple and cost effective reconnaissance of the Mare Tranquillitatis Pit with Arne, a small lander (<130 kg) that carries three flying microbots (or pit-bots) each with mass of 3 kg. Objectives serve key science and exploration needs.
author: Robinson, M. S.; Thanga, J.; Wagner, R. V.; Hernandez, V. A.

title: Intrepid: Lunar Roving Prospector — Providing Ground Truth and Enabling Future Exporation
abstract: We propose a long range lunar roving prospector, Intrepid, to collect essential measurements to address key questions and demonstrate technologies required for future robotic and human exploration of the Moon, Mars, and other terrestrial bodies.
author: Robinson, M. S.; Lawrence, S. J.; Speyerer, E. J.; Stopar, J. D.

title: Inversion Algorithms to Determine Likely 3D Solids from a Population of Particles
abstract: The 3D shape of particles affects many aspects of science and engineering. Two inversion algorithms were developed to determine sets of 3D solids that approximate the 2D measures of a population of particles of lunar regolith and lunar simulant.
author: Knicely, J.; Rickman, D.

title: Variable Abundance and Isotopic Composition of Hydrogen Inside the Moon
abstract: Measurements of H abundance and isotopes in lunar samples show that H is distributed heterogeneously in the lunar interior.
author: Robinson, K. L.; Taylor, G. J.

title: The Need for Lunar and Planetary Cartography Planning
abstract: A lack of planning in planetary cartography has had and will have serious consequences for planetary missions. Here we highlight the current lack of formal cartographic planning for the U.S. space program and recommend a community-driven solution.
author: Archinal, B. A.; Kirk, R. L.; Gaddis, L. R.; Hagerty, J.; Skinner, J.; Titus, T. N.; Keszthelyi, L. P.; Hare, T.; Lawrence, S. J.; Beyer, R.; Nefian, A.; Fong, T.; Duxbury, T.

title: In Search of Impact-Induced H2O-Alteration Signatures: Initial Thermal Constraints
abstract: Initial heat-transfer calculations suggest that polar ice can be melted and vaporized via impact-generated heating in the near-surface surrounding a crater. Water (liquid + gas) trapped in pore-spaces is available to form chemical alteration products.
author: Stopar, J. D.; Robinson, M. S.; Asphaug, E.; Jolliff, B. L.; Speyerer, E. J.; Christensen, P. R.

title: Lunar Flashlight: Mapping Lunar Surface Volatiles Using a Cubesat
abstract: The Lunar Flashlight mission will measure surface ice within the permanently shadowed regions of the lunar south pole in support of NASA’s Strategic Knowledge Gap to understand water and other volatiles in lunar cold traps.
author: Cohen, B. A.; Hayne, P. O.; Paige, D. A.; Greenhagen, B. T.

title: LROC NAC Photometry as a Tool for Studying Physical and Compositional Properties of the Lunar Surface
abstract: LROC NAC photometry has been used to study the effects of rocket exhaust on lunar soil properties, and here we apply the same photometric methods to place compositional constraints on regions of silicic volcanism and pure anorthosite on the Moon.
author: Clegg, R. N.; Jolliff, B. L.; Boyd, A. K.; Stopar, J. D.; Sato, H.; Robinson, M. S.; Hapke, B. W.

title: Astronaut Geology Training
abstract: We discuss the current status of astronaut training.
author: Bleacher, J. E.; Eppler, D. B.; Tewksbury, B. J.; Helper, M. A.

title: Coregistration of Elevation Data from the Lunar Orbiter Laser Altimeter and the SELENE Terrain Camera
abstract: Our goal is to produce the most complete, accurate, and precise global terrain model of the lunar surface by coregistering and merging the digital elevation models from LOLA and the SELENE terrain camera.
author: Barker, M. K.; Mazarico, E.; Neumann, G. A.; Smith, D. E.; Zuber, M. T.

title: A Laser Spectrometer for Global Mapping of the Abundance, Distribution and Variability of Water on the Moon
abstract: A multispectral laser spectrometer under development at Goddard Space Flight Center can definitively detect and map surface ice from orbit, and also quantify the abundance and variation of global bound water at the 10-100 ppm level.
author: Lucey, P. G.; Abshire, J. B.; Sun, X.; Neumann, G. A.; Mazarico, E. M.

title: Why Do We Need the Moon: Next Steps Forward for Moon Exploration
abstract: This paper outlines the various possibilities for the future of the moon and it details how it can be beneficial for future space technology endeavors and discusses alternatives of Nanosatellite Moon missions as well as private sector missions.
author: Guven, U. G.

title: Modular Heat Flow Probe for Small Lunar Landers
abstract: We report the latest on our effort for developing a modular lunar heat flow probe that can be accommodated on small landers.
author: Nagihara, S.; Zacny, K.; Hedlund, M.; Taylor, P. T.

title: Lunar Highlands Bulk Hydrogen Concentrations
abstract: A map of bulk hydrogen concentration across the lunar highlands is presented. These concentrations are measured with data from the Lunar Prospector Neutron Spectrometer.
author: Lawrence, D. J.; Peplowski, P. N.; Plescia, J. B.; Greenhagen, B. T.; Maurice, S.; Prettyman, T. H.

title: Epithermal Neutrons, Illumination, Spatial Scale and Topography: A Correlative Analysis of Factors Influencing the Detection of Slope Hydration Using LRO's Lunar Exploration Neutron Detector
abstract: This research correlates the Moon’s south polar epithermal neutron flux, topography and a visible illumination model and shows that there is a widespread hydration of polward-facing (PF) slopes that is occurring at a continuum of spatial scales.
author: McClanahan, T. P.; Mitrofanov, I. G.; Boynton, W. V.; Chin, G.; Evans, L. G.; Starr, R. D.; Livengood, T.; Sagdeev, R.; Parsons, A. M.; Su, J. J.; Murray, J.; Sanin, A.; Litvak, M.; Harshman, K.; Hamara, D.; Bodnarik, J.

title: A New Moon. An Initiative to Integrate new Lunar Information into our Fundamental Understanding of the Moon and the next Stages of Lunar Exploration
abstract: We propose a new initiative that will integrate recent mission observations into producing a richer understanding of the Moon, revealing new clues about the history of the solar system, and providing new information for renewed lunar exploration.
author: Shearer, C. K.; Neal, C. R.; Jolliff, B. L.; Wieczorek, M. A.; Mackwell, S.

title: Robotic Sample Return I. Advancing our understanding of Planetary Differentiation
abstract: We examine the role of lunar SR for advancing our knowledge of the early differentiation of the Moon and other planetary bodies.
author: Shearer, C. K.; Lawrence, S.; Jolliff, B. L.

title: Lunar PLANE: Lunar Polar Low-Altitude Neutron Experiment for High-Spatial Resolution Hydrogen Concentration and Depth Measurements
abstract: This presentation describes a low-cost, low-resource orbital mission that can obtain high-spatial resolution (<10 km) measurements of the hydrogen spatial and depth distributions for the lunar poles.
author: Lawrence, D. J.; Miller, R. S.; Peplowski, P. N.; Ozimek, M.; Scott, C.

title: The Integration of Handheld Technologies into Planetary Surface Exploration
abstract: Developing a suite of in situ geochemical instruments to assist in sample collection and high-grading is crucial in enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness of astronaut surface activities. We highlight several of these instruments here.
author: Young, K. E.; Bleacher, J. E.; Evans, C. A.; Arzoumanian, Z.; Gendreau, K.; Hodges, K. V.

title: Water Interactions with Lunar Regolith from LADEE Observations
abstract: Water in lunar polar regions may arise in part from migration of water through the exosphere. We study important parameters in that migration using LADEE NMS data from engine burn experiments.
author: Hurley, D. M.; Benna, M.; Mahaffy, P.; Elphic, R.; Goldstein, D.

title: Cross Calibration of Omnidirectional Orbital Neutron Detectors LPNS of Lunar Prospector and SETN/LEND of Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter
abstract: In this research we cross calibrate the omnidirectional neutron detectors from Lunar Prospector mission and Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter mission by Monte Carlo simulations.
author: Murray, J.; Su, J. J.; Sagdeev, R.; Chin, G.; McClanahan, T. P.; Livengood, T.; Starr, R. D.; Evans, L. G.

title: Taurus Littrow Pyroclastic Deposit — An Optimum Feedstock for Lunar Oxygen
abstract: A lunar resources demonstration mission to Taurus Littrow will encounter a >10 m thick pyroclastic deposit with few landing hazards, a uniform composition, and a predicted oxygen yield of approximately 3 wt. %, among the highest values on the Moon.
author: Allen, C. C.

title: The Geology of Inferno Chasm, Idaho: A Terrestrial Analog for Lunar Rilles?
abstract: We compare field observations at a rille-like channel (Inferno Chasm) at Craters of the Moon in Idaho to a rille in Marius Hills on the Moon.
author: Garry, W. B.; Hughes, S. S.; Kobs Nawotniak, S. E.; Neish, C. D.; Haberle, C. W.; Heldmann, J. L.; Lim, D. S. S.; Finesse Team

title: Lunar Prospecting Drill
abstract: We report on development and testing of a drill designed to capture volatile rich samples on the Moon from up to 1 meter depth. The drill was recently tested in lunar chamber at NASA GRC.
author: Zacny, K.; Paulsen, G.; Chu, P.; Kleinhenz, J.; Smith, J.; Trautwein, J.; Quinn, J.

title: Mini-RF Bistatic Observations of Cabeus Crater
abstract: Observations of the south polar crater Cabeus indicate anomalous scattering behavior associated with crater floor materials (behavior not observed with monostatic data). We interpret this behavior as consistent with the presence of water ice.
author: Patterson, G. W.; Bussey, D. B. J.; Stickle, A. M.; Cahill, J. T. S.; Spudis, P.; Mini-RF Team

title: Developing the Global Exploration Roadmap
abstract: The GER can be developed by mapping existing international and detailed documents to it.
author: Neal, C. R.; Schmidt, G.; Crawford, I. A.; Ehrenfreund, P.; Carpenter, J.

title: Important SKGs for Lunar Water Resources: Time/Space Variations of Surficial OH/H2O
abstract: The pervasive nature of surficial OH/H2O across the Moon may make it the most valuable resource. Although our knowledge of its origin, abundance, and properties is currently very limited, this is easy to correct with new orbital spectroscopic data.
author: Pieters, C. M.; Milliken, R. E.

title: Volatiles (H, C, N, F, S, Cl) in the Lunar Mantle, Crust, and Regolith: What Questions Remain and Where do We go Next?
abstract: This paper presents a summary of data pertaining to the "magmatic volatile" elements H, C, N, F, S, Cl in and on the Moon. The progress made thus far is presented and future avenues of research are highlighted.
author: McCubbin, F. M.; Shearer, C. K.

title: Association Between Small Thorium Enhancements, Silicic Volcanism, and Enhanced OH/H2O as Measured by the Moon Mineralogy Mapper
abstract: The association between the 3 µm absorption feature measured by M3 and locations of silicic volcanism is evaluated. There are a number of small-scale features on the Moon that appear to contain abundance endogenic hydroxyls at the lunar surface.
author: Petro, N. E.

title: Copernicus Crater: Compelling Science Exploration Target Waiting for Future Missions
abstract: Copernicus crater has several scientifically interesting locations that provide a strong motivation for its exploration. We provide a summary of new scientific insights, exploration objectives and potential targets.
author: Dhingra, D.; Pieters, C. M.; Head, J. W.

title: Communication and Illumination Conditions at Ina-D — An Information Fusion Approach for Lunar Exploration Planning
abstract: Knowledge of line-of-sight and solar illumination conditions (LoSSIC) drive lunar surface exploration planning. LoSSIC information derived from LROC NAC DTMs is used to greatly enhance communication and traverse planning on the lunar surface.
author: Mahanti, P.; Robinson, M. S.; Lawrence, S. J.; Stelling, R.; Boyd, A.

title: Production of Volatiles at Lunar Pyroclastic Volcanic Vents
abstract: Significant masses of CO, CO2, and H2O can be released by pyroclastic eruptions.
author: Kring, D. A.

title: Prominent Volcanic Source of Volatiles in the South Polar Region of the Moon
abstract: Volatiles produced by an immense pyroclastic vent in Schrodinger basin may be a good target for future missions that test models of volatile production, transport, and deposition.
author: Kring, D. A.; Kramer, G. Y.; Bussey, D. B. J.; Hurley, D. M.

title: Diurnally Variable Hydrogen-Bearing Volatiles at the Moon's Equator: Evidence, Concentration, Transport, Implications
abstract: Neutron remote-sensing demonstrates significant quantities of volatiles in the equatorial region that cycle in and out of subsurface sequestration diurnally. Solar wind and micrometeoroids supply insufficient hydrogen to support equilibrium.
author: Livengood, T. A.; Chin, G.; Sagdeev, R. Z.; Mitrofanov, I. G.; Boynton, W. V.; Evans, L. G.; Litvak, M. L.; McClanahan, T. P.; Sanin, A. B.; Starr, R. D.; Su, J. J.

title: Five Years at the Moon with the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter (LRO): New Views of the Lunar Surface and Environment
abstract: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter (LRO) has been orbiting the Moon for over five years. In that time, data from the seven instruments onboard the spacecraft have made significant advances in our understanding of the Moon and its environment.
author: Petro, N. E.; Keller, J. W.

title: International Strategy for the Exploration of Lunar Polar Volatiles
abstract: The International Space Exploration Coordination Group (ISECG) has begun an effort to develop a strategy to investigate lunar polar volatiles in a cooperative approach that is technically feasible, yet programmatically implementable.
author: Gruener, J. E.; Suzuki, N. H.

title: Robotic Sample Return II: Addressing Fundamental Exploration Themes
abstract: A campaign of automated sample return to specific locations identified by recent mission results as a critical aspect of an integrated exploration strategy is discussed; specific ROIs are identified to inform future hardware choices.
author: Lawrence, S. J.; Jolliff, B. L.; Shearer, C.; Robinson, M. S.; Stopar, J. D.; Braden, S. E.; Speyerer, E. J.; Hagerty, J. T.; Denevi, B. W.; Neal, C. R.; Draper, D. S.

title: Astrobotic Technology: Commercial Lunar Payload Delivery Service
abstract: This paper describes Astrobotic Technology’s financial and technical model for delivery of commercial lunar landing capabilities through government partnership.
author: Huber, S. A.; Thornton, J. P.; Hendrickson, D. H.

title: Mini-RF Observations of Mare Ejecta Emplacement Diversity
abstract: Significant diversity is seen in the radar scattering characteristics of mare crater ejecta. Here, signatures of subsurface layering emplaced on the lunar surface following impact events are observed using Mini-RF radar data.
author: Stickle, A. M.; Patterson, G. W.; Bussey, D. B. J.; Cahill, J. T. S.; Mini-RF Team

title: Astrobotic Technology: Planetary Pits and Caves for Science and Exploration
abstract: This paper describes lunar pits and caves as a potential destination for future science and exploration missions and crewed lunar outposts.
author: Huber, S. A.; Hendrickson, D. B.; Jones, H. L.; Thornton, J. P.; Whittaker, W. L.; Wong, U. Y.

title: Optimized Traverse Planning for Future Lunar Polar Prospectors
abstract: Ground-truth measurements are required to fully understand the resource potential of lunar volatiles. A mobile polar prospector that leverages persistently illuminated areas would address many outstanding questions by sampling multiple nearby PSRs.
author: Speyerer, E. J.; Lawrence, S. J.; Stopar, J. D.; Robinson, M. S.; Jolliff, B. L.

title: The Benefits of Sample Return: Connecting Apollo Soils and Diviner Lunar Radiometer Remote Sensing Data
abstract: Here we present a comprehensive study to reproduce an accurate simulated lunar environment, evaluate the most appropriate sample and measurement conditions, collect thermal infrared spectra of Apollo soils, and correlate them with Diviner observations.
author: Greenhagen, B. T.; Donaldson Hanna, K. L.; Thomas, I. R.; Bowles, N. E.; Allen, C. C.; Pieters, C. M.; Paige, D. A.

title: Lunar Surface Traverse and Exploration Planning: Farside Locations
abstract: We describe morphometric properties of farside exploration destinations.
author: Lawrence, S. J.; Robinson, M. S.; Stopar, J. D.; Speyerer, E. J.; Jolliff, B. L.

title: Steamboat Spring Field Trip Overview
author: Calvin, W. C.; Farmer, J. D.

title: The Planetary Science Workforce: Goals Through 2050
abstract: The planetary science workforce is not nearly as diverse as the society from which its membership is drawn and from which the majority of our funding comes. We discuss the current state and recommendations for improvement.
author: Rathbun, J. A.; Cohen, B. A.; Turtle, E. P.; Vertesi, J. A.; Rivkin, A. S.; Hörst, S. M.; Tiscareno, M. S.; Marchis, F.; Milazzo, M.; Diniega, S.; Lakdawalla, E.; Zellner, N.

title: Titan's Atmosphere and Climate: Unanswered Questions
abstract: By 2050 / We must unravel Titan's / Complex chemistry.
author: Horst, S. M.

title: Strategies for Enabling Lunar Exploration: A NextGen Perspective
abstract: The NextGen is passionate about and committed to continued lunar exploration. Here we outline strategies that NextGen believes are important for enabling future lunar exploration, and what role the NextGen will play in these activities.
author: Watkins, R. N.; Runyon, K.; Caswell, T. E.; Ostrach, L. R.; Jawin, E. R.; Meyer, H. M.; Mitchell, J. L.

title: Viability of a Reusable Lunar Lander
abstract: This abstract talks about the viability of a reusable lunar lander and my start-up, Lunar8.
author: Vidra, N.

title: Geological Spacesuit Testing
abstract: Adapting terrestrial field geology techniques for use in a spacesuit is a science-exploration synergistic goal that I am able to support as a qualified spacesuit test subject and geologist.
author: Runyon, K. D.

title: Building an Economical and Sustainable Lunar Infrastructure to Enable Lunar Science and Space Commerce
abstract: A new concept study was initiated to examine and analyze architecture concepts for an economical and sustainable lunar infrastructure system that can extend the life, functionality, and distance traveled of surface mobility missions.
author: Zuniga, A. F.; Turner, M. F.; Rasky, D. J.

title: Charged Particle Weathering Rates at the Moon as Determined from ARTEMIS Observations
abstract: We use a combination of ARTEMIS ion measurements and SRIM simulations to compute the mean ion flux to the Moon and the associated rates of amorphous silicate rim formation on lunar grains. We compare to previous observational and laboratory results.
author: Poppe, A. R.; Farrell, W. M.; Halekas, J. S.

title: A Space Commodities Futures Trading Exchange to Grow the Lunar Economy
abstract: This paper proposes to establish a Space Commodities Futures Trading Exchange in order to define and trade essential commodities that, when traded on an open exchange, improve availability, quality, price discovery, financeability, and equal access.
author: Cahan, B. B. C.

title: ESA's Journey to the Moon
abstract: To assure future access to the fundamental capabilities needed to get humans to the Moon in a sustainable way, ESA is developing technologies, planning missions, and building international and public-private partnerships.
author: Carpenter, J. D.

title: Commercial Enabled Science
abstract: New commercial space capabilities offer the potential to enable new lunar science and space science missions that can be developed quickly, fly frequently, and at greatly reduced cost.
author: Pittman, R. B.; Rasky, D. J.

title: Supporting Future Lunar Surface Exploration Through Ongoing Field Activities
abstract: We present results from several ongoing field deployments that are working to explore 1) lunar surface trafficability, 2) radiation shielding, and 3) lunar habitat, life support, and mobility.
author: Young, K. E.; Graff, T. G.; Bleacher, J. E.; Coan, D.; Whelley, P. L.; Garry, W. B.; Kruse, S.; Reagan, M.; Garrison, D.; Miller, M.; Delgado, F.; Rogers, A. D.; Glotch, T. D.; Evans, C. A.; Naids, A.; Walker, M.; Hood, A.

title: Astrobotic's Payload Delivery Services Enables Lunar Surface Activities
abstract: This paper describes Astrobotic's lunar payload delivery service, along with the latest program developments toward the company's first demonstration of service.
author: Hendrickson, D. B.; Thornton, J. M.

title: Science from the Surface of the Moon: A Rover Traversing a Crustal Magnetic Anomaly
abstract: An in situ investigation of a magnetic anomaly would directly address major sets of questions in planetary magnetism, space plasma physics, lunar geology, space weathering, and the lunar water cycle, as well as human exploration SKGs.
author: Blewett, D. T.; Hurley, D. M.; Denevi, B. W.; Cahill, J. T. S.; Klima, R. L.; Plescia, J. B.; Paranicas, C. P.; Greenhagen, B. T.; Tunstel, E. W.; Anderson, B. A.; Korth, H.; Ho, G. C.; Nunez, J. I.; Hibbitts, C. A.; Stanley, S.; Jozwiak, L.; Daly, T.; Johnson, J. R.; Zimerman, M. I.; Brandt, P. C.; Westlake, J. H.

title: Conducting Subsurface Surveys for Water Ice Using Ground Penetrating Radar and a Neutron Spectrometer on the Lunar Electric Rover
abstract: Teleoperation of the Lunar Electric Rover can survey large areas of the Moon for subsurface volatile deposits in permanently shadowed regions such as Cabeus and Amundsen craters.
author: Kring, D. A.

title: Interaction of Space Radiation with Agriculture on the Moon
abstract: This paper proposes to understand the effects of GCR and SEP on the plants and agriculture, which is the primary step to colonization at any celestial site. This paper is dedicated to achieve this understanding to aid plantation missions on the Moon.
author: Guven, U. G.; Goel, E. G.

title: The Future Lunar Flora Colony
abstract: A constructional design for the primary establishment for a lunar colony using the micrometeorite rich soil is proposed. It highlights the potential of lunar regolith combined with Earth technology for water and oxygen for human outposts on the Moon.
author: Goel, E. G.; Guven, U. G.

title: Recent Achievement by the SSERVI ALSEP Data Recovery Focus Group
abstract: We report recent research progress made by the SSERVI ALSEP Data Recovery Focus Group.
author: Nagihara, S.; Nakamura, Y.; Williams, D. R.; Taylor, P. T.; McLaughlin, S. A.; Hills, H. K.; Kiefer, W. S.; Weber, R. C.; Dimech, J. -L.; Phillips, D.; Nunn, C.; Schmidt, G. K.

title: Quantifying Elements of a Lunar Economy Based on Resource Needs
abstract: We model a simplified lunar economy from human life support, Earth materials consumption, and energy and propulsion requirement estimates, constrained by lunar elemental abundances; estimate likely imports/exports and "gross interplanetary product."
author: Greenblatt, J. B.

title: Astrobotic: Peregrine Lunar Lander Technical Program Update
abstract: This paper describes the latest developments in Astrobotic's lunar lander mission program. Topics addressed here include program updates, technical updates, and a summary of our approach.
author: Bhaskaran, S.; Hopkins, J. K.

title: Launch Services for the Moon
abstract: One of the next frontiers is the Moon. United Launch Alliance (ULA) has extensive experience with launching delicate, exquisite payloads throughout our solar system, including the Moon. ULA's ACES/XEUS provides lunar surface delivery.
author: Sampson, M. S.

title: Lunar Ice Cube: Development of a Deep Space Cubesat Mission
abstract: Lunar Ice Cube, a 6U deep space cubesat mission, will be deployed by EM1. It will demonstrate cubesat propulsion, the Busek BIT 3 RF Ion engine, and a compact instrument capable of addressing HEOMD Strategic Knowledge Gaps related to lunar volatiles.
author: Clark, P. E.; Malphrus, B.; McElroy, D.; Schabert, J.; Wilczewski, S.; Farrell, W.; Brambora, C.; Macdowall, R.; Folta, D.; Hurford, T.; Patel, D.; Banks, S.; Reuter, D.; Brown, K.; Angkasa, K.; Tsay, M.

title: Synthesizing Surface and Subsurface Measurements of Water Ice in the Polar Regions of the Moon
abstract: Though surface and subsurface data may disagree about the location of water ice near the lunar poles on small scales, we show they are well-correlated on very large scales, with water ice being distributed down to about +/-70 degrees latitude.
author: Jordan, A. P.; Wilson, J. K.; Schwadron, N. A.; Spence, H. E.

title: LRO-LAMP Observations of Illumination Conditions in the Lunar South Pole Permanently Shaded Regions
abstract: LRO-LAMP is able to observe scattered sunlight within the south pole PSRs. We compare these observations to illumination models and other LRO datasets.
author: Mandt, K. E.; Mazarico, E.; Greathouse, T. K.; Byron, B.; Retherford, K. D.; Gladstone, G. R.; Liu, Y.; Hendrix, A. R.; Hurley, D. M.; Stickle, A.; Patterson, G. W.; Cahill, J.; Williams, J. -P.

title: Geologic Exploration Enabled by Optimized Science Operations on the Lunar Surface
abstract: We present detailed geologic field studies that can best be accomplished through in situ investigations on the Moon, and the associated recommendations for human and robotic mission capabilities and concepts of operations for lunar surface missions.
author: Heldmann, J. L.; Lim, D. S. S.; Colaprete, A.; Garry, W. B.; Hughes, S. S.; Kobs Nawotniak, S.; Sehlke, A.; Neish, C.; Osinski, G. R.; Hodges, K.; Abercromby, A.; Cohen, B. A.; Cook, A.; Elphic, R.; Mallonee, H.; Matiella Novak, A.; Rader, E.; Sears, D.; Sears, H.; Finesse Team; Basalt Team

title: Resource Prospector: Evaluating the ISRU Potential of the Lunar Poles
abstract: This talk will provide an overview of the Resource Prospector mission with an emphasis on mission goals and measurements, and will provide an update as to its current status.
author: Colaprete, A.; Elphic, R.; Andrews, D.; Trimble, J.; Bluethmann, B.; Quinn, J.; Chavers, G.

title: Leveraging Virtual Reality for the Benefit of Lunar Exploration
abstract: Virtual reality (VR) and related technologies will assist scientists with lunar exploration and public engagement. We will present the future exponential impact of VR on lunar activities over the coming decades.
author: McCandless, R. S.; Burke, E. D.; McGinley, V. T.

title: Science Enabled by Getting to a Swirl
abstract: The bright, optically immature, curvilinear, magnomaphile surface features known as lunar swirls should be the target of the next lunar mission.
author: Kramer, G. Y.

title: Drilling Regolith: Why Is It So Difficult?
abstract: The Apollo rotary percussive drill system penetrated the lunar regolith with reasonable efficiency; however, extraction of the drill core stem proved to be very difficult on all three missions. Retractable drill stem flutes may solve this problem.
author: Schmitt, H. H.

title: Developing and Testing Lunar Technologies in a Controlled Simulation Lab Using Simulants Built from the Particle Level Up
abstract: Off Planet Research replicated the natural formation processes on the Moon and then fully characterized regolith formation at the particle level, including agglutinates, so these simulants are very close approximations of true lunar regolith.
author: Roux, V. G.; Roth, M. C.

title: Near-Surface Age Distribution of Lunar Impact-Melt Rocks
abstract: Grouping impact-melt rocks from Apollo 16 double-drive tube in preparation for age determination of these samples. The study uses a combination of major-element chemistry, mineralogy, and age to understand impact history of Apollo 16 lunar site.
author: Curran, N. M.; Bower, D. M.; Cohen, B. A.

title: The Lunar Water Assessment Transport Evolution and Resource (WATER) Mission Concept Study
abstract: We will describe the Lunar Water Assessment Transport Evolution and Resource mission concept study that is funded under the NASA PSDS3 program.
author: Hibbitts, C. A.; Blewett, D.; Brandt, P.; Burke, L.; Clyde, B.; Cohen, B.; Dankanich, J.; Hurley, D.; Klima, R.; Lawrence, D.; Patterson, W.; Plescia, J.; Sunshine, J.; Westlake, J.

title: Structural Members Produced from Unrefined Lunar Regolith Simulant
abstract: This topic will present data analysis and findings from experimental results from sintered lunar simulant testing for material properties.
author: Indyk, S.; Benaroya, H.

title: Enabling Mid-Infrared Spectral Analysis on the Lunar Surface
abstract: Mid-infrared spectroscopy is a powerful tool in identifying areas of scientific or exploratory interest. Here we demonstrate the necessity of a simulated lunar environment spectral database to be used in conjunction with handheld MIR instruments.
author: Shirley, K. A.; Glotch, T. D.; Ito, G.; Rogers, A. D.

title: Modeling Sodium Abundance Variations in the Lunar Crust: A Likely Proxy of Past Solar System History and a Potential Guide to Close-In Rocky Exoplanets
abstract: The initial sodium budget of the Moon may have been depleted/transported from the surface post-formation. Abundance variations in crustal samples may be a powerful tool towards exploring conditions on the Moon's surface through solar system history.
author: Saxena, P.; Killen, R. M.; Petro, N. E.; Airapetian, V.; Mandell, A. M.

title: The Robotic Architecture of Moon Express: Exploration, Resources, and Delivery
abstract: Moon Express has recently released a planetary exploration architecture that describes a variety of spacecraft configurations that may be combined and configured to carry out a variety of missions to the Moon and in cislunar and deep space.
author: Spudis, P. D.; Richards, R. D.

title: DREAM2 Studies in Support of Human Exploration of the Moon
abstract: We describe some of the exploration-enabling activities of the DREAM2 team.
author: Farrell, W. M.; Killen, R. M.; Delory, G. T.; Dream2 Team

title: Diurnal Variation of Lunar Albedo Proton Yield and Hydrogenation
abstract: The quantity of hydrogen or hydrogen-bearing molecules in the top 10 cm of lunar regolith may vary significantly with local time, according to albedo proton data collected by LRO/CRaTER.
author: Wilson, J. K.; Schwadron, N. A.; Jordan, A. P.; Looper, M. D.; Zeitlin, C.; Townsend, L. W.; Spence, H. E.; Legere, J.; Bloser, P.; Farrell, W.; Hurley, D.; Petro, N.; Stubbs, T. J.; Pieters, C.

title: The Far-UV Wavelength Dependence of the Lunar Phase Curve as Seen by LRO LAMP
abstract: In this study we discuss the Far-UV wavelength dependence of the lunar phase curves for sample mare and highlands as seen by the LAMP instrument, and we report current derived Hapke parameters at Far-UV wavelengths for the study areas.
author: Liu, Y.; Retherford, K. D.; Greathouse, T. K.; Hendrix, A. R.; Cahill, J. T. S.; Mandt, K. E.; Gladstone, G. R.; Grava, C.; Egan, A. F.; Kaufmann, D. E.; Pryor, W. R.

title: Integrating Diverse Datasets to Assess Approaches for Characterizing Mare Basalts
abstract: This research utilizes new LROC data to re-evaluate the composition of the mare basalt flows in the Marius Hills Volcanic Complex to provide new insights about the relative ages of the low shields and surrounding flows.
author: Deitrick, S. R.; Lawrence, S. J.

title: A New Approach Towards Deployment of Far Side Lunar SETI Using a Tethered Link to a Near Side Antenna
abstract: Keeping in pace with the recent growth in interest in deployable space telescopes for detection of extra-solar objects, we suggest a feasible approach to make a lunar far side SETI mission a reality with the technology. available today.
author: Datta, L. V.; Guven, U.; Goel, E.

title: Field Test of Route Planning Software for Lunar Polar Missions
abstract: A novel field test paradigm has been developed to demonstrate and validate route planning software in the stark low-angled light and sweeping shadows a rover would experience at the poles of the Moon. Software, ConOps, and test results are presented.
author: Horchler, A. D.; Cunningham, C.; Jones, H. L.; Arnett, D.; Fang, E.; Amoroso, E.; Otten, N.; Kitchell, F.; Holst, I.; Rock, G.; Whittaker, W.

title: Astrobotic Research and Development: New Technology for Lunar Science and Exploration
abstract: Astrobotic will present recent work on a range of space robotics technologies relevant to the lunar science and exploration communities.
author: Kitchell, J. F.; Horchler, A. D.; Snyder, K.; Amoroso, E.

title: Robust Navigation for Autonomous Exploration of Extreme Environments from a Free-Flying Platform
abstract: Free flying vehicles have the mobility to explore scientifically interesting extreme environments, such as permanently shadowed regions and lava tubes, but require robust and precise navigation to operate safely and autonomously.
author: Snyder, K.; Amoroso, E.; Kitchell, F.; Horchler, A. D.

title: Asymmetric Ejecta Emplacement from South Pole-Aitken Basin: 3D Hydrocode Modeling Results
abstract: Using high-resolution 3D impact hydrocodes, we model the ejecta emplacement from the South Pole-Aitken basin-forming impact. We find the Moon's upper mantle material is likely exposed in close proximity to the basin's north rim and farside highlands.
author: Kendall, J. D.

title: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter: A Focused Study of Fundamental Solar System Processes at the Moon
abstract: The LRO mission is midway through a two-year extension, to study the fundamental processes recorded on the Moon. LRO's instruments are measuring processes that operate at the Moon and throughout the solar system, especially on airless bodies.
author: Petro, N. E.; Keller, J. W.

title: Mini-RF S- and X-Band Bistatic Radar Observations of the Moon
abstract: Mini-RF is operating in concert with the Arecibo Observatory and the Goldstone DSS-13 antenna to collect bistatic radar data. We will provide an update on science questions being addressed by the Mini-RF team in the current LRO extended mission.
author: Patterson, G. W.; Carter, L. M.; Stickle, A. M.; Cahill, J. T. S.; Nolan, M. C.; Morgan, G. A.; Schroeder, D. M.; Mini-RF Team

title: Determining the Mineralogy of Lunar Samples Using Micro Raman Spectroscopy: Comparisons Between Polished and Unpolished Samples
abstract: Raman spectroscopy is a versatile non-destructive analytical technique that provides compositional and contextual information for geologic samples, including lunar rocks. We have analyzed a suite of Apollo 16 samples using micro Raman spectroscopy.
author: Bower, D. M.; Curran, N. M.; Cohen, B. A.

title: The Lunar Volatiles Orbiter: A Lunar Discovery Mission Concept
abstract: The Lunar Volatiles Orbiter is a discovery-class mission concept which leverages the spacecraft design and operations experience of LRO. LVO is aimed at understanding the current state of volatiles on the Moon with an emphasis on current dynamics.
author: Lucey, P. G.; Petro, N. E.; Hurley, D.; Farrell, W.; Sun, X.; Green, R.; Greenberger, R.; Cameron, D.

title: Building on the Cornerstone Mission: Focused LRO Workshops to Support Science Team Synergies
abstract: During the Cornerstone Mission, the LRO instrument teams have identified a number of key science themes that drive their observations during the extended mission. These themes serve as a basis for the identification of the thematic workshops.
author: Keller, J. W.; Petro, N. E.

title: Far-Ultraviolet Bidirectional Photometry of Apollo Soil 10084: Laboratory Studies in the Southwest Ultraviolet Reflectance Chamber (SwURC)
abstract: We present new far-ultraviolet bidirectional reflectance spectra of Apollo soil 10084. The FUV spectra this mare soil is featureless, though with a small blue slope. Increased reflectance at high phase imply the grains forward-scatter FUV photons.
author: Raut, U.; Karnes, P. L.; Retherford, K. D.; Davis, M. W.; Patrick, E. L.; Liu, Y.; Mokashi, P.

title: The Onset of the Cataclysm: In Situ Dating of the Nectaris Basin Impact Melt Sheet
abstract: The impact history of the Moon has significant implications for solar system dynamics and evolution. We are working on a potential Discovery mission concept that would directly constrain the onset of the cataclysm by dating the Nectaris Basin.
author: Cohen, B. A.

title: Spectral Unmixing Modeling of the Aristarchus Pyroclastic Deposit: Assessing Eruptive History and Exploration Potential of Glass-Rich Regional Lunar Pyroclastic Deposits
abstract: Spectral modeling of the Aristarchus pyroclastic deposit shows that the Moon's largest explosive volcanic deposit is rich in high-titanium volcanic glass. This lunar pyroclastic deposit is of importance for both scientific and exploration purposes.
author: Jawin, E. R.; Head, J. W.; Cannon, K. M.

title: MAPSIT and a Roadmap for Lunar and Planetary Spatial Data Infrastructure
