abstract: We describe MAPSIT, and the development of a roadmap for lunar and planetary SDI, based on previous relevant documents and community input, and consider how to best advance lunar science, exploration, and commercial development.
author: Radebaugh, J.; Archinal, B.; Beyer, R.; DellaGiustina, D.; Fassett, C.; Gaddis, L.; Hagerty, J.; Hare, T.; Laura, J.; Lawrence, S. J.; Mazarico, E.; Naß, A.; Patthoff, A.; Skinner, J.; Sutton, S.; Thomson, B. J.; Williams, D.

title: Canadian Space Agency Activities and Science Priorities Related to Lunar Surface Exploration
abstract: Canadian Space Agency activities: Canadian science priorities for lunar surface exploration, rover technology development, mission concept study for rover element of lunar sample return.
author: Hipkin, V. J.; Picard, M.; Haltigin, T.; Gonthier, Y.; Lange, C.; Jean, P.

title: Water in Pyroclastic Deposits and Cold Traps on the Moon: Possible Resources for Future Exploration
abstract: We propose two types of water reservoirs for future exploration of the lunar resources. Both advantages and challenges of exploring the two types of water reservoirs are analyzed.
author: Li, S.; Lucey, P. G.; Milliken, R. E.

title: Lunar Volcanic History from In-Situ Morphological Analyses
abstract: We present a new method requiring no sample collection to assess the thermal evolution of lunar volcanic deposits, providing key information on eruptive history of volcanic areas on the Moon.
author: Rader, E. L.; Heldmann, J. L.

title: The Anatomy of the Blue Dragon: Changes in Lava Flow Morphology and Physical Properties Observed in an Open Channel Lava Flow as a Planetary Analogue
abstract: We present the relationship of lava flow morphology and the physical properties of the rocks based on terrestrial field work, and how this can be applied to infer physical properties of lunar lava flows.
author: Sehlke, A.; Kobs Nawotniak, S. E.; Hughes, S. S.; Sears, D. W.; Downs, M. T.; Whittington, A. G.; Lim, D. S. S.; Heldmann, J. L.

title: Numerical Models of Volatiles Loss During Lunar Resource Prospector Mission Sample Acquisition
abstract: In the context of the NASA's Resource Prospector, we developed new numerical models of the volatiles transport in lunar regolith.
author: Teodoro, L. F.; Colaprete, A.; Roush, T.; Elphic, R.; Cook, A.; Kleinhenz, J.; Fritzler, E.; Smith, J. T.; Zacny, K.

title: Low-Frequency Moon-Based Radio-Interferometer for Earth Studies
abstract: We suggest that the concept of a Moon-based array of microwave antennas and up-gradable electronics, facing the Earth, to measure soil moisture, sea surface salinity, etc. be matured.
author: Hudson, D.; De Amici, G.

title: CubeRovers for Lunar Exploration
abstract: CubeRover is a 2-kg class of lunar rover that seeks to standardize and democratize surface mobility and science, analogous to CubeSats. This CubeRover will study in-situ lunar surface trafficability and descent engine blast ejecta phenomena.
author: Tallaksen, A. P.; Horchler, A. D.; Boirum, C.; Arnett, D.; Jones, H. L.; Fang, E.; Amoroso, E.; Chomas, L.; Papincak, L.; Sapunkov, O. B.; Whittaker, W. L.

title: Building the Foundations for a Large-Scale, Cross-Sector Collaboration for a Sustainable and Permanent Return to the Lunar Surface
abstract: This presentation will describe how to build the foundations needed for a large scale, cross-industry collaboration to enable a sustainable and permanent return to the Moon based on system leadership, cross-sector partnership, and inclusive business.
author: Kapoglou, A.

title: Science and Antenna Array Trade Studies for Low Frequency Radio Observatories on the Lunar Surface
abstract: A "low-frequency" radio astronomy observatory on the lunar surface would serve to address science goals that cannot be achieved by ground-based observatories. We describe status and plans for such an observatory.
author: MacDowall, R. J.; Burns, J. O.

title: Technology Demonstration of Extended Operations for Volatile Prospecting and Processing in Lunar Permanently Shadowed Regions Enabled by Advanced Radioisotope Power
abstract: An extended demonstration mission for the purpose of validating advanced radioisotope power system in concert with ISRU systems in a permanently shadowed region.
author: Cataldo, R. L.; Kleinhenz, J. E.; Sanders, G. B.

title: Development of Mission Enabling Infrastructure — Cislunar Autonomous Positioning System (CAPS)
abstract: Advanced Space, LLC is developing the Cislunar Autonomous Positioning System (CAPS) which would provide a scalable and evolvable architecture for navigation to reduce ground congestion and improve operations for missions throughout cislunar space.
author: Cheetham, B. W.

title: Technologies for Lunar Exploration
abstract: Honeybee Robotics, with its partners, developed numerous technologies for lunar exploration. Most of these technologies are at high TRL and have been designed for small landers, rovers, as well as astronauts. This abstract presents several of these technologies.
author: Zacny, K.; Indyk, S.

title: Development and Testing of a Lunar Resource Prospector Drill
abstract: We present update on development and testing of a sampling drill for the Resource Prospector mission.
author: Paulsen, G.; Zacny, K.; Kleinhenz, J.; Smith, J.; Quinn, J.; Kim, D.; Mank, Z.; Wang, A.; Thomas, T.; Hyman, C.; Mellerowicz, B.; Yaggi, B.; Fitzgerald, Z.; Ridilla, A.; Atkinson, J.

title: Magnetic Field Measurements on the Lunar Surface: Lessons Learned from Apollo and Science Enabled by Future Missions
abstract: We discuss the science to be enabled by new magnetometer measurements on the lunar surface, based on results from Apollo and other lunar missions. Also discussed are approaches to deploying magnetometers on the lunar surface with today's technology.
author: Chi, P. J.

title: A Moon Sample Return Campaign Will Advance Lunar and Solar System Science and Exploration
abstract: Using private commercial companies to initiate a lunar sample return campaign funded by NASA Planetary Science Division that will advance lunar and solar system science and exploration.
author: Neal, C. R.; Lawrence, S. J.

title: Scientific Outreach of the Lunar Expedition I.0 in the Lunares Habitat in Poland
abstract: Lunares is a chronobiological laboratory to perform advanced studies on humans in controlled MoonMars conditions. Results from The Lunar Expedition I.0 reveal unique properties of the base for future human spaceflight investigation.
author: Kołodziejczyk, A. M.; Rudolf, A.; Gocyła, M.; Młyńczak, M.; Wierzejska, E.; Waśniowski, A.; Davidova, L.; Konorski, P.; Słonina, M.; Budzyń, D.; Kuźma, J.; Ambroszkiewicz, G.; Harasymczuk, M.; Foing, B. H.

title: Lunar, Cislunar, Near/Farside Laser Retroreflectors for the Accurate: Positioning of Landers/Rovers/Hoppers/Orbiters, Commercial Georeferencing, Test of Relativistic Gravity, and Metrics of the Lunar Interior
abstract: We developed next-generation lunar, cislunar, near/farside laser retroreflectors for the improved/accurate: Positioning of landers/rovers/hoppers/orbiters, commercial georeferencing, test of relativistic gravity, and metrics of the lunar interior.
author: Dell'Agnello, S.; Currie, D.; Ciocci, E.; Contessa, S.; Delle Monache, G.; March, R.; Martini, M.; Mondaini, C.; Porcelli, L.; Salvatori, L.; Tibuzzi, M.; Bianco, G.; Vittori, R.; Chandler, J.; Murphy, T.; Maiello, M.; Petrassi, M.; Lomastro, A.

title: MoonMars Astronaut and CapCom Protocols: ESTEC and LunAres PMAS Simulations
abstract: ILEWG developed since 2008 a Mobile Laboratory Habitat (ExoHab) at ESTEC which was tested during a short simulation in July. It was a foretaste of the PMAS mission on 31 July-14 August in LunAres base at Pila, with mission control in Torun, Poland.
author: Authier, L.; Blanc, A.; Foing, B. H.; Lillo, A.; Evellin, P.; Kołodziejczyk, A.; Heinicke, C.; Harasymczuk, M.; Chahla, C.; Tomic, A.; Hettrich, S.; PMAS Astronauts

title: Logistics for MoonMars Simulation Habitats: ExoHab ESTEC and LunAres Poland
abstract: ILEWG developed within EuroMoonMars research programme since 2008 a Mobile Laboratory Habitat (ExoHab) at ESTEC. Its organization led to logistic concerns our team had to work on. We contributed also to the installation of LunAres in Poland.
author: Blanc, A.; Authier, L.; Foing, B. H.; Lillo, A.; Evellin, P.; Kołodziejczyk, A.; Heinicke, C.; Harasymczuk, M.; Chahla, C.; Tomic, A.; Hettrich, S.

title: ILEWG EuroMoonMars Research, Technology, and Field Simulation Campaigns
abstract: ILEWG developed since 2008, "EuroMoonMars" pilot research with a Robotic Test Bench (ExoGeoLab) and a Mobile Laboratory Habitat (ExoHab) at ESTEC. Field campaigns were e.g. in ESTEC, EAC, at Utah MDRS, Eifel, and LunAres base at Pila Poland in 2017.
author: Foing, B. H.; Lillo, A.; Evellin, P.; Kołodziejczyk, A.; Heinicke, C.; Harasymczuk, M.; Authier, L.; Blanc, A.; Chahla, C.; Tomic, A.; Mirino, M.; Schlacht, I.; Hettrich, S.; Pacher, T.; Maller, L.; Decadi, A.; Villa-Massone, J.; Preusterink, J.; Neklesa, A.; Barzilay, A.; Volkova, T.

title: The Status of Restoration of Moon Mineralogy Mapper Data
abstract: We present an update on the status of our geometric and geodetic restoration of the Moon Mineralogy Mapper data.
author: Gaddis, L. R.; Boardman, J.; Malaret, E.; Besse, S.; Weller, L.; Edmundson, K.; Kirk, R.; Archinal, B.; Sides, S.

title: 2017 EuroMoonMars Analog Habitat Preparation at ESTEC
abstract: The 2017 EuroMoonMars analog habitat aims at testing viable concepts of laboratories and habitats to optimize the scientific results of the first crew members of the MoonVillage. The focus is made on developing and testing breakthrough experiments.
author: Evellin, P.; Foing, B. H.; Lillo, A.; Kołodziejczyk, A.; Authier, L.; Blanc, A.; Chahla, C.; Tomic, A.

title: Resource Prospector, the Decadal Survey, and the Scientific Context for the Exploration of the Moon
abstract: The ISRU-focused Resource Prospector mission will address key questions about lunar polar volatiles set out in the Decadal Survey, as well as goals in the Scientific Context for the Exploration of the Moon.
author: Elphic, R. C.; Colaprete, A.; Andrews, D. R.

title: Lunar SKGs: What's Really Needed and What Do We Already Know?
abstract: The distinction between enabling and enhancing SKGs must be maintained. The key unknown is the species, form, and distribution of H in polar regions and it can only be addressed by in situ exploration. The commercial role in resource SKGs is unclear.
author: Plescia, J. B.

title: Constructing Lunar Neutron Flux Maps with LRO/LEND Sensor Field of View
abstract: Neutron instrumentation is essential to characterize the quantity and location of hydrogen-rich deposits in lunar regolith as well as iron-group elements. Accurate mapping requires incorporating the spatial resolution of the detection system.
author: Livengood, T. A.; Chin, G.; Mitrofanov, I. G.; Boynton, W. V.; Harshman, K. P.; Litvak, M. L.; McClanahan, T. P.; Sagdeev, R. Z.; Sanin, A. B.; Starr, R. D.; Su, J. J.

title: Remote Operation of the ExoGeoLab Lander at ESTEC and Lunares Base
abstract: The ExoGeoLab Lander is a prototype developed to demonstrate joint use of remote operation and EVA astronaut work in analogue lunar environment. It was recently deployed in the new analogue base Lunares in Poland and controlled from ESA ESTEC center.
author: Lillo, A.; Foing, B. H.; Evellin, P.; Kołodziejczyk, A.; Jonglez, C.; Heinicke, C.; Harasymczuk, M.; Authier, L.; Blanc, A.; Chahla, C.; Tomic, A.; Mirino, M.; Schlacht, I.; Hettrich, S.; Pacher, T.

title: Measuring the Value of AI in Space Science and Exploration
abstract: FDL is tackling knowledge gaps useful to the space program by forming small teams of industrial partners, cutting-edge AI researchers and space science domain experts, and tasking them to solve problems that are important to NASA as well as humanity's future.
author: Blair, B.; Parr, J.; Diamond, B.; Pittman, B.; Rasky, D.

title: Modeling PPP Economic Benefits for Lunar ISRU
abstract: A new tool is needed for selecting the PPP strategy that could maximize the rate of lunar commercialization by attracting private capital into the development of critical infrastructure and robust capability. A PPP model under development for NASA-ESO will be described.
author: Blair, B.

title: Pb-pb Dating for Miller Range 05035, La Paz Icefield 02205, and Northwest Africa 032 Using CODEX
abstract: We have produced new Pb-Pb dates of Miller Range 05035, La Paz Icefield 02205, and Northwest Africa 032 using CODEX, illustrating how in-situ dating can assess age and isotopic reservoirs.
author: Anderson, F. S.; Levine, J.; Whitaker, T. J.

title: Live from the Moon ExoLab: EuroMoonMars Simulation at ESTEC 2017
abstract: Space enthusiasts simulated the landing on the Moon having pre-landed Habitat ExoHab, ExoLab 2.0, supported by the control centre on Earth. We give here the first-hand experience from a reporter (A.N.) who joined the space crew.
author: Neklesa, A.; Foing, B. H.; Lillo, A.; Evellin, P.; Kołodziejczyk, A.; Jonglez, C.; Heinicke, C.; Harasymczuk, M.; Authier, L.; Blanc, A.; Chahla, C.; Tomic, A.; Mirino, M.; Schlacht, I.; Hettrich, S.; Pacher, T.

title: Transfer and Parse Orbit Momentum Management System Architecture
abstract: Delta V conservative mass transport using orbital tethers at the Moon delivers science and human infrastructure payload mass without need for expendable propulsion as part of the payload platter.
author: Harris, T. H. S.

title: Safety and Comfort for Moon and MARS Habitats: Key Design Considerations
abstract: Safety requirements are critical in designing for any extreme environment and especially for habitats in space and on Moon or Mars. But safety alone is not enough when designing for long-term missions in extreme environments on Earth and in space.
author: Volkova, T. V.; Bannova, O. K.

title: Growing Plants at a MoonMars Base or/and Dedicated External Space
abstract: We developed an experiment growing plants for the human use, as a food or/and additional oxygen/energy source, that could be adapted on a Moon lander.
author: Tomic, A.; Authier, L.; Blanc, A.; Foing, . H.; Lillo, A.; Evellin, P.; Kołodziejczyk, A.; Heinicke, C.; Harasymczuk, M.; Chahla, C.; Hettrich, S.

title: ispace and the Lunar Missions Ahead
abstract: The presentation will introduce ispace's three-step vision beyond GLXP, the technology that ispace is developing for lunar exploration, and opportunities for the scientific community throughout our mission.
author: Ichikawa, R.

title: Space Transportation Network Analysis for Cislunar Space Economy with Lunar Resources
abstract: This work provides a transportation network analysis of lunar exploration architecture and cislunar mission design with lunar in-situ resource utilization (ISRU).
author: Ho, K.; Chen, H.

title: Coping with Dust for Extraterrestrial Exploration
abstract: Dust presented challenges for previous lunar exploration missions. Astronauts indicated more extensive pursuits are not possible unless solutions are found to mitigate/avoid exposure. I will present evidence along with mitigation proposals.
author: Creel, R.

title: The 2017 Space Resources Roundtable and New Space Resources Graduate Program at Colorado School of Mines
abstract: For eighteen years, SRR has brought together interested individuals from the space exploration community, the mining and minerals industries, and the financial sector to discuss issues related to the ISRU of lunar, asteroidal, and martian resources.
author: Abbud-Madrid, A.

title: China's Lunar Exploration Programme
abstract: Update on China's lunar program.
author: Xiao, L.; Wang, Q.

title: Japanese Space Program Update
abstract: The JAXA's overall moon exploration scenario, including the water utilization, will be presented.
author: Masuda, K.; Sato, N.

title: The Planetary Science Workforce: Who Is Missing?
abstract: Absence of voices / Lost paths, lost thoughts, lost ideas / Who we are missing?
author: Rathbun, J. A.; Diniega, S.; Quick, L. C.; Grinspoon, D. H.; Hörst, S. M.; Lakdawalla, E. S.; Mandt, K. E.; Milazzo, M.; Piatek, J.; Prockter, L. M.; Rivera-Valentin, E. G.; Rivkin, A. S.; Thomas, C.; Tiscareno, M. S.; Turtle, E. P.; Vertesi, J. A.; Zellner, N.

title: Plumes Across the Solar System — When is Cryovolcanism Implicated?
abstract: Plumes have been detected at Enceladus, Triton, Mars, and probably Europa. This talk compares and contrasts their properties, with implications for the driving processes.
author: Hansen, C. J.

title: Cryomagma Ascent on Europa
abstract: This study aims at modeling the cryomagma ascent from a liquid reservoir to Europa's surface. We obtain the eruption duration and emitted cryomagma volume at the surface for different chamber depths and volumes and different cryomagma compositions.
author: Lesage, E.; Massol, H.; Schmidt, F.

title: Potential Mud Volcanism Type Processes on Pluto
abstract: Mapping and measurements of several vented dome structures on Pluto leans toward a mud-volcanism type process.
author: Ahrens, C. J.; Chevrier, V. F.

title: Volume Expansion of Ganymede due to Temperature Change and Phase Change of Ices
abstract: We estimate phase and volume changes coupled with Ganymede's thermal evolution using numerical simulations. From the results, we discuss surface features of Ganymede which could provide important constraints on interior dynamics and evolution.
author: Yoda, M.; Kimura, J.; Sekine, Y.; Kurita, K.

title: An Enthalpy Method to Simulate the Cryomagmatic Evolution of Impact Induced Melt Beneath Occator Crater on Ceres
abstract: An enthalpy method to simulate the cryomagmatic evolution of impact induced melt beneath Occator Crater on Ceres.
author: Hesse, M. A.; Castillo-Rogez, J. C.; Scully, J. E. C.

title: Systematic Spatial Variations in the Dust-to-Gas Ratio Within Enceladus' Plume
abstract: Simultaneous measurements of the gas and dust components of Enceladus' plume reveal that the material above Baghdad and Damascus sulci has a dust-to-gas ratio roughly an order of magnitude higher than the material above Alexandria and Cairo sulci.
author: Hedman, M. M.; Dhingra, D.; Hansen, C. J.; Portyankina, G.; Ye, S.

title: Cryovolcanic History of Ceres from Topography
abstract: We use image analysis and flow modeling of domes on Ceres to argue that they are cryovolcanic in origin. Results imply an average cryovolcanic rate of 10000 m^3/yr, orders of magnitude lower than rates of basaltic volcanism on terrestrial planets.
author: Sori, M. M.; Sizemore, H. G.; Byrne, S.; Bramson, A. M.; Bland, M. T.; Stein, N. T.; Russell, C. T.; Raymond, C. A.

title: Rheological Investigation of Cryovolcanic Slurries
abstract: Subliquidus rheological experiments will be conducted for briny cryovolcanic compositions. Understanding how these materials move, deform, and evolve upon crystallizing will help constrain what morphological features can form by various compositions.
author: Morrison, A. A.; Whittington, A. G.; Zhong, F.; Mitchell, K. L.; Carey, E. M.

title: Cold Case: Fractional Crystallization in Cryomagmatic Systems
abstract: Simulating the thermal and physicochemical properties of planetary oceans/brines/ices as they solidify. What we can learn from terrestrial sea ice.
author: Buffo, J. J.; Schmidt, B. E.; Walker, C. C.

title: Enceladus' Plumes Reflectance. Particle-in-Cell Model Parametric Study
abstract: In our work we are using kinetic numerical model to describe plumes curtain forms as a result of kinetic and thermodynamic processes: a) in the ocean, b) inside Tiger Stripes icy forms and c) over moon's surface.
author: Kotlarz, J. P.; Zalewska, N. E.

title: Phase Behaviour of Methane Hydrate Under Conditions Relevant to Titan's Interior
abstract: The high-pressure behaviour Clathrate hydrates, thought to be abundant in the outer solar system, underpins planetary modelling efforts of the interior of Titan, where clathrates are hypothesised to be the source of the dense N2, CH4 atmosphere.
author: Sclater, G.; Fortes, A. D.; Crawford, I. A.

title: Cryovolcanism on Pluto from the New Horizons Flyby
abstract: Overview of the morphology, composition, and possible formation mechanism of Pluto's putative cyrovolcanic constructs.
author: Singer, K. N.; Schenk, P. M.; White, O. L.; Moore, J. M.; McKinnon, W. B.; Beyer, R. A.; Spencer, J. R.; Howard, A. D.; Schmitt, B.; Stern, S. A.; Cook, J. C.; Grundy, W. M.; Cruikshank, D. P.; Umurhan, O.; Protopappa, S.; Lauer, T. R.; Weaver, H. A.; Young, L. A.; Olkin, C. B.; Ennico, K.

title: Are Floor-Fractured Craters on Ceres Formed by Cryomagmatism?
abstract: Several of the impact craters on Ceres have sets of fractures on their floors, morphologically similar lunar Floor-Fractured Craters. We present a geomorphic and topographic analysis of the cerean FFCs and propose hypotheses for their formation.
author: Buczkowski, D. L.; Sizemore, H. G.; Bland, M. T.; Scully, J. E. C.; Quick, L. C.; Hughson, K. H. G.; Park, R. S.; Preusker, F.; Raymond, C. A.; Russell, C. T.

title: Experimental Simulation of Cryomagmatic Processes. Water Ice, Clathrates and Salts
abstract: Study of diverse cryomagmatic processes based on the system H2O-CO2-MgSO4 with application to Europa. The type of the crystals formed is related to volume-temperature changes, while their morphology is associated with surface geological features.
author: Muñoz-Iglesias, V.; Prieto-Ballesteros, O.; López, I.

title: Heat Pipe Effects on Enceladus' South Polar Terrain and the Implications for Regional Heating and Eruption Activity
abstract: We model Enceladus' plume material passing through cracks in an icy crust. Repeated passage yields local thermal and structural weakness zones that favor additional eruptions through the same system, leaving more distant crustal areas cold and thick.
author: Sakimoto, S. E. H.; Gregg, T. K. P.

title: A Closer Look at Galileo Photopolarimeter-Radiometer (PPR) Data from a Possible Plume Source North of Pwyll, Europa
abstract: An endogenic source is not necessary to explain the temperature observations of the N. Pwyll region. However, the area has a particularly high thermal inertia, which may be indicative of plume fallout.
author: Rathbun, J. A.; Spencer, J. R.

title: Evolution of Photometric and Polarimetric Phase Curves of Fine-Grained Water Ice Particles due to Grain Sintering
abstract: Laboratory photometric and polarimetric phase curves of micrometer-sized water ice particles to elucidate the effect of grain sintering on scattering properties relevant for the analysis of potential plume deposition sites on icy satellites.
author: Jost, B.; Cerubini, R.; Poch, O.; Pommerol, A.; Thomas, N.

title: Stress, Tectonics and Cryovolcanism
abstract: Here we examine mechanisms, mostly tidal, that can impart stress to the surfaces of icy satellites, the formation of fractures as a response to these stresses, and the ability of these fracture to serve as conduits for eruptive processes.
author: Hurford, T. A.

title: Investigating the Dynamics of Dike-Fed Cryovolcanism
abstract: The density of cryomagmas relative to the ice shell is a common barrier to dike propagation. We hypothesize that including dike-tip degassing in dike propagation models will lower cryomagma densities, and allow for surface propagation.
author: Jozwiak, L. M.

title: The Europa Lander Mission Concept and Science Goals — Highlighting Ice Properties and Surface Activity
abstract: The Europa Lander mission concept would address key questions regarding ice properties and surface activity, including characterizing any plume deposits, understanding local topography, searching for evidence of interactions with liquid water.
author: Hand, K. P.; Murray, A. E.; Garvin, J.; Horst, S.; Brinckerhoff, W.; Edgett, K.; Hoehler, T.; Russell, M.; Rhoden, A.; Yingst, R. A.; German, C.; Schmidt, B.; Paranicas, C.; Smith, D.; Willis, P.; Hayes, A.; Ehlmann, B.; Lunine, J.; Templeton, A.; Nealson, K.; Christner, B.; Cable, M.; Craft, K.; Pappalardo, R.; Hofmann, A.; Nordheim, T.; Phillips, C.

title: Heat Generating Processes and Their Affects on Ice and Ice Mixtures: On the Potential Origins of Cryovolcanism in the Solar System
abstract: A summary of our knowledge about cryovolcanism and information about the composition and rheology of relevant ice system.
author: McCarthy, C.

title: Modeling the Enceladus, Europa and Io Plumes; a Contrast
abstract: We present a comparison of simulations of the Enceladus, Europa and Io plumes.
author: Goldstein, D. B.; Mahieux, A.; Hoey, W.; Ackley, P.; McDoniel, W.; Yeoh, S.; Berg, J.; Trafton, L.; Varghese, P.

title: Testing the Cryovolcanism Hypothesis for Vulcan Planum, Charon
abstract: Shape of bending plate / Not cryovolcanism / Explains Vulcan moat.
author: Borrelli, M. E.; Collins, G. C.

title: Eruption Style Sensitivity to Cryomagma-Volatile Coupling in Conduits on Enceladus and Other Ocean Worlds
abstract: Enceladus plumes / Effervescent eruptions / Fueled by hydrogen.
author: Mitchell, K. L.

title: What can Silicate Volcanism tell Us About Cryovolcanism?
abstract: This contribution is intended to inspire discussion about the validity and limits of applicability of models of silicate volcanism with a view to further elucidating cryovolcanic processes.
author: Fagents, S. A.

title: Brine-Driven Volcanism at Ceres
abstract: This presentation will review our understanding of Ceres' brine chemistry and its role in geological activity.
author: Castillo-Rogez, J. C.; Quick, L.; Scully, J. E. C.; Hesse, M. A.; Raymond, C. A.

title: Investigating Effects of Subsurface Cryovolcanic Chamber Pressurization on Ceres and Icy Moons — Fracturing, Cryovolcanism, and Surface Response
abstract: Investigations of fractures, cryovolcanism, and surface response driven by over-pressurization as a cryomagma chamber cools and freezes.
author: Craft, K. L.; Lowell, R. P.; Walker, C. C.; Quick, L. C.

title: Determining Heat Fluxes of Small Icy Bodies Using 2D Numerical Models
abstract: Validating heat fluxes generated by 1D parameterized models for small icy body evolution by performing 2D numerical convection simulations with implications for cryovolcanism.
author: Allu Peddinti, D.; Desch, S. J.

title: Breaking the BBC (Buoyancy Barriers to Cryovolcanism)
abstract: Like Australian table wines, Cryovolcanism has been poo-poohed, because of a perceived negative buoyancy problem. Here we point out that several basaltic planets have overcome far worse barriers, and calculate a scenario for cyrovolcanism on Pluto.
author: McGovern, P. J.; White, O. L.

title: Vulcan Planitia, Type Example of Outer Solar System Ammonia-Water Cryovolcanism
abstract: Pluto's moon Charon offered the first clear (ground-based) evidence for the ammonia-water volcanism predicted long ago by J.S. Lewis. New Horizons then obtained compelling evidence for an ammonia-bearing cryovolcanic plain. But how did it get there?
author: McKinnon, W. B.; Beyer, R. A.; Schenk, P. M.; Moore, J. M.; Singer, K. N.; White, O. L.; Spencer, J. R.; Cook, J. C.; Grundy, W. M.; Cruikshank, D. P.; Weaver, H. A.; Young, L. A.; Olkin, C. B.; Stern, S. A.; Robbins, S. J.; New Horizons GGI Team; New Horizons Composition Team

title: Charon's Smooth Plains
abstract: We hypothesize that Charon's smooth plains result from its global extension that caused crustal blocks to founder. Then, a viscous cryoflow composed of ammonia-rich mantle material rose up, enveloped the sinking blocks, and produced the plains.
author: Beyer, R. A.; Spencer, J. R.; Nimmo, F.; Beddingfield, C.; Grundy, W. M.; McKinnon, W. B.; Moore, J.; Robbins, S.; Runyon, K.; Schenk, P.; Singer, K.; Weaver, H.; Young, L. A.; Ennico, K.; Olkin, C.; Stern, S. A.; New Horizons Science Team

title: Cryovolcanism in Concept and Reality
abstract: Cryovolcanism, cryomagmatism and related terms pertain to the melting and solid-liquid phase separation, intracrustal transfer, eruption, and flow of aqueous or other cold liquids on icy planets, satellites, comets, and asteroids.
author: Kargel, J. S.

title: Cryovolcanism at Rhadamanthys Linea, Europa and the Role of Tidal Stresses
abstract: At Rhadamanthys linea the low-albedo areas are localized, causing a distinctive pattern of spots. In this work we investigate possible causes of this localization and the potential effects of tidal stresses.
author: Maxwell, R. E.; Nimmo, F.

title: Terrestrial Magma Dynamics as an Analog for Cryomagma Transport on Icy Worlds
abstract: We present modes of magma transport on Earth, and consider the extent to which these modes of transport might operate on icy worlds.
author: Quick, L. C.; Marsh, B. D.

title: Candidate (Cryo)Volcanic Features in the Outer Solar System: Observational Constraints
abstract: Volcanic constructs abound / Constraints are few and far between / Variety and complexity in style and composition.
author: Schenk, P.; Prockter, L.

title: Time Evolution of Ice-shell Thickness: Implications for Cryovolcanic Activity on Europa
abstract: Europa, amongst other icy bodies in our solar system, exhibits a suite of surface features with aligned chemistry indicative of transport between the ice-shell and ocean.
author: Allu Peddinti, D.; Rhoden, A. R.

title: Cryovolcanism on Titan
abstract: Titan's volcanoes: / None, or mostly veiled beneath / Cold seas, haze and gunk?
author: Mitchell, K. L.; Lopes, R. M. C.

title: Concepts and Planning for MSR Public Outreach
abstract: The Mars Sample Return (MSR) community now has an opportunity to build support through outreach to policy makers, the media, the public, teachers, and students. This presentation aims to start a dialogue on concepts and planning for MSR outreach.
author: Heward, A. R.

title: Lunar Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (LSMES)
abstract: This study seeks a method to efficiently store electrical energy without using chemical batteries, by applying terrestrial technology based on a superconducting coil and a persistent magnetic field located in a lunar permanently shadowed crater.
author: Evans, M. E.; Ignatiev, A.

title: Passive Survivability of 18650 Lithium-Ion Cells Through Lunar Night Environment Scenario
abstract: Present study describes passive survivability of commercially-off-the-shelf 18650 lithium-ion cells tested in an environmental scenario similar to onset and progress of lunar night that is at cryogenic temperatures under vacuum for 336 earth hours.
author: Nandini, K.; Usha, K.; Srinivasan, M. S.; Pramod, M.; Satyanarayana, P.; Sankaran, M.

title: Data Encoded Laser Wireless Power (DELWP) for Lunar Polar Applications
abstract: Data encoded high power fiber lasers illuminating specialized tuned photovoltaic panels designed for power transfer will provide reliable, continuous power and data during periods of limited solar illumination, including into the dark polar craters.
author: Poulos, D. D.

title: Darkness Visible: Instrumentation and Thermal Design to Access the Hidden Moon
abstract: We show mission concepts for a long-lived geophysical network and in-situ investigation of volatiles in the lunar polar cold traps, and Ball instrument and thermal technology enabling survival, situational awareness, and operations in the dark Moon.
author: Van Cleve, J. E.; Weinberg, J. D.; Neal, C. R.; Elphic, R. C.; Weed, K.; Mills, G.; Dissly, R.

title: Small Modular Fission Reactors that Enable Affordable and Sustainable Lunar Enterprise
abstract: We will present the results of a study looking at the use of a LEU-based Small Modular Fission Reactor (SMFR) in the 40 to 100 kW range for lunar activities, building on the results of NASA's HEU-based KiloPower project.
author: Herring, J. S.; Mackwell, S.; Pestak, C.

title: Multi-Lunar Day Polar Missions with a Solar-Only Rover
abstract: The lunar poles offer opportunities for solar-only rovers to survive and operate many lunar days. Presented here are examples of rover traverses that take advantage of the unique polar illumination environments to operate across multiple lunar days.
author: Colaprete, A.; Elphic, R. C.; Shirley, M.; Siegler, M.

title: Lighting Constraints to Lunar Surface Operations
abstract: An investigation into lunar surface ambient lighting levels indicates that, for most nearside locations, illumination will be adequate throughout a large portion of the lunar night to conduct surface activities.
author: Eppler, D. B.; Budden, N. A.

title: High Performance Thermal Switch for Lunar Night Survival
abstract: A high performance differential thermal expansion (DTE) thermal switch was developed to enable solar/battery powered lunar surface science payloads. The measured thermal switch performance is: 5 W/K ON, 0.002 W/K OFF, and 2500:1 ON/OFF ratio.
author: Bugby, D. C.; Clark, P. E.; Hofmann, D. C.

title: The Importance of Nightside Magnetometer Observations for Electromagnetic Sounding of the Moon
abstract: Nightside Time Domain Electromagnetic Sounding has the capability to advance the state of knowledge of the field of lunar science. This requires magnetometer operations to withstand the harsh conditions of the lunar night.
author: Fuqua Haviland, H.; Poppe, A. R.; Fatemi, S.; Delory, G.

title: Shifting the Paradigm of Coping with Nyx on the Moon — a Ground-Penetrating Radar Case
abstract: A multi-static, autonomous ground-penetrating radar instrument, MARGE, will incorporate strategies to be more tolerant of the lunar diurnal thermal cycle.
author: Nunes, D. C.; Carpenter, K.; Haynes, M.; de la Croix, J. P.

title: The Use of Lunar Resources for Energy Generation on the Moon
abstract: The resources of the Moon can be used to develop an electrical energy system for the Moon. This can be accomplished by leveraging vacuum deposition technology and lunar resources to fabricate a low-cost and scalable lunar power grid.
author: Ignatiev, A.

title: Requirement Analysis and Night Survival Concept for Z-01 Landing Mission Using Fuel Cell
abstract: Only three missions have survived the lunar night, using Radioisotope Thermo-Electric Generators and Radioisotope Heating Units. This paper discusses the challenges to survive lunar night and presents a fuel cell-based concept as an alternative.
author: Wani, S. C.; Shah, U. B.; Kothandhapani, A.; Garg, P.; Sahai, M.; Garg, M.; Nair, S.

title: Adapting Terrestrial Technology to the Design of a Night-Survivable 10 Meter Lunar Polar Prospecting Drill
abstract: This paper will explore the possibility of a 10 meter cryogenic lunar polar drill that could 'survive the night' and that would enable the collection of scientific data that could validate current models for polar resources.
author: Baiden, G. R.; Blair, B. R.

title: Lunar Roads: Strategies for Remaining in the Sunlight
abstract: By driving westward on the slowly rotating Moon, telerobots could remain in the sunlight while compressing the regolith in order to make basic, reduce-dust roads.
author: Plata, D. S.

title: Leveraging In-Situ Regolith Properties for Nighttime Heating
abstract: Despite large temperature fluctuations at the lunar surface, thermally coupling to warm nighttime materials (rocks, subsurface, etc.) present in-situ might provide some heating and reduce the engineering payload necessary for surviving the night.
author: Powell, T. M.; Siegler, M. A.; Molaro, J. L.; Paige, D. A.

title: Bulk Metallic Glass Gears for Lunar Night Capable Actuators
abstract: BMG Gears is developing unheated, cold-capable gearboxes for use in cryogenic environments such as lunar night. The enabling alloy properties, cryogenic test performance, part processing, qualification, TRL, and infusion challenges are discussed.
author: Dillon, R. P.; Borgonia, J. -P. C.; Roberts, S. N.; Hofmann, D. C.; Kennett, A.; Firdosy, S. A.; Wilcox, B. H.; Hales, S.; Smith, J. D.; Schuler, J.; McEnerney, B.; Shapiro, A. A.

title: Lunar Surface Gravimetry Surveying Through the Lunar Night
abstract: Lunar surface gravimetry is a powerful technique for probing the Moon's subsurface structure, using a gravimeter on a static lunar lander or on a lunar rover. Measurements spanning multiple lunar days will increase accuracy and resolution.
author: Carroll, K. A.

title: Utilization of Nuclear Power for Moon Missions: Nuclear Power Generation Using Helium Cooled Reactor for Moon Habitats
abstract: Abstract discusses using helium cooled nuclear reactors in Moon habitats to supply continuous power to the habitat as well as any future processing/manufacturing plants on the Moon.
author: Guven, U. G.; Singh, A. K. S.

title: Material Selection for Mechanical Mechanism Survival and Use in the Lunar Night
abstract: Survival of spacecraft mechanisms is challenging due to low polar temperatures. Structural and cutting materials enabling drilling and mining under deep cryogenic conditions are currently being tested under the NASA Early Stage Innovation program.
author: Nieczkoski, S.; Dreyer, C. B.; Blair, B.; Rostami, J.

title: Regenerative Fuel Cell-Based Energy Storage Systems for Lunar Surface Exploration

author: Guzik, M. C.; Gilligan, R. P.; Smith, P. J.; Jakupca, I. J.

title: Seasonal Temperature Variations in the Polar Regions of the Moon
abstract: Mapping of temperatures in the south polar region with LRO’s Diviner Lunar Radiometer Experiment shows how temperatures within 5 degrees of the pole vary considerably with season.
author: Williams, J. -P.; Greenhagen, B. T.; Paige, D. A.

title: MilliWatt Lunar VLBI Beacons: Surviving the Lunar Night
abstract: MilliWatt radio beacons could establish a lunar VLBI network for science and navigation in cislunar space, ideally operating for decades. Small, gm-scale Americium-241 batteries are proposed to meet the power and longevity needs of these networks.

title: A Strategy for Managing NASA's Long Tail of Planetary Research Data: Insights from the Development of the AHED Repository
abstract: We detail the architecture of the Astrobiology and Habitable Environments Database system to guide strategies for data management in other NASA-funded scientific disciplines where research is performed by individual PIs, and small research teams.
author: Bristow, T. F.; Lafuente, B.; Wolfe, S.; Parenteau, N.; Stone, N.; Rojo, S.; Boydstun, K.; Blake, D.; Downs, R.; Dateo, C.

title: Field Expedition Codes of Conduct for Increasing Safety and Inclusivity
abstract: Given the importance of research expeditions to planetary analog field sites, our community must work to make expeditions safe and inclusive. We provide recommendations and our teams' strategies to make the field safer.
author: Richardson, J. A.; Whelley, N. L.; Whelley, P. L.; Barry, C. E.; Young, K. E.

title: Status Update on the Inaugural NASA Planetary Geologic Mapping Workshop: Selected for June 2022
abstract: Our proposed planetary geologic mapping workshop has been selected for June 2022. Activities will include instruction, field trips, and mapping exercises. We are planning the workshop for the week before the PGMM and welcome community participation.
author: Burr, D. M.; Wolak Luna, J.; Learner Ponterio, Z. A.; Skinner, J. A.; Black, S. R.

title: Studies of In Situ Fissile Fuel from Lunar Resources
abstract: Lunar surface science for density sorting and neutron generation can be tested with lightweight hardware and modest tending. The outcome can prove technical feasibility of fueling a baseload fission plan on the Moon.
author: Schubert, P. J.

title: Lunar Node 1 and Beyond
abstract: Lunar Node 1 is an S-band navigation beacon for lunar applications that was recently designed and built at Marshall Space Flight Center. This presentation will discuss the design, upcoming surface mission, and future development of this concept.
author: Anzalone, E. J.; Bone, J. C.; Brooks, T. E.; Campbell, P. S.; Guillory, A. R.; Jensen, J. V.; Merrill, G. W.; Statham, T. L.

title: Knowledge of Impact Gardening is Necessary to Understand the History of Lunar Ice
abstract: Models of impact gardening reveal the history and context of cores and can help us interpret the history of lunar ice.
author: Costello, E. S.; Lucey, P. G.; Ghent, R. R.

title: Advancing Operational and Training Techniques for Artemis Missions
abstract: MSFC has integrated and operated the scientific payloads that are essential to human spaceflight. This abstract lays clear the challenges and proposes the elements necessary to achieve the aspirational scientific goals set out by the Artemis program.
author: Howley, I. J.; Byars, M. K.

title: Optical Monitoring of the Dust Environment Around Lunar Exploration Sites
abstract: A model study of whether it is possible to build an optical dust monitoring camera, using commercial off-the-shelf image sensors with wide-field optics, for use at exploration sites for science and human safety. Our results show that it is possible.
author: Lolachi, R.; Glenar, D. A.; Stubbs, T. J.

title: X-Ray Computed Tomography for the Analysis of Materials Collected at the Lunar South Pole
abstract: A variety of materials will be collected during future missions to the lunar south pole. We outline what materials may be collected and how the technique of X-ray computed tomography will help investigate these materials.
author: Gawronska, A. J.; McLeod, C. L.; Gilmour, C. M.

title: Replicating or Exceeding the Imagery from Apollo for Artemis Missions
abstract: The Apollo Program is remembered in large part thanks to the iconic imagery produced during the missions. As we plan for humankind's return to the Moon, there are significant challenges to replicate the quality of the imagery in the digital era.
author: Grubbs, R. P.

title: Passive Detection of Subsurface Lunar Ice Using the Askaryan Effect with the Cosmic Ray Lunar Sounder
abstract: The Cosmic Ray Lunar Sounder (CoRaLS) is a new orbital mission concept that uses the radio emission from ultrahigh energy cosmic ray impacts on the Moon (generated via the Askaryan effect) to detect and characterize subsurface layers of lunar ice.
author: Prechelt, R. L.; Romero-Wolf, A.; Costello, E.; Ghent, R.; Gorham, P. W.; Lucey, P.

title: In-Situ Artificial Substrate Witness Plates: Ground Truthing Scientific and Human Operations Relevant Processes on the Moon
abstract: In this study, we investigated the potential of using an artificial substrate-based witness plate to capture location dependent lunar processes. These plates are low cost, low mass, and produce a low environmental footprint.
author: Morrissey, L. S.; Saxena, P.; Curran, N.; McClain, J.; Killen, R. M.

title: Lunar Vertex: A PRISM Mission to a Magnetic Anomaly
abstract: Lunar Vertex is a PRISM lander/rover mission to investigate the Reiner Gamma magnetic anomaly and related phenomena, including a mini-magnetosphere and a lunar swirl.
author: Blewett, D. T.; Halekas, J.; Ho, G.; Greenhagen, B. T.; Anderson, B. J.; Regoli, L.; Vines, S. K.; Jahn, J. -M.; Kollmann, P.; Denevi, B. W.; Meyer, H. M.; Klima, R. L.; Cahill, J. T. S.; Hood, L. L.; Tikoo, S.; Zou, X. -D.; Fatemi, S.; Lemelin, M.; Wieczorek, M. A.; Boldt, J. D.; Cox, A. L.

title: A Legacy of Lunar Water Through SOFIA
abstract: We have preliminary approval from SOFIA to conduct a two-year Legacy campaign to map water on the sunlit Moon. We will sample a large fraction of the surface and volcanic features to identify areas of concentrated water for possible landing sites.
author: Honniball, C. I.; Lucey, P. G.; Reach, W. T.

title: Advances in Lunar Science Return via Distributed Instrument Mobility and Swarm Robotics: The Lunar Outpost Mobile Autonomous Prospecting Platform (MAPP) Rovers
abstract: Lunar Outpost has developed the MAPP rover to enable suites of instruments to be deployed in multi-instrument campaigns across multiple small rovers, deploying large instrument networks and investigating science sites in high resolution.
author: Gemer, A. J.; Cyrus, J. A.; Meyen, F.; Cyrus, J. B.

title: Electrostatic Dust Analyzer (EDA) for Measuring Dust Transport on the Lunar Surface
abstract: The Electrostatic Dust Analyzer (EDA) will quantitatively measure electrostatically lofted lunar dust in order to provide insights into its effects on the lunar surface properties and assess potential risks posed by lofted dust to human exploration.
author: Wang, X.; Sternovsky, Z.; Horanyi, M.; Deca, J.; Garrick-Bethell, I.; Farrell, W. M.; Minafra, J.; Bucciantini, L.

title: Lunar Science and Exploration at Marshall Space Flight Center
abstract: Under the Artemis program for lunar exploration, the Agency is planning an ambitious path forward to the Moon. NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center offers unique capabilities in propulsion, technology, engineering, science, and exploration.
author: Weber, R. C.; Dankanich, J.; Herrmann, N.

title: Suitability of an MSL-Generation APXS in a Lunar Setting and Future Improvements
abstract: We investigate the performance of an MSL-like APXS instrument for expected in-situ lunar samples.
author: Gellert, R.; VanBommel, S. V.; Cloutis, E. A.; Kerber, L.

title: 12 Action Items for Optimizing Human Exploration and Lunar Science in the Next 5 Years
abstract: We identify 12 themes/objectives for the next 5 years to optimize chances of collecting a representative sample of the Moon outside the Apollo-Luna exploration region, with emphasis on obtaining samples of South Pole-Aitken (SPA) Basin ejecta.
author: Head, J. W.; Scott, D. R.

title: Gruithusien Domes: Insights from Silicate Mineralogy and Surface Textures
abstract: A landed mission to GD should emphasize techniques that clarify variations in silica mineralogy to identify different types of silicic minerals and glasses at the surface including Raman spectroscopy, micro-morphometric analysis, and thermal imaging.
author: Bower, D. M.; Livengood, T. L.; Barker, M. A.; Honniball, C. I.; Hewagama, T.

title: Utilization Scenarios — Outcome of the Space Resources Week 2021
abstract: The European Space Agency (ESA) and Luxembourg Space Agency (LSA) gathered the international community at the Space Resources Week 2021 to discuss future Utilization Scenarios. This talk presents the outcome of the discussion groups.
author: Meurisse, A.; Mousel, J.; Kapoglou, A.; Conti, M.; Makaya, A.; Cowley, A.; Carpenter, J.; Link, M.; Hufenbach, B.

title: An International Lunar Resource Prospecting Campaign
abstract: An international lunar resource prospecting campaign allows data to be collected that inform the reserve potential of such resources in compliance with the Outer Space Treaty.
author: Neal, C. R.; Abbud-Madrid, A.; Carpenter, J.

title: NASA Lunar Surface Habitat: Enabling a Sustained Lunar Presence
abstract: This lunar Surface Habitat (SH) topic will provide an overview of the Surface Habitat as an anchor to establishing a sustained lunar presence and the challenges faced operating on the lunar surface.
author: Kessler, P. D.

title: Distributed Autonomy for Lunar Micro-Rovers — A Case Study for the Emirates Lunar Mission
abstract: In 2022, Mission Control will demonstrate AI-based lunar terrain classification using images from the Rashid micro-rover. This will support science and navigation operations, showcasing how these technologies can add autonomy for future lunar rovers.
author: Battler, M. M.; Faragalli, M.; Cross, M.; Raimalwala, K.; Cole, M.; Smal, E.; Reid, J. E.; Cloutis, E.; Newman, J.; Skonieczny, K.

title: The Lunar Geophysical Network Landing Sites Science Rationale
abstract: Rationale for landing sites for the Lunar Geophysical Network (LGN) mission is highlighted. Returning to the lunar surface with a long-lived geophysical network is a key next step to advance lunar and planetary science.
author: Fuqua Haviland, H.; Weber, R. C.; Neal, C. R.; Lognonné, P.; Garcia, R. F.; Schmerr, N.; Nagihara, S.; Grimm, R.; Currie, D. G.; Dell'Agnello, S.; Watters, T. R.; Panning, M. P.; Johnson, C. L.; Yamada, R.; Knapmeyer, M.; Ostrach, L. R.; Kawamura, T.; Petro, N.; Bremner, P. M.

title: A Next-Generation Lunar Orbiter to Support Lunar Science and Exploration
abstract: NASA should consider post-LRO remote sensing strategies for lunar remote sensing. I present a notional payload for a Next-Generation Lunar Orbiter and tie measurements that would be enabled by such a mission to lunar science and exploration goals.
author: Glotch, T. D.

title: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter in 2021 and Beyond: Status and Future Plans
abstract: LRO is in its 12th year at the Moon, enabling new science, observing changes to the lunar surface and environment over the human timescale. Our ability to respond to data requests in support of missions to the surface is a critical resource for NASA.
author: Petro, N. E.; Elder, C.; Stickle, A.; Stopar, J.; Banks, M.; Keller, J.

title: From Apollo to Artemis: How ANGSA Helps Preparing for Future Sample Missions to the Moon and Beyond
abstract: Analyses of ANGSA samples with new tools and technologies will maximize the science return from Apollo and enable new generations of scientists and curators to refine their techniques and help prepare future explorers for future lunar missions.
author: Gross, J.; Zeigler, R. A.; McCubbin, F. M.; Shearer, C.; Angsa Science Team

title: New LRO Investigations of Volcanism, Tectonism, and the Lunar Interior
abstract: LRO will collect new data needed to answer evolving science questions about the lunar interior, volcanism, and tectonics, as well as provide additional orbital context for the forthcoming era of lunar exploration.
author: Stopar, J. D.; Banks, M. E.; Elder, C. M.; Keller, J. W.; Petro, N. E.; Stickle, A. M.; LRO Team

title: New High Resolution Polar Topographic Products from the Lunar Orbiter Laser Altimeter (LOLA)
abstract: We are creating new high-resolution (5 m/pix) topographic models of high-priority south pole sites based only on laser altimetry data acquired by the Lunar Orbiter Laser Altimeter (LOLA) onboard the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter (LRO).
author: Barker, M. K.; Mazarico, E.; Smith, D. E.; Sun, X.; Zuber, M. T.; Neumann, G. A.; Head, J. W.

title: Keep Your Ion the Next Five Years: CRATER, a Laser Ablation Orbitrap Mass Spectrometer for Future Lunar Exploration
abstract: CRATER — a laser ablation mass spectrometer — enables in situ determination of mineralogy, organic inventory, and elemental and isotopic fingerprints of lunar samples with unprecedented mass resolving power and mass accuracy for spaceflight technology.
author: Willhite, L. N.; Arevalo, R.; Southard, A. E.; Llano, J. M.; Bardyn, A.; Ni, Z.; Graham, J. D.; Grubisic, A.; Danell, R. M.; Minasola, N.; Gundersen, C.; Lee, J.; Fahey, M. E.; Yu, A. W.; Ersahin, A.; Briois, C.; Thirkell, L.; Colin, F.; Cohen, B. A.; Makarov, A. A.

title: Design and Use of the Cold Operable Lunar Deployable Arm End Effector for Geotechnical Investigations
abstract: The Cold Operable Lunar Deployable Arm is a Lunar tech demo that consists of a robotic arm and end effector (EE). Here we present the design of the end effector and how it can be used to perform basic excavation and geotechnical surface interactions.
author: Backus, S. B.; Moreland, S.; Kerber, L.; McCormick, R.

title: Mote Lunar Penetrator Arrays for Rapid Exploration of Extreme Lunar Terrains
abstract: Here we describe the "Mote" ballistic penetrators developed to support lunar science by allowing precursor missions to difficult to reach terrain, and through the rapid creation of instrument and communications arrays on the lunar surface.
author: Eubanks, T. M.; Blase, W. P.

title: LRO Investigations of Volatiles Processes and the Space Environment of the Moon
abstract: Summary of current science results and future plans from the LRO Volatiles, Exosphere, and Space Environment investigations.
author: Stickle, A. M.; Petro, N. E.; Elder, C. M.; Stopar, J. D.; Banks, M. E.; Keller, J. W.; LRO Science Team

title: The Lunar Geophysical Network Mission
abstract: The science and exploration justification behind the Lunar Geophysical Network mission is given in this paper.
author: Neal, C. R.; Weber, R. C.; Banerdt, W. B.; Beghein, C.; Chi, P.; Currie, D.; Dell'Agnello, S.; Garcia, R.; Garrick-Bethell, I.; Grimm, R.; Grott, M.; Haviland, H.; Kawamura, T.; Johnson, C.; Kedar, S.; Lognonne, P.; Nagihara, S.; Nakamura, Y.; Nunn, C.; Ostrach, L.; Panning, M.; Petro, N.; Schmerr, N.; Siegler, M.; Watters, T.; Wieczorek, M.; Zacny, K.

title: A 21-cm Cosmology Experiment on the Far Side of the Moon
abstract: We simulated the galactic radio spectrum that would be measured by an antenna located at the Schrödinger Basin. A real antenna will measure this radiation and a weak background of cosmic H I emission. We explore how the H I signal might be detected.
author: Page, B.; Bale, S. D.; Slosar, A.

title: Lunar Night Survival and Operation Utilizing Commercial Radioisotope Heaters and Electric Generators
abstract: Atomic batteries are enabling lunar operations. USNC-Tech is developing commercial watt-scale batteries looking to license and flight demo the technology around 2024. USNC-Tech is soliciting input from the science community.
author: Morrison, C. G.

title: ispace's 2022 Mission and Future Commercial Capabilities for Lunar Science Missions
abstract: ispace technologies U.S. will present how our U.S.-based advanced lander program will facilitate future landed science missions and advanced mobility options for the planetary science community over the next five years.
author: Acierno, K.; O'Neill, K.

title: Lunar Mobility as a Service in the Next Five Years: A Software Perspective
abstract: Astrobotic's developments of the CubeRover mobility platform and Lunar Mobility as a Service model have provided insights to the software ecosystem that will begin to emerge as lunar surface operations are increased.
author: Whitaker, T. J. L.; Rampolla, C.; De La Fuente, C. C.; Provenzano, M.

title: Environmental Analysis of the Bounded Lunar Exosphere (ENABLE): Analytical Chemistry in Extreme High Vacuum (XHV)
abstract: A prototype mass spectrometer is being developed for lunar surface operations from a commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) instrument with wide pressure, mass range, and target mass capabilities and operable in a number of lunar mission scenarios.
author: Patrick, E. L.; Blase, R. L.

title: The Scientific Value of Lunar Sample Exchange
abstract: As we consider the future of lunar science and exploration, we emphasize the benefit of sample exchange and sample sharing between all nations. Here we draw attention to the past exchange of Apollo and Luna samples between different countries.
author: Barnes, J. J.; Crow, C.; Jolliff, B. L.; Joy, K. H.; Lapen, T.; Gross, J.; Mitchell, J.; Zeigler, R.; Fagan, A. L.

title: LRO Investigations of Regolith and Impacts
abstract: A brief summary of highlights from the LRO extended mission 4 investigations relating to regolith and impacts, and ideas for potential investigations in LRO extended mission 5.
author: Elder, C. M.; Petro, N. E.; Keller, J.; Stickle, A. M.; Stopar, J.; Banks, M.; LRO Science Team

title: Lunar ExoCam — Surface Measurement of Lunar Dust Plume Migration
abstract: Summary of current development of the Lunar ExoCam remote video and sensor payload system. This project was awarded a NASA Flight Opportunities grant in Oct. 2020 for test flight on board Masten Space Systems Xodiac rocket, to be completed Oct. 2021.
author: Mezilis, J. A.; Ridenoure, R.; Hovik, W.; Zacny, K.; Bergman, D.; Bell, J.; Jacobs, D. C.; McCormick, C.; Adkins, M.; Das, J.; Anand, H.; Masud, A.; Antervedi, L. G. P.; Mick, D.; Davis, K.

title: Intense Passive Commercial X-Ray Sources for Chemical and Elemental Analysis
abstract: USNC-Tech is developing radioisotope technology for heat and electricity called the Chargeable Atomic Battery (CAB). However, the same technology can be used to generate sources of passive X-rays larger than has traditionally been used.
author: Morrison, C. G.

title: Lunar Autonomous Robotic Rover System
abstract: The Lunar Autonomous Robotic Rover will permit documentation of Artemis science and exploration to be comprehensive, near-real-time, and representative of the advanced technological capabilities of the day.
author: Sweeney, T.; Schrock, R.; Hoyt, J.; Hurtado, J. M.

title: LRO Support for Lunar Surface Exploration
abstract: LRO continues to serve the lunar community and facilitate lunar surface exploration with a wealth of data products and PDS-archived data (data volume of >1.2 PB), and ongoing acquisition of Constellation-site-quality observations.
author: Banks, M. E.; Elder, C. M.; Keller, J. W.; Petro, N. E.; Stickle, A. M.; Stopar, J. D.

title: The Unresolved Problem with Deriving a Lunar Temperature Profile from Heat Producing Elements
abstract: This work is about calculating whole-Moon 1D thermal profiles. The focus of this presentation is to highlight how including internal heating contributions from current estimates of radioactive decay produce hot, or extremely hot selenotherms.
author: Bremner, P. M.; Haviland, H. F.; Mallik, A.; Diamond, M.

title: Radiation Dosage from Solar Energetic Particles Around a Lunar Crater
abstract: The level of radiation exposure at a given location on the Moon is dependent on the amount incident from above the local horizon. Here we consider the radiation exposure around simple lunar craters that are representative of the types of landforms that will be encountered by future landed missions.
author: Phipps, P. H.; Stubbs, T. J.; Looper, M. D.; Spence, H. E.; Townsend, L. W.

title: Cislunar Explorers: A Student Cubesat Demonstrating Low-Cost Technologies for Lunar Exploration
abstract: Developed in 2014 by students at Cornell, the Cislunar Explorers mission proposes to send a pair of 3U CubeSats to lunar orbit and demonstrate new technologies for water electrolysis propulsion and optical navigation in cislunar space.
author: Muhlberger, C. D.

title: InSight's Diversity and Inclusion Working Group
abstract: InSight science team / Diversity and inclusion / Working group presents.
author: Marusiak, A. G.; Baker, M.; Beghein, C.; Daubar, I. J.; Fernando, B.; Irving, J. C. E.; Johnson, C. L.; Morgan, P.; Newman, C.; Panning, M. P.; Smrekar, S.; Stanley, S.

title: The Manitoba Lunar and Planetary STEM Network (MLaPS): A K-12 STEM Initiative
abstract: The Manitoba Lunar and Planetary STEM Network is developing, delivering, testing, and refining a range of lunar exploration materials and hands-on activities.
author: Cloutis, E. A.; Kiddell, C. B.; Misner, A.; Lukie, M.; Ferguson, P.

title: Testing Accessibility Accommodations for Disabled or Mixed-Ability Crews Operating in Space-Like Environments
abstract: Mission: AstroAccess launched twelve disabled individuals on a parabolic ZERO-G flight to test accessibility accommodations for future disabled astronauts.
author: Molaro, J. L.; Wells-Jensen, S.; Virre, E.; Kapusta, A. B.; Voelker, A. D.; Whitesides, G. T.; Bailey, T.; Deroko, B.; Deming, M. A.; Fauerbach, M.; Gifford, S.; Jha, S.; Johnson, J. C.; Johnson, P. A.; Mardon, A. A.; O'Brien, C. A. L.; Zucker, H. R.

title: InSightSeers: Early Career Opportunity to Observe the InSight Science Team at Work
abstract: Early-career researchers observe mission science team meetings. Goals include exposure to work, research, team dynamics, networking, help inform career paths.
author: Daubar, I. J.; Stanley, S.; Irving, J.; Marusiak, A. G.; Morgan, P.; Fernando, B.; Mittelholz, A.; Golombek, M. P.; Johnson, C. L.; Newman, C.; Baker, M.; Beghein, C.; Bozdag, E.

author: Shupla, C.; Gorce, J. S.; Filiberto, J.; Mane, P.; Rivera-Valentín, E. G.; Svambera, C.

author: Rathbun, J. A.; Rivera-Valentín, E. G.; Diniega, S.

title: Using Effective Practices in Inclusion, Diversity, Equity, and Accessibility to Engage with Underrepresented Audiences in STEM
abstract: The Planetary ReaCH project is designed to build the planetary community's capacity to engage Black and Latinx communities with planetary science content.
author: Shaner, A. J.; Buxner, S.; Lynch, K. L.; Matiella Novak, A.; Merkel, A. W.; Rivera-Valentín, E. G.; Rubino-Hare, L.; Shebby, S.; Shupla, C.

title: Advancing Inclusion, Diversity, Equity, and Accessibility in the Lunar and Planetary Exploration Community Through Mission Control Software
abstract: An overview of how our Mission Control Software improves accessibility for remote participants in lunar and planetary missions, and use cases for education.
author: Battler, M. M.; Macdonald, A. J.; Cross, M.; Raimalwala, K. V.; Chatrath, V.

abstract: Science is shared here / But crowded halls, stairs — no access? / Yes, we can fix this.
author: Piatek, J. L.

title: Beyond Permits: Expanding Fieldwork Protocols to Include Relationship Building with Indigenous Communities
abstract: Calling for a cultural change in the scientific community to embrace relationship-building with Indigenous communities as part of fieldwork protocol and process.
author: Scalice, D. M.; Kirven-Brooks, M.; Gronstal, A. L.; Gardner Vandy, K. G.

title: Enabling a Diverse and Inclusive STEM Workforce by Identifying and Mitigating the Barriers to Success
abstract: The L'SPACE Program model works to address many of the challenges and barriers that can lead to inequity in technical workforce preparation opportunities.
author: Klug Boonstra, S.; Garcia, D.; Kretke, K.; Acuña, A.; Storksdieck, M.; Buxner, S.; Fischer, H.

title: The Need for an Intersectional Perspective to Improve the State of the Profession in Planetary Science
abstract: We review data on some of the opportunity gaps faced by women of color and argue that future IDEA initiatives should employ an intersectional perspective.
author: Rivera-Valentín, E. G.; Rathbun, J. A.; Lynch, K. L.

title: Applying the Braided River STEM Workforce Development Model to Planetary Science and Astrobiology
abstract: Replacing the leaky pipeline model with the braided river STEM workforce development model allows an inclusive, diverse workforce to thrive in our community.
author: Gardner-Vandy, K. G.; Batchelor, R. L.; Scalice, D. M.

title: Developing Community Resources to Promote Safety and Inclusivity in Field Work
abstract: Three teams work together to set field research expeditions up for success with a jointly developed Field Safety Plan, Code of Conduct, and Bill of Rights.
author: Barry, C.; Whelley, N.; Richardson, J.; Whelley, P.; Glotch, T.; Young, K.; McAdam, A.; Schmerr, N.

abstract: Preliminary results for PSD pilot program Here to Observe (H2O) where undergrads observe NASA mission team meetings alongside mentors, with the goal of improving DEIA outcomes.

abstract: So many careers! / PAWS helps you explore and find / The one best for you.

abstract: An overview on the efforts of the EuroSpaceHub project to foster collaboration, innovation, entrepreneurship, and access to funding opportunities in aerospace.
author: Crotti, S.; Pascual, J.; Puriené, V.; Foing, B.; EuroSpaceHub Team

title: Unbounded Learning Environments as an Approach to Preserving Design Flexibility Demonstrated with NASA STEM Enhancement in Earth Science (SEES) Students
abstract: NASA summer students utilizing publicly available info and unbounded learning exercise in order to emulate building a lunar workspace upon the surface of the Moon.
author: Zacha, Z.; Williams, K.; Brown, B. H.; Cardenas, E.; Gomez, T.; Miller, C.; Foxworth, S.; Baguio, M. R.; Lewis, E. K.

abstract: The current naming conventions for planetary features exacerbate the underrepresentation of marginalized groups in space science.

abstract: In this abstract we discuss the implementation of inclusion plans for some ROSES program elements in NASA's SMD.

title: Diversity and Inclusion in Spacecraft Science Teams: What Do We Know and What Can We Do About It?
abstract: Do you need help with / Writing an inclusion plan? / Here are data and ideas.
author: Rathbun, J. A.; Rivera-Valentín, E. G.; Bayron, J.; Quick, L. C.

title: USGS STEP UP! Employee Empowerment Strategies: A Bystander Intervention Program for the Planetary Science Community
abstract: We describe a Bystander Intervention training that is available at no cost for the planetary science community and can be a resource for Inclusion Plans.
author: Bennett, K. A.; Garcia, P.; Keszthelyi, L.

title: Introducing the New NASA Science Mission Directorate's ROSES 2021 Research and Analysis Yearbook: An Online Resource for Programmatic and Self-Reported Demographic Data
abstract: The NASA Science Mission Directorate Data Analytics Team is excited to share a new resource for programmatic and self-reported demographic data.
author: Jensen, H. B.; Pappas, L. L.; Taha, N. A.; New, M. H.

title: Cross-AG Inclusion, Diversity, Equity and Accessibility (IDEA) Working Group: 2023 Priorities
abstract: The Cross-AG Inclusion, Diversity, Equity and Accessibility Working Group presents our 2023 priorities.
author: McAdam, M. M.; Rathbun, J.; McCanta, M. C.; Deutsch, A.; Knicely, J.; Neveu, M.; Dinwiddie, C. L.; Roberts, J. H.; Thomson, B. J.; Regoli, L. H.; Izenberg, N. R.; Stopar, J.; Gaddis, L. R.; Mane, P.; Bjonnes, E.; Bennett, K. A.; Venkatesan, A.

title: From Classroom to Career: Changing the Culture of Geoscience (We're Quite Aware of What We're Going Through)
abstract: Old ways block access / How should we change our culture? / New ways open doors.
author: Piatek, J. L.; Marshall, A. M.; Cervato, C.; Cooke, M. L.; Jackson, S.; Sibert, E. C.

title: Co-Creating Ethical Practices and Approaches to Fieldwork
abstract: Supporting the evolution of ethics for fieldwork by centering indigenous knowledges and perspectives.
author: Scalice, D. M.; Ryan Davis, J.; Chan, M. A.; Lagroix, F.

title: IDEA: Principles in Practice with the TREX Analog Rover Team
abstract: We report demographics of the TREX 2022 participating science team, share feedback from the field science team, and offer recommendations for other field teams.
author: Patterson, R. V.; Meier, M. L.; Hendrix, A.; Buxner, S.; Grier, J. A.

title: Results of the 2022 Mental Health Survey of the Planetary Science Community
abstract: We used assessments measuring depression, anxiety, and stress to investigate the mental health of the planetary science community.
author: Trang, D.; Swafford, C. E. M.; Vance, S. D.; Davidson, J.; Filiberto, J.; Ostrach, L. R.; Richey, C. R.

title: Insights from InSight: Strategies for Advancing Early-Career Researcher Inclusion in Planetary Science Missions
abstract: They be new to space / Early career researchers / How do we include?
author: Fernando, B. A.; Daubar, I. J.; Marusiak, A. G.; Baker, M.; Newman, C.; Irving, J. C. E.; Panning, M. P.; Banerdt, W. B.; Stanley, S.

title: If It's Worth Doing, It's Worth Paying For
abstract: You want it done right? / You better have the money. / Folks can't work for free.
author: Roberts, J. H.; Rathbun, J. A.; Daubar, I. J.

title: The Cost of Diminished In-Person Participation in Unsafe Locations: The Necessity of Hybrid Meetings
abstract: The changing political location is a detriment to the safety of many of our members attending in person meetings. Hybrid options are one adequate solution.
author: Elrod, M. K.; Roberts, J. H.; Daubar, I. J.

title: GeoSPACE: An Approach to Accessible and Inclusive Planetary Science Education.
abstract: The fields of planetary science and geology aim to learn/educate about our solar system. It is important to focus on accessibility and inclusivity in the fields.
author: Cabalceta, M. S.; Meier, M. L.; Thompson, A.; Baker, A.; Marshall, A.; Williams, A. J.; Piatek, J. L.; Arroyo, Y.; Collins, T.; Thatcher, S.; Gallant, E.; Elardo, S.; Williams, D. A.

title: NASA L'SPACE Program: Reimagining Agile, Equitable, Technical STEM Workforce Development for All
abstract: L'SPACE addresses the need for an equitable, inclusive technical STEM workforce model that can be delivered at scale.
author: Klug Boonstra, S.; Garcia, D.; Kretke, K.; Storksdieck, M.; Fischer, H.; Buxner, S.

title: Grimaldi Basin: Science Goals and Exploration from Geologic Mapping
abstract: Age determination of ejecta deposits near Grimaldi D Crater could constrain the formation time of Grimaldi Basin as one step toward establishing a precise lunar basin chronology. A robotic or human mission could accomplish this.
author: Runyon, K. D.; Buczkowski, D. L.; Greenhagen, B. T.; Moriarty, D. P.; Petro, N. E.; van der Bogert, C. H.; Hiesinger, H.

title: Training for Artemis Base Camp: EMMPOL 15 Analogue Astronaut Mission Overview
abstract: EMMPOL 15 was an analog astronaut mission performed in the Analogue Astronaut Training Centre (AATC) in Poland in February/March.
author: Osoianu, D.; Molony, S.; Hutchinson, A.; Barker, N.; Guziewicz, W.; Kołodziejczyk, A.; Foing, B.

title: Living in the Artemis Base Camp: Life-Science Experiments in EMMPOL 15 EuroMoonMars Poland
abstract: This abstract talks about the EMMPOL 15 mission and the experiments conducted that could be addressed in the Artemis Base Camp.
author: Molony, S. M.; Guziewicz, W. G.; Osoianu, D. O.; Hutchison, A. H.; Barker, N. B.; Foing, B. F.

title: Enabling Global Lunar Surface Mobility with the Artemis Base Camp
abstract: In situ resource utilization at the Artemis Base Camp enables the operation of a crewed hopping lander or hopper. This vehicle would revolutionize lunar science by allowing field geologists to access the entire lunar surface.
author: Longo, A. Z.

title: PRISM-1 Lunar Vertex: Five Instruments and a Rover
abstract: The Lunar Vertex PRISM investigation is speeding rapidly toward its Reiner Gamma target site and investigating the mysteries of lunar swirls, magnetic anomalies, and plasma interactions.
author: Blewett, D. T.; Halekas, J.; Ho, G. C.; Greenhagen, B. T.; Anderson, B. J.; Vines, S. K.; Waller, C. D.; Jahn, J. -M.; Kollmann, P.; Denevi, B. W.; Meyer, H. M.; Klima, R. L.; Regoli, L.; Cahill, J. T. S.; Hood, L. L.; Tikoo, S.; Zou, X. -D.; Wieczorek, M.; Lemelin, M.; Fatemi, S.; Cloutis, E. A.; Cox, A. L.; Cooper, S. A.; Ames, W. F.

title: The Lunar Vertex Vector Magnetometers: Status and Efforts in Anticipation of Arrival at Reiner Gamma
abstract: We present an overview of the Lunar Vertex magnetometers, including current status, performance, modeling efforts in anticipation of mission operations, and potential multi-mission observation opportunities.
author: Vines, S. K.; Waller, C. D.; Anderson, B. J.; Fatemi, S.; Blewett, D. T.; Halekas, J.; Ho, G. C.

title: Python Software Package to Distinguish Lunar Impacts from Shallow Moonquakes
abstract: The seismic signal of impacts and shallow moonquakes are visually similar. We develop a semi-automated method to distinguish the signal of shallow moonquakes from impacts. This code will aid in the robust analysis of future lunar seismic signals.
author: Turner, A. R.; Trugman, D. T.; Gulick, S. P. S.

title: An Ultra-Compact Imaging Spectrometer for the Lunar Surface: UCIS-Moon
abstract: We have built an ultra-compact imaging spectrometer (UCIS-Moon) under DALI. UCIS-Moon will achieve spatial resolutions of mm to m from a lunar lander, rover, or deployed as an instrument by astronauts and covers 600-3600nm at 10 nm sampling.
author: Fraeman, A. A.; Bender, H. A.; McKinley, I. M.; Gibson, M. S.; Smith, C. D.; Green, R. O.; Eastwood, M. L.; Sarture, C. M.; Thompson, D. R.; Vinckier, Q.; Mouroulis, P.; Ehlmann, B. L.; Blaney, D. L.

title: A Regolith Thermal Model of the Mare Crisium Landing Site for the Upcoming CLPS Mission
abstract: In preparation for the heat flow measurement planned on the upcoming CLPS mission, a thermal model of the regolith of the landing site has been built to estimate the range and the depth of penetration of the insolation-induced thermal fluctuation.
author: Nagihara, S.

title: Lunar Periscope: A Probe for Exploring Regolith and Ice By Subsurface Classification Of Organics, Pahs, and Elements
abstract: The lunar Probe for Exploring Regolith and Ice by Subsurface Classification of Organics, PAHs, and Elements (PERISCOPE) addresses challenges of characterizing polar volatile deposits by enabling in-situ surface and subsurface fluorescence measurements.
author: Gillis-Davis, J. J.; Sobron, P.; Yanchilina, A.; Vidwans, A.; Jolliff, B. L.; Byrne, P. K.; Ogliore, R. C.

title: A Framing Multispectral Imager for Lunar Applications: Mahina Color Camera
abstract: MahinaCam is a COTS-based snapshot multispectral imager. It provides a combination of reconnaissance imaging and spectral parameter (FeO, TiO2, and OMAT) mapping, ideal for a lunar lander, rover, or sampling context camera. Funded by DALI.
author: Blewett, D. T.; Denevi, B. W.; Meyer, H. M.; Hibbitts, C. A.; Ikpe, S.; Maas, B. J.; London, S. M.

title: Vulcano Summer School Research and Studies for Lunar Exploration
abstract: This abstract discusses the research and studies that the Vulcano Summer School 2023 has performed for Lunar application.
author: Osoianu, D.; Foing, B.; Molony, S.; Swida, O. B.; Ronca, G.; Jusner, S. F.; Gruber, N.

title: POSSUMD: Portable Optical State-of-the-Art Spectrometer for Understanding and Mitigating Dust
abstract: The Portable Optical State-of-the-Art Spectrometer for Understanding and Mitigating Dust acquires data essential to solving dust mobilization and mitigation challenges (e.g., size distribution, concentration, trajectory, sedimentation rate).
author: Vidwans, A.; Gillis-Davis, J. J.

title: Aluminum-Ammonia Screen Wick Heat Pipes for Lunar Surface Missions
abstract: Advanced Cooling Technologies is developing aluminum-ammonia heat pipes with screen wicks for operation on the lunar surface. The screen wick allows the heat pipe to operate against gravity and enables passive thermal management on complex terrain.
author: Diebold, J.; Van Velson, N.; Schulze, D. P.; Tarau, C.; Anderson, B.

title: Latitude Dependence of Hydrogen Concentration in the Lunar Surface Measured by LRO/LEND and Test by Endurance Rover
abstract: Endurance can test widespread hydration quantified by LEND measurements and its meridional variation through significant changes within the region of the Endurance traverse, enabling Endurance to calibrate the abundance at all latitudes.
author: Livengood, T. A.; Boynton, W. V.; Chin, G.; Harshmann, K. P.; Litvak, M. L.; McClanahan, T. P.; Mitrofanov, I. G.; Sanin, A. B.; Starr, R. D.; Su, J. J.

title: Magnetic Gradiometry and Ongoing Modeling Efforts for the Lunar Vertex Mission
abstract: The Lunar Vertex mission will utilize a novel form of magnetic gradiometry to characterize magnetic sources during landing and surface operations. This work details the instrument development, mathematical motivation, and algorithm implementation.
author: Waller, C. D.; Vines, S. K.; Anderson, B. J.; Blewett, D. T.; Halekas, J.

title: Light Scattering Grid for Realistically-Shaped Lunar Dust Grains: A Resource for Surface and Orbital Investigations
abstract: A precomputed grid of light scattering properties for realistically-shaped grains which is a more accurate representation of lunar dust than the Mie models commonly employed. The grid spans UV to near-IR wavelengths with a wide range of grain sizes.
author: Lolachi, R.; Glenar, D. A.; Stubbs, T. J.

title: Demonstration of Thermal Management System of Lunar Ice Miners System Components
abstract: This presentation discusses the status of advanced thermal management technologies being developed by ACT for lunar ice mining. More particularly, the emphasis of this talk is on characterizing ice extraction with the thermal corer.
author: Hota, S. K.; Lee, K. L.; Truong, Q.; Zacny, K.

title: Submillimeter Solar Observation Lunar Volatiles Experiment (SSOLVE), a Spectrometer to Measure Water Vapor in the Lunar Exosphere
abstract: SSOLVE is a spectrometer to measure water vapor above the lunar surface with sensitivity to surface-boundary exosphere and the ability to distinguish indigenous vapor from local contamination.
author: Livengood, T. A.; Anderson, C. M.; Bulcha, B. T.; Chin, G.; Ehsan, N.; Hewagama, T.; Racette, P. E.

title: CAMELS: Capacitance and Magnetism Exploration of Lunar Swirls
abstract: The CAMELS mission will study a prominent lunar swirl, Reiner Gamma, using LunaSATs equipped with magnetometers and capacitive sensors to enhance knowledge of its magnetic field and regolith chemistry.
author: Abramson, A.; Andres, H.; Pestone, A.

title: Cellular Array Gas Phase Scintillation Neutron Spectrometer and Synthetic Aperture Neutron Image Formation
abstract: The low-power, low-voltage cellular array neutron spectrometer offers capabilities for unfolding energy spectra with self-calibration by boron-11 cells. Its synthetic aperture imaging feature provides valuable insights for lunar exploration.
author: Su, J. J.; Shahi, C. B.; Clark, C. W.; Coplan, M. A.; Lutz, L.; Putnam, L.; Livengood, T. A.; McClanahan, T. P.

title: S.P. Hopper: In-Situ Exploration of the Shackleton de Gerlache Ridge
abstract: A deployable robotic hopper enables exploration of challenging terrains: permanently shadowed regions, rough or blocky targets, pits, and steep slopes. The μNova hopper, developed by Intuitive Machines, was designed for these exploration challenges.
author: Martin, T. D.; Atwell, M. J.; Bussey, D. B. J.; Estes, N. M.; Grott, M.; Hamm, M.; Knollenberg, J.; Pacher, T.; Robinson, M. S.; Speyerer, E. J.; Wagner, R. V.

title: Modelling the Sources of Lunar Mare Basalts Mapped by Chandrayaan-2
abstract: This summarises our efforts in modelling the sources of lunar mare basalts. Results of the model are compared with elemental abundances from CLASS over the mare data from Chandrayaan-2.
author: Thakur, H.; Pillai, N. S.; Narendranath, S.; Chakrabarti, R.

title: New Insights on Lunar Mare Basalts from the Elemental Abundance Estimates by CLASS on Chandrayaan-2
abstract: Abundances of Mg, Al, Si and Fe are modeled from CLASS X-ray fluorescence measurements to understand the compositional variability of lunar mare. Heterogeneity and thermal evolution of the sources are revealed by the trends in Mg number with age.
author: Pillai, N. S.; Narendranath, S.

title: Student research in the cultivation of lettuce and chamomile in a hydroponic system and research of the benefit of the chamomile on the health through an analog mission.
abstract: The abstract presents my research on the development of two species of lettuce and one species of chamomile grown in a hydroponic system. The system has been implemented in the Self Deployable Habitat for Extreme Environment (SHEE).
author: Wurtz Pra, S.

title: Shedding Light on the Darkness: Diversity of Permanently Shadowed Regions at the Lunar Poles
abstract: Permanently shadowed regions (PSRs) vary in their morphology and placement within craters, which can give insight to their accumulation and mechanical properties. From these, we created a simple classification at the north and south lunar poles.
author: Ahrens, C. J.; Fastook, J.; Petro, N. E.

title: SESAR-LITE: Probing the Lunar Subsurface with P-band Radar
abstract: We are developing SESAR-LITE, a compact P-band (70 cm wavelength) polarimetric synthetic aperture radar designed to address Artemis science objectives and lunar Strategic Knowledge Gaps.
author: Carter, L. M.; Rincon, R. F.; Baker, D. M. H.; Shoemaker, E. S.

title: Reflectance Spectroscopy of Lunar-Like Samples during Vulcano 2023 Field Summer School
abstract: During the 2023 Vulcano summer school spectral measurements were performed in the field in preparation of integrating a spectrometer onto a mobile robot for an analog mission.
author: Jusner, S. F.; Gruber, N.; Ronca, G.; Osoianu, D.; Molony, S.; Swida, O. B.; Foing, B.; Unnithan, V.

title: Water Outside the Shadows: Evidence for Hydrotectonics at Northern Lunar Latitudes?
