abstract: A survey of northern lunar latitudes for potential landing sites reveals apparently recent surface deformations on the floor of Philolaus crater. Could these be driven by the subsurface motions of water?
author: Eubanks, T. M.; Blase, W. P.; Gerhardt, R. A.; Lingam, M.; King, S. D.

title: The Lunar Ground Segment: Lunar Geodesy with LLR and VLBI Beacons
abstract: Here, we describe how the dynamical monitoring of the Moon can be improved through the establishment of collocated LLR retroreflectors and VLBI radio beacons at a geodetic fiducial point on Malapert Mountain near the lunar South Pole.
author: Blase, W. P.; Eubanks, T. M.; Bills, B.; Petrov, L.; Viswanathan, V.; King, S.

title: Prospecting for Water at High Lunar Latitudes
abstract: Neutron scatterometry data indicate that at high latitudes water is probably present outside of PSR. Here, we describe how water may be sequestered in cold ground at latitudes above ∼80◦.
author: Eubanks, T. M.; Blase, W. P.; Gerhardt, R. A.; Lingam, M.

title: Geometallurgical Studies of the Moon
abstract: In this article, geometallurgical studies of the moon are reviewed and summarized in terms of the current status and future perspectives, including some requests on the lunar exploration and map update.
author: Otsuki, A. O.

title: Development of a Thermal Control Valve for Passive Flow Control of a Loop Heat Pipe
abstract: A thermal control valve has been developed and tested, demonstrating flow control about a user-specified system as part of a passive thermal management system.
author: Ellis, M. C.; Nicolaescu, I. V.; Demydovych, M. V.

title: Two-Phase Thermal Switch for Lunar Night Survival
abstract: A two-phase thermal switch is developed for thermal management of future lunar landers and rovers that can be utilized to enable lunar night survival. Theoretical and experimental work has been performed, including a design for a small lunar rover.
author: Van Velson, N.; Kumar, R.; Diebold, J.; Tarau, C.; Anderson, W. G.

title: Towards a Better Understanding of Lunar Exosphere Through the Detection of Water Form
abstract: This study focuses on different forms of water on the surface. We propose that data from Lunar Trailblazer will contribute to a better understanding of the various forms of water, thereby enhancing our comprehension of the lunar exosphere.
author: Huang, Z.; Nomura, K.; Nakano, A.; Morrissey, L. S.; Wang, J.

title: "GlobeTrotter Lunar" All-Terrain Hopper: Digital Animations of Surface and Subsurface Extreme Terrain Access
abstract: "GlobeTrotter Lunar" is a mobile instrument package that hops across the lunar surface, allowing access to extreme terrain, including pits and caves. We present digital animations to illustrate this innovative payload concept.
author: Chhibber, A.; Lee, P.; Riedel, J. E.

title: Identifying High Priority Lunar Landing Sites: An Aristarchus Perspective
abstract: Here we present the value of Mini-RF radar data to lunar exploration. Using the Aristarchus Region as an example, we outline how radar data can be applied alongside other datasets to prioritize landing site sections and design mission traverses.
author: Morgan, G. A.; Patterson, G. W.; Stickle, A. M.

title: JETT5 Geologic Mapping in Support of Simulated Artemis Surface Operations: Process and Preliminary Products
abstract: The Joint Extravehicular Activities and Human Surface Mobility Test Team 5 (JETT5) is preparing for a fall field-based Artemis 3 simulation by producing 1:5,000-scale geologic maps for two sites with Actions taken in response to JETT3 Recommendations.
author: Huff, A. E.; Garry, W. B.; Hurtado, J. M.; Miller, M. J.; Skinner, J. A.; Weitz, C. M.; Edgar, L. A.; Young, K. E.

title: Optimizing Sampling Decision for Lunar Missions Using Machine Learning Techniques on Geochemical Data
abstract: We identify methods for efficiently classifying lunar rocks based on their geochemistry, enabling timely decision-making regarding the inclusion of a diverse range of rocks during sample return missions.
author: Shubham, S.; Arevalo, R.; Cohen, B. A.

title: Moon Rover Thermal and Power Analysis for Night and PSR Survival
abstract: Ron Creel is an Apollo program veteran who supported those missions with thermal models of the Lunar Roving Vehicles. Today, Ron continues his interest in thermal survival power for Artemis rovers in lunar nights and PSRs at the Moon's South Pole.
author: Creel, R. A.

title: A New View of the Lunar South Pole from the Lunar Orbiter Laser Altimeter
abstract: We utilize LOLA topographic roughness based on improved south polar altimetry to examine the broader geologic context of the Artemis III candidate regions.
author: Barker, M. K.; Mazarico, E.; Neumann, G. A.; Smith, D. E.; Zuber, M. T.; Head, J. W.

title: The Lunar Vertex Camera Array
abstract: The Lunar Vertex Camera Array will provide 360° imaging of the Reiner Gamma landing site as part of the PRISM 2 instrument suite.
author: Denevi, B. W.; Meyer, H. M.; Pasqualino, G.; Ames, W. F.; Cooper, S. A.; Dupont, A. R.; Geidel, K.; Mastandrea, J. P.; McCord, K.; Ocasio Milanes, A. V.; Morgan, F.; Taylor, H. W.; Tinsman, C. L.; Blewett, D. T.

title: Identifying Potentially Survivable Niches and Areas of High Biological Interest on the Lunar South Pole
abstract: We find that the Lunar South Pole is likely to possess survivable niches for certain microorganisms. We describe our methodology in determining where such locations may be and discuss potential ramifications for exploration.
author: Saxena, P.; Graham, H. V.; Bertone, S.; Regberg, A.; Curran, N. M.; Pugel, D. B.; Needham, A.; Petro, N. E.

title: Sustaining Lunar Exploration through Worldwide Public Support
abstract: Why continued public buy-in and funding remain crucial to sustaining the new worldwide impetus for exploring our Moon to reap its immense science and technology benefits, especially now when commercial partnerships are put on critical paths.
author: Mehta, J. M.

title: TRIDENT Drill for VIPER and PRIME1 Missions to the Moon: 2023 Update
abstract: TRIDENT drill is scheduled to fly on PRIME-1 and VIPER missions in 2023 and 204, respectively. In addition to providing subsurface samples to instruments, it can also capture geotechnical data.
author: Zacny, K.; Chu, P.; Vendiola, V.; Creekmore, P.; Ng, P.; Goldman, S.; Seto, E.; Bywaters, K.; Bailey, E.; Zheng, R.; King, I.; Rashedi, A.; Chow, P.; Huddleston, R.; Paulsen, G.; Wang, A.; Wilson, J.; Xu, H.; Indyk, S.; Quinn, J.; Eichenbaum, A.; J., Captain; Kleinhenz, J.; Rezich, E.; Colaprete, T.; Lim, D.; Mirmalek, Z.; Lees, D.; Elphic, R.; Ennico Smith, K.

title: Sustainable Power as an Enabling Resource for Lunar Science
abstract: Lockheed Martin is developing a sustainable power architecture for the Lunar poles supporting both robotic and human science. The architecture is built on modular voltage conversion, smart power controllers, and an automated fault management system.
author: Williams, H. J.; Sampson, M. C.

title: Primary Radiation Dose Around the Artemis III Candidate Landing Sites
abstract: The level of radiation exposure at a given location on the Moon is dependent on the amount incident above the local horizon. Here we consider the radiation exposure around the South Pole including the 13 candidate Artemis III landing sites.
author: Phipps, P. H.; Stubbs, T. J.; Looper, M. D.; Spence, H. E.; Townsend, L. W.

title: Mini-RF S-Band Radar Characterization of a Tycho Ray over the Lunar South Pole
abstract: Radar reveals truth. / Hidden secrets of the Moon. / Tycho's ray shines bright!
author: Rivera-Valentín, E. G.; Fassett, C. I.; Denevi, B. W.; Neish, C. D.; Stickle, A. M.; Meyer, H. M.; Patterson, G. W.; Morgan, G. A.

title: Experimental Results of Sublimation Loss from Open-Gap Lunar Water Extraction
abstract: This research examines the feasibility of extracting water from icy regolith with an open-gap system: how much of the ice in an ice-regolith mixture can be captured by a system that leaves narrow gaps between heated regolith simulant and a cryotrap?
author: Krause, T. S.; Thomas, F.; Gertsch, L.

title: Relative Gravimetry in the Lunar Highlands Would Resolve Ambiguity in GRAIL Data
abstract: Ground-based gravity measurements in the lunar highlands (including the South Pole) could plausibly distinguish between various cratering paradigms.
author: James, P. B.; Broad, K.

title: The Value of Geologic Mapping for a Sustained Presence on the Moon and Beyond
abstract: We summarize efforts that can be employed to ensure geologic maps are available at the right time, at the right scale, and with the right content to support short- and long-term exploration of the lunar surface and beyond.
author: Skinner, J. A.; Luna, J. W.; Thomson, B. J.

title: Lunar Vulkan Imaging and Spectroscopy Explorer (Lunar-VISE)
abstract: Lunar-VISE will land on the Gruithuisen Gamma dome and use its combined lander and rover payload to determine the composition and physical properties of the rocks and regolith comprising the domes, placing critical constraints on their formation mechanism.
author: Donaldson Hanna, K.; Benavente, J.; Bennett, K.; Denevi, B.; Dove, A.; Hagerty, J.; Hardgrove, C.; Hayne, P.; LaMee, A.; Landis, M.; Osterman, D.; Prettyman, T.; Shirley, K.; Siegler, M.; Sunshine, J.; Williams, J. -P.; Valencia, S.

title: Detection of Evolved Granitic Lunar Volcanism at Compton-Belkovich
abstract: Here we report a novel microwave-wavelength measurement of an anomalously hot region on the Moon that indicates the presence of a ~50 km diameter subsurface, granitic body beneath the farside, thorium-rich feature known as Compton-Belkovich.
author: Siegler, M.; Feng, J.; Lehman-Franco, K.; Andrews-Hanna, J.; Economos, R.; St. Clair, M.; Million, C.; Head, J.; Glotch, T.; White, M.

title: Rover Testing for Lunar Landing Sites and Terrains: Exploring Lunar Analogues on Vulcano Island
abstract: This abstract talks about the importance of authentic analogue terrain for rover field testing.
author: Molony, S. M.; Dominguez, R. D.; Fox, L. F.; Stark, T. S.; Willenbrock, P. W.; Felmet, A. F.; Planitzer, T. P.; Stapperfend, S. S.; Foing, B. F.

title: Artemis Program: An Open Gate to Private-Public Partnerships to Develop a Lunar-Based Economy
abstract: This paper investigates the Artemis program as an opportunity to strengthen private-public partnerships to foster Moon exploration through the Commercial Lunar Payloads Services (CLPS) and the subsequent economic and scientific opportunities.
author: Duboille, C.; Foing, B.

title: Preparing Artemis Base Camp: Highlights From Ilewg, LUNEX Euromoonmars, IMA International MoonBase Alliance, and EuroSpaceHub Academy
abstract: Activities and results preparing for exploration and Artemis Base Camp, from 2009 with ILEWG/LUNEX EuroMoonMars program in Data Analysis, Instrumentation, Field Work, and Astronautics, now upscaled with International MoonBase Alliance IMA, and EuroSpaceHub.
author: Foing, B. H.; Ilewg Cospar; Lunex Team; Euromoonmars Team; Ima International Moonbase Alliance; Eurospacehub Academy; Sri Space Renaissance International

title: Human Factor in an Analog Lunar Habitat: EuroSpaceHub and EMMPOL18 2023 Campaigns and Lessons for Artemis Base Camp
abstract: EMMPOL18 is a one-week isolation mission taking place in Poland which serve as training program for analog astronaut, it allows to conduct experience inside the habitat that can be re-create in a moon-base environment.
author: Vandycke, R.; Neuman, T.; Sekara, S.; Shinde, D. K.; Foing, B.

title: Toward an Array-Based Passive Seismic Experiment at the Lunar South Pole for Water Ice Prospecting and Geotechnical Characterization of the Regolith
abstract: We show progress toward our goal of conducting an array-based passive seismic imaging experiment near the lunar south pole to illuminate water ice deposits and determine the geotechnical properties of the regolith for critical infrastructure planning.
author: Olivier, G.; O'Neill, C.; Aubert, J.; Pearson, M.

title: On the Governance of Early Lunar Operations: Solving "The Dust Problem"
abstract: This paper correlates how the physics of lunar dust adhesion provides the basis for dust mitigation per surface repulsion (passive strategy of surface etching) or dust migration (active strategy of electrodynamics dust shielding). EVAs vs. robotics.
author: Freeman, R. H.

title: Shape-from-Shading Topography: Applications to Upcoming Human and Robotic Exploration of the Moon
abstract: We outline a processing pipeline for generating meter-scale topography products that would be broadly applicable to landing site selection and mission planning for upcoming human and robotic exploration of the lunar south polar region and beyond.
author: Boatwright, B. D.; Head, J. W.

title: NASA STMD LSII/LSIC ISRU Focus Group Update and Path Forward
abstract: An update and future plans for the Lunar Surface Innovation Consortium's (LSIC) ISRU Focus Group, aimed at advancing technologies for the collection, processing, storing, and use of material on the lunar surface.
author: Berdis, J. R.; Hibbitts, C. A.; Nord, M.; Miller, R.; Burke, P.; Smith, D.; John, J.

title: Exploration of the Moon at the Microscale Using the Advanced Multispectral Infrared Microimager (AMIM)
abstract: AMIM is a compact instrument for future robotic and human missions that provide spatially‑correlated mineralogy and microtexture of rocks, soils, and ices in situ at the microscale for characterizing planetary surfaces and prospecting for resources.
author: Núñez, J. I.; Klima, R. L.; Murchie, S. L.; Lees, J.; Lehtonen, S. J.; Maas, B. J.; Goldberg, A. C.; Bekker, D. L.; Rorschach, K. L.; Seelos, F. P.; Wylie, B. M.; Greenhagen, B. T.

title: Updates on Mini-RF Operations, Data, and Applicability to Artemis Landing Zone Characterization
abstract: We will provide updates on current Mini-RF operations, newly re-processed data products, and newly collected data that can be used for Artemis zone and landing site characterization, with examples from current products over Artemis zones.
author: Stickle, A. M.; Patterson, G. W.; Morgan, G. A.; The Mini-RF Team

title: Permanently Shadowed Regions Have Light, but How Much? A Case Study at the Artemis Candidate Landing Regions
abstract: All PSRs, even the darkest, coldest ones are not completely dark and have light from indirect illumination. ShadowCam images enable comparison of the available illumination to human work conditions.
author: Mahanti, P.; Wagner, R. V.; Robinson, M. S.

title: Geologically Recent Regolith Drainage into Subsurface Voids: Implications for Lunar Exploration
abstract: Lunar "spiders" a rare new type of small young features, are formed by regolith drainage into shallow subsurface voids after geologically recent partial collapse of the voids' roofs. Unstable void roofs can pose a hazard for surface operations.
author: Kreslavsky, M. A.; Head, J. W.

title: Near-Infrared Photometry of Future Landing Sites from the Lunar Orbiter Laser Altimeter (LOLA)
abstract: Near-IR photometry from LOLA is available at low- to mid-latitude CLPS landing sites and can be used to infer surface properties of the regions of interest and place the results in the global geological context.
author: Walker, R. T.; Barker, M. K.; Mazarico, E.; Sun, X.; Neumann, G. A.; Smith, D. E.; Zuber, M. T.; Head, J. W.

title: Lunar Trailblazer: A Pioneering Smallsat for Lunar Water, Lunar Geology, and Landing Site Reconnaissance
abstract: NASA's smallsat mission for understanding the Moon's water and water cycle is in the final stages of assembly and testing, and as-built characteristics of the delivered flight system will be described.
author: Ehlmann, B. L.; Klima, R. L.; Blaney, D.; Bowles, N.; Dickson, J.; Donaldson Hanna, K.; Edwards, C. S.; Green, R.; House, M. A.; Miura, J.; Pieters, C.; Thompson, D. R.; Lunar Trailblazer Team

title: Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS): Contracted Deliveries of NASA Payloads to the Moon
abstract: Through the NASA CLPS initiative, NASA has selected 11 primary task order (TO) payload manifests for delivery by commercial lander vendors to the Moon. Here, we overview the science and tech demo payloads manifested on each TO.
author: Lederer, S. M.; Commercial Lunar Payload Services; Exploration Science Strategy; Integra

title: Field Campaign to Test a Nano-Rover in a Moon-Analog Environment and 3D Mapping Using LiDAR and Stereoscopic Camera
abstract: The campaign to test the planetary rover platform HiveR from NEUROSPACE was conducted on Vulcano Island, Italy. Vulcano features Moon and Mars Analogs. Tests included maneuverability and optical localization with stereo and LiDAR cameras.
author: Planitzer, T.; Stapperfend, S.; Fox, L.; Foing, B.; Unnithan, V.

title: Supporting A New Lunar Geologic Mapping Campaign
abstract: Systematic geologic mapping campaigns were conducted in the Apollo era to support landed missions. We are overdue for a renewal of a funded, systematic lunar mapping campaign to enable future mission support, site selection, and characterization.
author: Thomson, B. J.; Williams, D. A.; Luna, J. W.

title: Candidate Lunar Traverse Gravimetry Investigations Enabled by the VEGA Gravimeter
abstract: The VEGA space gravimeter (TRL 5/6) enables several science studies to constrain sub-surface density distribution of lunar geological features. We show through survey design and modelling how surface gravimetry addresses specific science questions.
author: Braun, A.; Carroll, K. A.; Ermakov, A.

title: Canadian Lunar Surface Exploration Initiatives
abstract: In 2019, the Canadian Prime Minister announced that "Canada is reaching for the Moon." Two surface missions have been planned: the Lunar Rover Mission and the Lunar Science Instrument. The next one is to develop a Lunar Utility Vehicle for Artemis.
author: Morisset, C. -E.; Picard, M.; Hill, P.; Haltigin, T.; Bergeron, M.; Saint-Jacques, D.; Lange, C.

title: Lunar Far Side Volcanism: More than Just Mantle Overturn
abstract: We discuss a number of unique far side volcanic targets of opportunity that could be explored by the Endurance mission.
author: Jozwiak, L. M.; Meyer, H. M.

title: Visualizing Lunar Vertex Image Data with the Small Body Mapping Tool
abstract: The Small Body Mapping Tool will be updated for Lunar Vertex in the following areas: distortion models, landed visualizations, and preparing the SBMT for Lunar Vertex. This presentation will discuss improvements in each of the areas.
author: Steele, R. J.; Cheung, E. S.; Doku, I. Y.; Johnson, A. R.

title: Coordinating Laboratory Analyses on Small Lunar Samples: Advantages, Challenges, and Lessons Learned
abstract: We present an overview of three investigations of Endurance A-sized samples. Their small masses can pose many logistical and scientific challenges. We will discuss the advantages, challenges, and lessons learned from working with small lunar samples.
author: Crow, C. A.; Barnes, J. J.; Brounce, M.; Borg, L. E.; Boyce, J.; Davis, J.; Diaz, C.; Economos, R.; Erickson, T.; Flowers, R. M.; Jolliff, B.; Lehman-Franco, K.; Shearer, C.; Wilbur, Z. E.

title: Lunar Intermediate Infrared Imaging Spectrometer (LIIRIS) for Mafic Mineral Composition and Direct H2O Detection
abstract: We describe the design of the Lunar Intermediate Infrared Imaging Spectrometer (LIIRIS), which will measure emitted thermal radiation from the surface of the Moon to determine mineral composition and detect H2O.
author: Kremer, C. H.; Bender, H. A.; Mustard, J. F.; Pieters, C. M.; Green, R. O.; Vinckier, Q.; Gunapala, S. D.; Bramble, M. S.; Parman, S. W.

title: The Endurance Lunar Rover Mission Study Status
abstract: The Endurance lunar sample return mission was recommended in 2022 by the National Academy's Planetary Science and Astrobiology Decadal Survey as a high-priority strategic medium-class mission to the NASA Lunar Development and Exploration Program.
author: Baker, J. D.; Keane, J. T.

title: Mare Mesas in Mare Fecunditatis: Characteristics of a Newly Documented Class of Mare Volcanic Features
abstract: We document "Mare Mesas," an unusual class of mare volcanic features in Mare Fecunditatis, steep-sloped, flat-topped hills less than a few kilometers across and tens of meters high, and encourage the search for more examples.
author: Head, J. W.; Ivanov, M. A.

title: Investigating Lunar Polar Thermal Environments In Situ with the LAFORGE Instrument Aboard the CSA Lunar Rover Mission
abstract: LAFORGE is a multispectral thermal infrared (TIR) imaging radiometer designed to maximize temperature accuracy, especially at very low temperatures. It will fly on the CSA Lunar Rover Mission as early as 2026.
author: Greenhagen, B. T.; Cahill, J. T. S.; Elder, C. M.; Siegler, M. A.; Warren, T.; Ryan, K.; Clyde, B.

title: Lunar Magnetism Studies Facilitated by the Endurance Mission Concept
abstract: We describe how new samples and measurements facilitated by Endurance could transform our understanding of lunar magnetism.
author: Tikoo, S. M.

title: Artemis Zone Landing Sites, Science, and Suitability for a Base Camp
abstract: We identified multiple sites of special scientific interest near potential landing sites. Several are compelling targets of extended investigations that could be serviced from a base camp.
author: Stopar, J. D.; Syposs, J. T.

title: Sustained Low Altitude Lunar Orbit Mission to Map Resource (SLALOM MapR)
abstract: The Sustained Low Altitude Lunar Orbit Mission to Map Resource (SLALOM MapR) brings sensors closer to the lunar surface, enhancing the potential for resource prospecting and scientific monitoring of the lunar environment.
author: Chikine, S. C.; Johnson, T. J.; Parker, J. P.; Gardner, T. G.; Imler, P. I.

title: Lunar Water Ice, O2, and Metals Derived from the Lunar Regolith: Some Thoughts on the Linkage Between Science Measurements and ISRU Needs
abstract: Science measurements of the lunar surface including composition (elemental and mineralogy), morphology, and stratigraphy, would provide valuable, even essential, information for the implementation of ISRU systems for water, O2, and metal extraction.
author: Hibbitts, C. A.; Nord, M.; Berdis, J.; Miller, R.

title: The Lunar Exploration and Science Orbiter (LExSO): Preparing for a Post-LRO Luna-Verse
abstract: LRO, a most remarkable asset, may not last forever. Here we report on work to develop a mission concept for a robust post-LRO mission called LExSO, a mission responsive to the recent LEAG CLOC-SAT report.
author: Petro, N. E.

title: Mochii'L Spectroscopic Electron Microscope: A Remote-Controlled Lunar Surface Geochemical Analyzer
abstract: Mochii L is a mobile mini spectroscopic scanning electron microscope for the lunar surface, providing insights into the formation and evolution of the Lunar surface, aiding EVA sample selection, and helping define future ISM/ISRU workflows.
author: Own, C. S.; Thomas-Keprta, K. T.; Clemett, S.; Rahman, Z.; Martinez, J.; Abel, P.; Dunand, D. C.; Pettit, D. R.

title: Expanding Access and Usability of Spacecraft Data: The Mars Exploration Rovers Portal to Observations, Resources, and Tools to Advance Legacy Science (MER PORTAL)
abstract: Through the MER PORTAL / People will learn how to find / and use MER data.
author: Cole, S. B.; Aubele, J. C.; Farrand, W. H.; Lu, S.; Lynch, K. L.; Mer Portal Team

title: Updates from Planetary Science Division's Here to Observe (H2O) Program
abstract: We will present updates and preliminary outcomes from PSD's H2O Program, summarize opportunities for participation, and address questions about the proposal submission process or status of participating PSD missions.
author: Smith, D. J.; Lang, N. P.; Moore, L.; Niebur, C.; Rinehart, S.; Santiago-Materese, D.; Thompson, M.; Throop, H.; Vander Kaaden, K. E.

title: Inclusion Plans in NASA's Science Mission Directorate for ROSES-2024
abstract: All people deserve / To feel included, with help / From Inclusion Plans.
author: Nahm, A. L.; Watkins, R. N.

title: Europa Clipper: Seven Months to Launch!
abstract: Just seven months hence / Europa Clipper begins / Its wonderful trek.
author: Pappalardo, R. T.; Buratti, B.; Korth, H.; Blaney, D.; Blankenship, D. D.; Burch, J.; Christensen, P.; Kempf, S.; Kivelson, M.; Luspay-Kuti, A.; Mazarico, E.; Retherford, K.; Turtle, E.; Craft, K.; Glein, C.; McKinnon, W.; Moore, J. M.; Patterson, G. W.; Raymond, C.; Soderlund, K.; Trumbo, S.; Daubar, I.; Howell, S.; Klima, R.; Leondar, E.; Matiella Novak, A.; Phillips, C.; Paczkowski, B.; Ray, T.; Europa Clipper Science Team

title: Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility Initiatives on the Mars 2020 Science Team and Implications for NASA Planetary Science Missions
abstract: We describe the initiatives facilitated by the DEIA working group for the Mars 2020 Science Team and barriers faced in their implementation; these include team guidelines, discussions, training, mentoring, and a survey.
author: Vaughan, A.; Ravanis, E.; Newman, C.; Jensen, E.; Patel, P.; Herweigh, C.; Stack, K. M.; Simon, J. I.; Herd, C. D. K.; Connell, S. A.; Bell, J.; Cloutis, E. A.

title: Workforce Development, Diversity, Inclusion, Innovation and Entrepreneurship from LUNEX EuroMoonMars and EuroSpaceHub Academy
abstract: Activities from ILEWG LUNEX Euro-MoonMars, EuroSpaceHub Academy, SRI and partners for WorkForce Development in Space and Planetary Research, Innovation, Interdisciplinarity, Diversity, Inclusion, Accessibility , Astronautics and Entrepreneurship.
author: Foing, B.; Rogers, H.; Pascual, J.; Puriené, V.; Fazel, F.; Ropero, A.; Claeys, K.; Ducai, T.; Crotti, S.; Tagne, D.; Vleugels, S.; Swida, O.; Hoogenboom, R.; Abbink, D.; Kolodziejczyk, A.; Perrier, I. R.; Baatout, S.; Pavanello, S.; Stoker, C.; Ehrenfreund, P.; Lee, T.; Musilova, M.; Heemskerk, M.; Pouwels, C.; Tavernier, A.; McGrath, K.; Robertson, C.; Horvatt, I.; Balfe, M.; Laffey, J.; Tyndall, C.; Harvey, M.; Ehreiser, A.; Schlarmann, L.; Reymens, B.; Sol, P.; Gautam, K.; Wedler, A.; Autino, A.; Heinz, S.; Pelton, J.; Crisafulli, J.; Beldavs, V.; Tacchini, D.; Hutchinson, A.; Duboille, C.; Gil Navidad, M.; Foing, V.; Demir, B.; Reibaldi, G.; Mankins, J.; Molony, S.; Osoianu, D.; Ip-Jewell, S.

title: African Initiative for Planetary and Space Sciences
abstract: The African Initiative for Planetary and Space Science is a research network of scientists and science communicators. This presentation will briefly review the history and past achievements of the network and will present the roadmap of the next four years.
author: Baratoux, D. B.; Belhaï, D.; Chabou, C.; Chennaoui-Aoudjehane, H.; Douté, D.; Ezzine, I.; Korsaga, M.; Pitout, F.; Quesnel, Y.; Quitte, G.; Rajaonarivelo, A.; Sapah, M. S.; Wieczorek, M.

title: The NASA Facility for Astromaterials Research at the Johnson Space Center — A National Laboratory for Planetary Research
abstract: The NFAR at NASA Johnson Space Center is open to external users for planetary research and exploration. The facilities encompass a large number of analytical, experimental, and mission analog laboratories for planetary science.
author: Simon, J. I.; Berger, E. L.; Keller, L. P.; Prissel, T. C.; Rampe, E.; Righter, K.

title: DEEPS CORES: Bridging the Gaps of Earth and Planetary Science Education in Providence Public School District
abstract: Learn more about "DEEPS CORES," an initiative to introduce Providence, RI high school students to Earth and planetary sciences.
author: Wilk, K. A.; Prilipko Huber, O.; Razionale, D.; Bowers, S.; Shabtian, H.; Kimble, K.; Lo Piccolo, A.; Mason, A.; Krueger, H.; Garelick, S.; Sully, C.

title: Here to Observe: Kingsborough Community College and DragonFly
abstract: Engaging students / At community college / We're here to observe!
author: Jaret, S. J.; Weisberg, M. K.; Park, J.; Pontefract, A.

title: Improving Inclusivity and Accessibility in Planetary Science in Remote Field Courses
abstract: Presentation on accessible and inclusive teachings of planetary and Earth sciences through remote field courses, with the NSF GeoSPACE program as a case study.
author: Meier, M. L.; Thatcher, S.; Piatek, J. L.; Marshall, A.; Arroyo, Y.; Leon, S. C.; Williams, A. J.; Collins, T.; Gallant, E.; Elardo, S.; Williams, D. A.

title: The NASA Planetary Science Summer School: Instructional Principles, Focus on Increasing Inclusivity and Demographic Data
abstract: NASA's early-career mission design Planetary Science Summer School's instructional design principles include authentic learning experiences and design thinking, using DEIA considerations in applications, review and selection, and climate and environment.
author: Lowes, L. L.; Scully, J. E. C.; Keane, J. T.; Hudson, T. L.; Nash, A. E.; Armijo, J.; Rodriguez, B.

title: Results of the 2023 Mental Health Survey of the Planetary Science Community
abstract: Marginalized groups and graduate students continue to experience more severe mental health symptoms than the dominant population and other career stages. Also, we explore potential factors contributing to mental health concerns within the community.
author: Trang, D.; Swafford, C. E. M.; Vance, S. D.; Davidson, J.; Filiberto, J.; Richey, C. R.

title: Investigating the Career Paths of New Frontiers and Discovery Program Proposal PIs
abstract: NASA's must stop relying on past mission experience to organically and passively grow experienced PIs and instead take a more proactive role training scientists to serve as a mission PI.
author: Chu, A.; Niebur, C.

title: Examining Science Productivity of Data Analysis Programs (DAPs) with Comparison to Prime and Extended Missions
abstract: This work completes an analysis of the scientific productivity of the science teams for prime and extended missions as well as the Data Analysis Programs funding non-team members.
author: Shteynberg, E.; Niebur, C.

title: The NASA Science Mission Directorate's ROSES 2021 Research and Analysis Yearbook: An Online Resource for Programmatic and Self-Reported Demographic Data
abstract: The NASA SMD ROSES 2021 Research and Analysis Yearbook is a new, online resource to provide relevant science communities and the public with data about ROSES 2021, including demographic data analyses of proposers and programmatic information.
author: Jensen, H. B.; Pappas, L. L.; Taha, N. A.; New, M. H.

title: A Historically Black College and University (HBCU) Pilot Program to Aid in the Diversification of the Planetary Science Pipeline
abstract: We describe the initiation of a pilot program that introduces HBCUs to the field of planetary science via a collaborative partnership between planetary scientists at NASA Goddard Space Flight Center and the Department of Physics at Howard University.
author: Quick, L. C.; Alfred, M.; Petro, N.; Tucker, O. J.; Ahrens, C.; Domagal-Goldman, S. D.; Wilk, K. A.; Young, A. V.

title: Beyond Permits, Toward Relationships: New NASA Planetary Science Division ROSES Requirements for Ethics in Fieldwork
abstract: NASA's Planetary Science Division has created a revised section of the omnibus solicitation system, ROSES, to ensure the fieldwork it funds reflects emergent ethics, especially where relationship with Indigenous communities is concerned.
author: Scalice, D.; Kirven-Brooks, M.; Gronstal, A.; Martin, M.; Eckman, R.; Santiago-Materese, D.; Thompson, M.; Williams, C.; Wade, J.; Voytek, M.

title: CERES: A Small but Mighty Culturally Inclusive Planetary Science Iterative Engagement Planning Strategy
abstract: CERES (Community, Empathy, Relensify, Engagement, Self-Reflection) is a new iterative engagement planning strategy developed for Planetary ReaCH to give the planetary science community a concrete tool to engage culturally diverse audiences.
author: Rojas, C.; Rubino-Hare, L.; Lynch, K. L.; Rivera-Valentín, E. G.; Shupla, C.; Buxner, S.; Shaner, A.

title: Statistics for IAU-Approved Planetary Nomenclature Help Chart an Effective Strategy for Diversity and Inclusion
abstract: We have used the database of ~16,000 IAU-approved feature names to determine whether IAU nomenclature has become more diverse and inclusive in the last decade. Gender and geographic diversity have both increased during this period.
author: Gaither, T. A.; Black, S. R.; Bogle, S. R.; Skinner, J. A.

title: NASA'S SMD Bridge Program: A Co-Created Program that Funds Faculty and Students at Under-Resourced Emerging Research Institutions
abstract: NASA's SMD Bridge Program was co-created with the science community. It funds meaningful research experiences that partner faculty and students at underresourced emerging research institutions with NASA scientists and engineers.
author: Zellner, N. E. B.; Boyd, P.; Villanueva, S.; Alexander, V.; Scalice, D.; Balachandran, L.; Nuñez, J.; Hart, B.; Gonzales, E.; Ferrell, T.

title: VIRTEX: Scientists Supporting the Next Generation in STEM
abstract: This presentation is a review of the VIRTEX (VIRtual Trips to EXtreme Environments) project, a newly-funded, informal education program that will connect middle school-aged learners with NASA science, careers, and mentors.
author: Beaudoin, G. M.; Shupla, C.

title: Evaluation of the InSightSeers Mission Observers Program
abstract: We provide a quantitative pedagogical evaluation of the InSightSeers mission observers program.
author: Fernando, B.; Newman, C.; Daubar, I. J.; Beghein, C.; Irving, J. C. E.; Johnson, C.; Panning, M. P. P.; Plesa, A. C.; Smrekar, S.; Stanley, S.; Banerdt, W. B.

title: Lessons Learned from the 2023 Joint DPS-EPSC Meeting in San Antonio, Texas, with Applicability to Other Meetings in Areas with Problematic Public Policies
abstract: Inclusive meetings / Have broad considerations / Still seek to improve.
author: Daubar, I. J.; Takir, D.; Roberts, J. H.; Piatek, J.; Berdis, J. R.; Brooks, S. M.; Diniega, S.; Elrod, M. K.; Masiero, J.; Walker, A.; Vance, S. D.

title: Planetary Resources and Content Heroes (ReaCH): Progress on a Model for Culturally Inclusive Public Engagement Workshops
abstract: Planetary ReaCH / Replicable model for / Engagement workshops.
author: Shaner, A. J.; King, J.; Kriescher, D.; Lynch, K. L.; Rivera-Valentín, E. G.; Shebby, S.; Shupla, C.; Planetary ReaCH Team

title: GeoSPACE: Bringing Field Geology and Planetary Geoscience to the Accessibility Challenged
abstract: This presentation describes our GeoSPACE project, a 2-week college course aiming to bring the geology field experience to students that are accessibility challenged.
author: Williams, D. A.; Marshall, A.; Meier, M.; Redding, S. L.; Gallant, E.; Piatek, J.; Thatcher, S.; Bearden, A.; Arroyo, Y.; Collins, T.; Williams, A.; Elardo, S.

title: Holey Tour Planetary Geology Field Trip: Recent Changes for an Evolving Planetary Community
abstract: This presentation discusses updates and changes to the ASU Holey Tour introductory planetary geology field trip, including a virtual field trip that is now available online.
author: Williams, D. A.; Narish, M.; Anbar, A. D.

title: InSight's Diversity and Inclusion Working Group
abstract: in this talk we will give an overview of the work of InSight's Diversity and Inclusion Working Group.
author: Fernando, B. A.; Daubar, I. J.; Newman, C.; Irving, J. C. E.; Johnson, C.

title: The Need for an International Lunar Volatile Strategy
abstract: We are at a critical turning point in space exploration. This is both an exciting time for humanity, and an urgent time for ensuring that we measure the pristine composition lunar volatiles to answer fundamental questions posed by the Decadal Survey .
author: Mandt, K. E.

title: Introduction to Lunar Caves: The Significance, Challenges, and Possibilities
abstract: This abstract focuses on the exciting discovery of lunar caves made from lava tubes and the causes, prospects, and opportunities associated with this discovery.
author: Tymchuk, B. M.; Johnson, J. C.; Johnson, P. A.; Mardon, A. A.

title: Development of a Reusable Lunar Environment Electrical Connector, the Dust Tolerant Connector
abstract: The Dust Tolerant Con-nector (DTC), solves the problem of a reusable electrical connector, cable of enduring the rigors of the lunar environment.
author: Indyk, S. I.; Xu, H. Y.; Schultz, J. T.; Mellman, B. S.; Tomasco, S. N.; Bywaters, K. F.; Traden, N. W.; Moreno, A. J.; Zacny, K. A.

title: Expanding Lunar Gateway Capabilities: A Comprehensive Framework for Multi-Planetary Missions to Mars and Ceres
abstract: The concept of deep space exploration is evolving rapidly, with space agencies and private companies setting their sights on more ambitious goals. Building on innovative proposals like the Human Crewed Interplanetary Transport Architecture (HUCITAR), a new vision is emerging that could revolutionize our approach to exploring the solar system. This vision centers on enhancing the planned Lunar Gateway to serve as a crucial staging point for expeditions to both Mars and Ceres, with potential launches in the 2040-2050 timeframe.
author: Biswal M, Malaya Kumar; Kumar, V. Ramesh

title: ILEWG LUNEX EuroMoonMars Earth Space Innovation Academy: Lunar Missions, Data, Instruments, Field Work, Astronauts, Habitats, and Business
abstract: We describe research highlights from ILEWG LUNEX EuroMoonMars Earth Space Innovation, EuroSpaceHub Academy partners contributing to MoonMars missions, Field Research, Astronautics, and Entrepreneurship.
author: Foing, B. H.; Rogers, H.; Lee, T. S.; Stoker, C.; Ehrenfreund, P.; Laforet, C.; Tataj, H.; Doyle, E.; Pascual, J.; Puriene, V.; Gomez de Castro, I.; Fazel, F.; Claeys, K.; Robertson, C.; Balfe, M.; Laffey, J.; Harvey, M.; Crampe, M.; Ducai, T.; Crotti, S.; Zanchi, M.; Tagne, D.; Vleugels, S.; Swida, O.; Hoogenboom, R.; Abbink, D.; Kolodziejczyk, A.; Perrier, I. R.; Baatout, S.; Pavanello, S.; Musilova, M.; Heemskerk, M.; Pouwels, C.; Tavernier, A.; McGrath, K.; Ehreiser, A.; Schlarmann, L.; Reymens, B.; Sol, P.; Gautam, K.; Wedler, A.; Autino, A.; Heinz, S.; Pelton, J.; Crisafulli, J.; Beldavs, V.; Tacchini, D.; Hutchinson, A.; Duboille, C.; Gil Navidad, M.; Foing, V.; Demir, B.; Reibaldi, G.; Mankins, J.; Molony, S.; Osioanu, D.; Ip-Jewell, S.; ILEWG Lunex Euromoonmars Team

title: All Female Crew "Lotus" for Artemis Base Camp: EuroMoonMars Poland EMMPOL21/AATC85 Campaign 2024
abstract: An overview of the "Lotus" AATC85 EMMPOL21 LUNEX EuroMoonMars all-female mission. As space exploration is a frontier of research and technology development an on-Earth moonbase simulation can provide insight for future space missions such as Artemis.
author: Tataj, H. Z.; Della Guardia, J.; Harutyunyan, H.; Ramos Moreno, L.; Verdan, C.; Kołodziejczyk, A.; Komenda, K.; Foing, B.

title: 4Artemis3 Rehearsal with the First Woman on the Moon
abstract: Artemis 3, set for NET September 2026, will return humans to the Moon, including the first woman. The 4Artemis3 LUNEX EuroMoonMars Poland initiative conducted a seven-day analog mission in a windowless Moonbase, simulating the Artemis 3 with 2-crew.
author: Laforet, C.; Harvey, M.; Kołodziejczyk, A.; Foing, B.

title: Update on the Prospects for Finding Ice on the Moon
abstract: The remarkable observations by ShadowCam, advances regarding the spin axis evolution of the Moon, and other recent results call for a reassessment of the distribution of lunar ice. A consistent picture for ice on the Moon has begun to emerge.
author: Schorghofer, N.

title: Computational Analysis of Adhesive Properties of Mussel Foot Proteins from Mytilus Californianus as a Model in Space Environments
abstract: This study explores the stability of mussel foot proteins (MFPs) under space conditions using molecular dynamics simulations, revealing potential applications in space bioadhesives and medicine.
author: Jagmag, S. H.; D'souza, N.

title: The Exciting Possibilities with 3D Printing for Space Travel, Lunar Colonization, and Infrastructure
abstract: This article focuses on the amazing possibilities and assistance that 3D printing can provide to space travel and colonization.
author: Johnson, J. C.; Tymchuk, B. M.; Johnson, P. A.; Mardon, A. A.

title: On the Importance of Geological and Geophysical Lunar Field Work Enabled by Artemis Base Camp
abstract: Time and equipment are the most geoscience-enabling aspects of having one or multiple Artemis Base Camps on the Moon to support crew. We present six Findings highlighting advancements to lunar geoscience from such base camps.
author: Runyon, K. D.; Buxner, S.; Crane, K.; Crow, C.; Douglas, A.; Edgar, L.; Eppler, D.; Hurtado, J. M.; Rubins, K.; Wagner, M.

title: Surface Operation Plan for the Heat Flow Measurement on the Blue Ghost Mission to Mare Crisium
abstract: The surface operation plan for the heat flow probe on the CLPS mission to Mare Crisium by Firefly Aerospace is described.
author: Nagihara, S.; Sanasarian, L.; Ngo, P.; Zacny, K.

title: ExoSpaceHab-Xpress: Preparing a Habitat for Luna Colonization, Artemis Base Camp
abstract: As space colonization is inventible, on-Earth simulations can provide valuable information. The ExoSpaceHub-Xpress, is a habitat where such missions can be hosted. During them the essential equipment, electronic devices, and tools can be determined.
author: Tataj, H. Z.; Laforet, C.; Foing, B.

title: Outer Space Classroom in Meteorite Lab: How to Develop School-Based Lessons about Moon Exploration through Lunar Meteorites and Historic Artifacts
abstract: The "Outer Space Classroom" uses interactive models, samples, and activities to engage students in multisensory STEAM learning about space exploration.
author: Sit, E. C. L.

title: Lunar Helium-3: New Insights from Apollo-Era Regolith Sample Studies
abstract: Interlune aims to be the first company to commercialize lunar helium-3. Here, I offer new interpretations of Apollo-era helium measurements of lunar regolith through the lens of recent microscopy studies.
author: Frank, E. A.

title: Impact Resurfacing of the Artemis Exploration Zone (AEZ): Sample Locations for Primordial Crust and South Pole-Aitken (SPA) Ejecta
abstract: In this study, we provide insides into the south pole stratigraphy and identify optimal sampling locations for primordial crust and SPA materials. We include ejecta thickness modeling, and excavation depth and compositional analyses.
author: Frueh, T.; Camon, A.; Boyce, M.; Halwa, S.; Ligeza, G.; Lemelin, M.; Kring, D. A.

title: Canada's Rover Development for Lunar Surface Exploration
abstract: CSA has been working on the development and launch of two rovers: The Canadian Lunar Rover and the Lunar Utility Vehicle.
author: Morisset, C. -E.; Bergeron, M.; Haltigin, T.; Hill, P.; Lamarche, T.; Lange, C.; Moroso, F.; Picard, M.; Saint-Jacques, D.

title: Space Art: Enhancing Effects of Japanese Calligraphy in a Space Simulation
abstract: This study aims to explore the potential of calligraphy in mitigating stress during a lunar base simulation at the Analogue Astronaut Training Center in Poland. It is crucial for astronauts to partake in stress-reducing activities.
author: Della Guardia, J.; Tataj, H. Z.; Foing, B.

title: NASA STMD Lunar Surface Innovation Consortium In-Situ Resource Utilization Focus Group: Update and Path Forward
abstract: The Lunar Surface Innovation Consortium (LSIC) In-Situ Resource Utilization (ISRU) Focus Group facilitates the development of ISRU-related technology to enable a sustained presence of the surface of the Moon.
author: Berdis, J.; Hibbitts, C. A.; Coburger, A.; Nord, M.; Miller, R.; Burke, P.

title: Magnetotelluric Sounding of the Lunar Interior at Mare Crisium and Schrodinger Basin
abstract: Magnetotellurics will probe the lunar interior at two locations at higher vertical resolution than ever before and without needing an orbital reference measurement. The soundings will contribute to understanding lunar differentiation and asymmetry.
author: Grimm, R. E.; Delory, G. T.; Espley, J. R.; Stillman, D. E.

title: Modeling Lunar Time
abstract: The White House OSTP has instructed NASA to develop a Coordinated Lunar Time (LTC), a lunar analog of TAI. Here, we describe initial efforts to model LTC, including the effects of tidal redshifts, and compare the agreement of 4 models.
author: Eubanks, T. M.; Blase, J. W.; Asmar, S.; Bills, B. G.

title: Cubic Zirconia in Northwest Africa 12593: Evidence of an Era of Intense Bombardment to the Earth-Moon System ~3.5 Ga
abstract: We present the first observation of baddeleyite with cubic phase heritage, indicative of formation at temperatures >2370°C in lunar meteorite NWA 12593, which have ages contemporaneous with multiple impacts on Earth asteroid 4 Vesta.
author: Crow, C. A.; Erickson, T. M.; Economos, R.; Lehman-Franco, K.; Boyce, J. W.; Davis, J. R.; Diaz, C. A.; Flowers, R. M.; Brounce, M.; Schoene, B.; Benowitz, J. A.

title: Farside Seismic Suite: A Pathway to Implement a Lunar Seismic Network via Commercial Missions
abstract: We propose a network of seismometers on the Moon, using NASA's commercial program, to form the backbone of an international seismic network.
author: Nunn, C.; Panning, M. P.; Kedar, S.; Bowles, N.; Calcutt, S.; Drilleau, M.; Garcia, R.; Horleston, A.; Kawamura, T.; Lognonné, P.; Miller, E.; Mimoun, D.; Pike, W. T.; de Raucourt, S.; Weber, R.

title: Exploring Lunar Water and Volatiles with the Heterodyne OH Lunar Miniature Spectrometer (HOLMS)
abstract: The following decades will revolutionize space exploration with advanced technologies. We are developing an ultra-mini UV spectrometer to measure lunar water to study its distribution, which is crucial for understanding lunar volatiles and the water cycle.
author: Hosseini, S.; Davidsson, B.; Hendrix, A.; Gronoff, G.; Hendrix, A.; Hurley, D.; Colaprete, A.

title: Combined XRF/XRD Instrument for In Situ Planetary Composition
abstract: Baseline design of a compact XRF/XRD instrument that can be flown on future planetary rovers is conceived based on simulation modules. Reflection geometry is demonstrated using lab setup and the relationship between instrument parameters is studied.
author: Pillai, N. S.; Vadodariya, K.; Narendranath, S.

title: Updated Kaguya Terrain Camera Ames Stereo Pipeline Derived Digital Terrain Models
abstract: This abstract describes the release of over 127,000 medium resolution lunar DTMs, usable for a myriad of science and engineering applications.
author: Laura, J. R.; Alexandrov, O.; Adoram-Kershner, L.; Bauck, K.; Wheeler, B.; Hare, T. M.

title: Mini-RF Radar-Derived Lunar Rock Abundance: Implications for Landing Site Hazard Assessment in the South Pole
abstract: We developed a radar-derived rock abundance map for the Moon that can be used for landing site hazard assessment in the South Pole.
author: Rivera-Valentín, E. G.; Fassett, C. I.; Powell, T. M.; Patterson, G. W.

title: Australian Undergraduate Participation in Milo Mission Academy for Lunar Exploration
abstract: The Milo Mission Academy led by Arizona State University makes space science and exploration accessible to countries around the world. In 2024, Australian students participated for the first time, producing design review documents for a lunar rover.
author: Iles, G. N.; Keegan, M.; Thomas, D.

title: Status Update on Endurance: A South Pole-Aitken Sample Return and Exploration Rover
abstract: Over the last year, JPL has made substantial progress in advancing the Endurance mission concept for a long-range rover to explore the Moon's enormous South Pole-Aitken basin and deliver samples to Artemis astronauts.
author: Keane, J. T.; Baker, J. D.; Elliott, J. O.; Kornfeld, R. P.; Nesnas, I. A.; Stone, H. W.; Khan, N.

title: Simulation Verification of Lava Cave Detection with GPR
abstract: Field data from the Undara National Park in Australia has allowed characterisation of a lightweight GPR antenna for eventual deployment on the Moon. Simulations here verify experimental subsurface feature depth estimates and lava tube diameters.
author: Auld, M. W.; Macnae, J. C.; Iles, G. N.

title: Lithospace: Unveiling a New Platform for Comprehensive Moon and Mars Data Analysis
abstract: Australian geoscience data company, Lithodat, have made their LithoSpace unique space data platform publicly available in 2024. LithoSpace provides geochemical analytical tools of the Moon and Mars.
author: Iles, G. N.; Kohlmann, F.; Noble, W.

title: Flow of Granular Materials in Micro-G
abstract: Using simulation guided by experiment we study the flow and jamming behavior of granular lunar regolith simulants in reduced gravity conditions.
author: Madden, I. P.; Muruganandam, S.; Ray, S. S.

title: Update on Completed and Upcoming Deliveries of NASA Payloads to the Moon via Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS)
abstract: We will present results from the NASA payloads that flew on the first two commercial missions to the Moon, provide an update on the NASA payloads flying on the next two commercial missions, and summarize our lessons learned.
author: Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS)

title: PlanetVac: Regolith Mining Systems for CLPS Firefly Blue Ghost Lander
abstract: PlanetVac is a low cost sample delivery system for in-situ science or sample return missions.
author: Zacny, K.; Firzgerald, Z.; Jung, H.; Vendiola, V.; Borcyk, N.; Misra, R.; Alattas, M.; Johnson, T.; Carrington, K.; Wohl, C.; Mueller, R.; Banks, M.

title: Hadley Max 500-Day Design Reference Mission (DRM) to the Apollo 15 Hadley Apennine Region: Outstanding Scientific Questions
abstract: We present science goals/objectives for a 500-day Hadley-Apennine Design Reference Mission providing guidance for requirements for extended Moon-Mars stays and mission design/architecture elements (habitats, human/robotic rovers, CONOPS, etc.).
author: Head, J.; Scott, D.; Boatwright, B.; Rothschild, L.; Maurer, C.; Eppler, D.; Creel, R.; Martin, R.; Fryd, D.; Daniti, M.; Mickey, W.; Sun, J.; Gao, T.; Buchanan, E.; Kuehr, K.; LeBlanc, N.; Hossain, R.; Seeb, R.; van der Bogert, C.; Hiesinger, H.; Iqbal, W.

title: TRIDENT (The Regolith and Ice Drill for Exploring New Terrain) for the Volatiles Investigating Polar Ex-ploration Rover (VIPER) and Polar Resources Ice Mining Experiment (PRIME-1)
abstract: TRIDENT drill is designed to provide 1 m deep samples to MSolo and NIRVSS instruments on PRIME-1 and VIPER missions.
author: Zacny, K.; Chu, P.; Vendiola, V.; Creekmore, P.; Ng, P.; Goldman, S.; Seto, E.; Bywaters, K.; Bailey, E.; Zheng, R.; King, I.; Rashedi, A.; Chow, P.; Huddleston, R.; Paulsen, G.; Wang, A.; Wilson, J.; Xu, H.; Indyk, S.; Quinn, J.; Eichenbaum, A.; J., Captain; Kleinhenz, J.; Rezich, E.; Colaprete, T.; Lim, D.; Mirmalek, Z.; Lees, D.; Elphic, R.; Ennico Smith, K.; Bickel, V.; Lewis, K.; Annex, A.; Deutsch, A.; Fernando, B.; Schmerr, N.

title: Solving Moon Rover Thermal Engineering Challenges
abstract: Ron will detail Apollo Lunar Roving Vehicle (LRV) thermal engineering experiences and recommendations for future Artemis Moon Crewed and Robotic roving exploration.
author: Creel, R. A.

title: Deploying Extreme Sensitive Laser Strainmeter and Distributed Accoustic Sensing on Future Artemis Opportunities: Geophysical Goals and Challenges
abstract: Future Artemis opportunities will be able to deploy extreme sensitivity instruments, such as laser strain meters or distributed accoustic strainmeters, able to merge geophysical and astrophysical science goals.
author: Lognonné, P.; Panning, M.; Tauzin, B.; Kawamura, T.; Karan, J.

title: Laser Interferometer Lunar Antenna
abstract: The Laser Interferometer Laser Antennae (LILA) will utilize the moon's quiet seismic background to make measurements of gravitational waves unable to be performed on Earth and measure the lunar interior composition to an unprecedented accuracy.
author: Trippe, J. M.; Jani, K.; Quetschke, V.; Reed, R. A.; Sierawski, B. D.; Karsai, G.; Lognonné, P.

title: Implications of the Nucleation Barrier on Lunar Core Evolution
abstract: To better understand the role of the nucleation barrier in planetary evolution, we model the formation of the lunar solid inner core. We self consistently model the effects of supercooling and composition on core solidification for an Fe–S system.
author: Gutierrez, S.; Hauck, S. A.

title: Proposed End-To-End Lunar Capillary Absorption Spectrometer (LuCAS) System for Isotopic and Abundance Analysis of Lunar Volatiles
abstract: The Lunar Capillary Absorption Spectrometer (LuCAS) is a novel end-to-end isotope and gas analyzer for studying lunar volatiles. LuCAS measures abundance and isotopic ratios of H2O and CO2 in regolith, as well as abundance of gases such as H2S.
author: Sheeran, F. J.; King, I. R.; Kriesel, J.; Fahrland, A.; Emerson-Shurilla, K.; Stern, J. C.

title: Opportunistic Science with Inertial Measurement Units on the Moon
abstract: The next generation of lunar science and exploration missions will all carry Inertial Measurements Units (IMUs). These IMUs are highly sensitive engineering instruments with the potential for use as scientific instruments as well.
author: Fernando, B. A.; Lewis, K.; Schmerr, N.; Gansler, K.

title: Lunar Spatial Data Infrastructure: Supporting Data Interoperability through Community Standards
abstract: This abstract describes the efforts of the Lunar Spatial Data Infrastructure Working Group to build community driven standards around lunar spatial data.
author: Laura, J. R.; Archinal, B. A.; Beyer, R. A.; Hunter, M. A.; Kestay, L.; Prosser, J. W.; Stopar, J. D.

title: Supporting Early-Career Researchers on Future Lunar Missions
abstract: Planetary science missions come with their own challenges for early-career researchers (ECRs). We will discuss strategies future lunar missions may put in place to better support them.
author: Fernando, B. A.; Daubar, I. J.; Newman, C.; Beghein, C.; Irving, J. C. E.; Johnson, C.; Panning, M. P.; Pleasa, A. C.; Smrekar, S.; Stanley, S.; Banerdt, W. B.

title: Development Status of the Canadian Lunar Rover
abstract: The Canadian Lunar Rover (CLR) is the flagship of the Canadian Space Agency's Lunar Exploration Accelerator Program (LEAP) and will be the first ever Canadian-led planetary surface mission.
author: Newman, J.; Edmundson, P.; Middleton, J.; Hackett, J.; Roberts, P.; Lalla, E.; Besko, G.; Osinski, G. R.; Cunje, A.; Tornabene, L.; Cloutis, E. A.; Lemelin, M.; Moroso, F.; Morisset, C. -E.; Lamarche, T.; Greenhagen, B. T.; Cahill, J. T. S.; Clyde, B.; Ryan, K.; Smith, M. B.; MacEwan, S. J.; CLR Team

title: Lunar-VISE Landing Site Selection and Characterization
abstract: The CP-21 mission will comprise a lander and rover carrying the Lunar-VISE instrument payload. Landing site criteria and characteristics of the selected site are described.
author: Williams, J. -P.; Landis, M. E.; Bennett, K. A.; Valencia, S.; Donaldson Hanna, K. L.; Dove, A.; O'Brien, P.; Mazarico, E.; Denevi, B. W.; Hagerty, J.; Hardgrove, C.; Hayne, P. O.; LaMee, A.; Prettyman, T. H.; Shirley, K. A.; Siegler, M. A.; Sunshine, J.; Karcz, J.; Banks, M. E.

title: The Science Opportunities of Artificially Created Shadowed Regions in the Lunar South Pole
abstract: Artificially created topographic modifications to the lunar surface will be an inevitable consequence of planned exploration of the lunar south pole. Many will be shadowed regions and can be leveraged for diagnostic experiments for surface processes.
author: Saxena, P.; Steinmetz, E. M.

title: Moon Diver Mission Concept Update: Data Analysis Strategies and Concept of Operations
abstract: An update on the Moon Diver mare pit exploration mission concept, focusing on what types of data would be collected, how this data would be processed, and how decisions about data collection would be made in real time.
author: Kerber, L.; Gale, R. V.; Moore, N.; Wire, N.; Francis, R.; Uckert, K.; Hockman, B. J.; Radebaugh, J.; Roy, A.; Sellar, R. G.

title: Liquid Water in the Lunar Crust
abstract: The Moon may possess, in warm layers km below its surface at high latitudes, reservoirs of liquid water, delivered by large impacts in the past and protected from loss by ice-saturated layers nearer to the surface.
author: Eubanks, T. M.; Blase, W. P.; Lingam, M.

title: A Heritage BioSensor Platform for Lunar Biology Experiments
abstract: The BioSensor CubeSat aboard BioSentinel used an automated cell culture system to study radiation effects on yeast cells. BioSensor can host a diverse range of experiments, making it a leading candidate for future space biology studies on the moon.
author: Govinda Raj, C.; Lee, J. A.; Padgen, M. R.; Ricco, A. J.; Timucin, L. R.; Gentry, D. M.; Gilroy, S.; Settles, A. M.; Santa Maria, S. R.

title: Coordinated Microscale Observations of Unique Lithologies in Apollo Sample 15405
abstract: This abstract presents new geochemical, microstructural and geochronologic data from quartzmonzodiorite fragments within Apollo impact melt breccia 15405.
author: Erickson, T. M.; Prissel, K.; Crow, C.; Christoffersen, R.; Barnes, J. J.; Buckley, W. P.; Eckley, S.; Hahn, T. J.; Keller, L. P.; Kent, J.; Kinny, P. D.; Setera, J. B.; Simon, J. I.; Valencia, S.

title: MoonWatcher Constellation for Next Generation Lunar Surface Mapping
abstract: The MoonWatcher six-satellite constellation is designed to bring high-resolution (less than 10 cm), high-cadence, multi-spectral mapping techniques to the Moon to serve the scientific, exploration and national security communities.
author: Morse, J.; Mangione, M.

title: Lunar Science and Mission Systems Integration for Real-Time Long Duration Remote Robot Surface Operations
abstract: Discussed are some findings from the VIPER mission on the process of integrating lunar science with mission system operations for real-time long duration remote robot surface operations.
author: Mirmalek, Z.; Colaprete, A.; Lees, D.; Lim, D. S. S.

title: The Volatiles Investigating Polar Exploration Rover (VIPER) Mission Update
abstract: This update will provide the LEAG the most current plans for VIPER, including potential commercial and governmental partnerships and closeout plans, including potential rover storage or disassembly.
author: Colaprete, A.; Lim, D. S. S.; Ennico-Smith, K.; Mirmalek, Z.; Elphic, E. C.; Zacny, K.; Captian, J.; Betyer, R.; Shirley, M.; Balaban, E.

title: Geotechnical Assessment of Trafficability On Regolith (GATOR) Using the RIDER Terramechanics Testbed
abstract: The GATOR project using the RIDER terramechanics rig experimented with three rover prototype wheels on a replicated 2-layer lunar highlands regolith column to measure the effect that repeated traffic has on the geotechnical properties of the regolith.
author: Lucas, M. P.; Neal, C. R.; Long-Fox, J. M.; Blandin, G.; Glover, A.; Easter, P.; Conroy, M.; Britt, D.

title: Crisium: Unveiling Volcanic Diversity Beyond the Procellarum Kreep Terrane
abstract: Despite being situated well beyond the PKT, the Crisium region hosts a diverse range of volcanic structures. We will present an integrated analysis of the Crisium region, with a focus on radar data, to propose high-value future landing sites.
author: Morgan, G. A.; Weitz, C. M.; Berman, D. C.; Jawin, E. R.; Russell, M. B.; Campbell, B. A.; Patterson, G. W.; Stickle, A. M.

title: Optimizing Astronaut Traverses at the Lunar South Pole Using Geologic Maps, Science Stations, and the LunarTRAV Geospatial Tool
abstract: We present a new geospatial tool, LunarTRAV, that considers surface EVA opportunities (e.g., science stations) and obstacles (e.g., hazards) and outputs the safest, most efficient path for crewed exploration.
author: Luna, J. W.; Hollingsworth, I. L.; Lamantia, A. M.; Li, P. C.; Sutherland, C. J.

title: System Health Enabled Realtime Planning Advisor (SHERPA) and Its Use in Lunar Exploration
abstract: SHERPA (System Health Enabled Realtime Planning Advisor) is an AI decision support system for space missions. It currently serves as the primary strategic mission planning system on the Volatiles Investigating Polar Exploration Rover (VIPER) mission.
author: Balaban, E.; Banerjee, S.; Booth, Z.; Ott, J.; Astle, E.; Shirley, M.; Bradner, K.; Colaprete, A.; Viper Science Team; Viper Mission Systems Team; Viper Mission Systems Engineering Team

title: Hydrolox Mass Economy of Intralunar Resource Transportation
abstract: I discuss ballistic trajectories of tankers carrying hydrogen, oxygen, or water from the Polar regions to 3He mines, rare earth refineries, or settlements in Equatorial regions. Destination regolith-derived O2 makes this 2 to 18x as effective.
author: Van Cleve, J. E.

title: Optimizing Lunar Exploration: A Multi-Dimensional Approach to Landing Site Selection
abstract: A comprehensive lunar landing site selection approach integrates static and dynamic datasets from the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter. It assesses terrain, lighting, and communication conditions to identify safe and scientifically valuable locations.
author: Speyerer, E. J.; Robinson, M. S.; Bussey, B. D.

title: An Alternative Human Landing System Leveraging Nova-C and Crew Dragon Heritage
abstract: Challenges associated with HLS development endanger the objectives of the Artemis program. This presentation will present a conceptual lander that can return astronauts to the Moon by 2029. Its design is based on Crew Dragon and Nova-C heritage.
author: Longo, A. Z.

title: Infrared Color Video for Artemis EVAs
abstract: We tested a wearable short-wave infrared camera for false-color video during Artemis EVAs.
author: Saper, L.; Heine, R.; Liu, Y.; Parekh, R. A.; Sellar, R. G.

title: Summary of Apollo Next Generation Sample Analysis (ANGSA) and Insights for Artemis Preliminary Examination Activities
abstract: This abstract summarizes ANGSA and provides lessons learned from ANGSA for Artemis Preliminary Examination activities.
author: McCubbin, F. M.; Shearer, C. K.; Barnes, J. J.; Burgess, K.; Cohen, B. A.; Curran, N.; Dyar, M. D.; Elsila, J. E.; Gillis-Davis, J. J.; Gross, J.; Sehlke, A.; Welten, K. C.; Zeigler, R. A.; The Angsa Science Team

title: Detecting the Gravitational Wave Linear Memory from Core-Collapse Supernovae Using the Moon
abstract: The detection of gravitational waves (GWs) from core-collapse supernovae has been long overdue. The current detection range is limited to 10 kpc. A lunar GW detector would extend this detection range to several megaparsecs.
author: Gill, K.

title: Emirates Lunar Mission Past, Present, and Future
abstract: The Emirates Lunar Mission (ELM) was established in 2019 with the aim to develop and land a series of small rovers to different sites on the lunar surface. This abstract describes the three rovers under the ELM program.
author: Almarzooqi, H.; Almatroushi, H.; Els, S. G.; Almaeeni, S.; Alzaabi, M.

title: Trace Element Analyses of Plagioclase from Troctolite 76535 and Implications for Mg-Suite Petrogenesis
abstract: We present the results of chemical analyses of 76535 plagioclase and two different calculations of the Mg-suite parental liquid REE composition. The results of which show a clear KREEP signature in the Mg-suite parental liquid.
author: Spring, I.; Mallik, A.; Moitra, P.; Kirk, J.; Borg, L.; Hervig, R.

title: Mapping Geomechanical Gradients Using SPARTA
abstract: Characterization of the subsurface and determining the spatial distribution of regolith geomechanical properties is critical for the operational success of all future planetary landed science missions.
author: Anderson, R. C.; Sollitt, L.; Buckowski, D.; Wyrick, D.; Long-Fox, J.; Duong, M.; Husson, N.

title: The Lunar Dawn Lunar Terrain Vehicle: Progressive Deployment of Lunar Surface Exploration and Science Capabilities
abstract: The Lunar Dawn Lunar Terrain Vehicle (LTV) is a commercially developed and operated lunar mobility platform created by Lunar Outpost in partnership with General Motors, MDA, Goodyear, and Leidos Dynetics, enabling excellent lunar surface science data return.
author: Gemer, A. J.; Cyrus, J. A.; Meyen, F.; Cyrus, J. B.

title: The Lunar Mapping Program (LMAP): An Innovative Approach to Targeted Lunar Geologic Mapping in Support of Future Exploration
abstract: The Lunar Mapping Program (LMAP), a pilot project funded by NASA and run by the USGS, seeks to innovate lunar geologic mapping, particularly in the lunar south pole, through a team-based approach.
author: Skinner, J. A.

title: Heimdall Camera System: Science Goals and Specifications
abstract: Gruithuisen Domes rise / and reveal their properties / to Heimdall's cameras
author: Yingst, R. A.; Cohen, B. A.; Garry, W. B.; Garvin, J. B.; Gregg, T. K. P.; Henderson, M. M.; Manzoni, C.; May, B. H.; Minitti, M. E.; Ravine, M. A.; Young, K. E.

title: Quantifying the Role of Heat-Producing Elements on Lunar Interior Thermal Profiles
abstract: Exploring the effect of decaying radioactive heat production elements on the thermal profile for the Moon's interior via experimental petrology and conductive modeling. We explore the effects of varying bulk composition and degree of mantle overturn.
author: Roy, A.; Mallik, A.; Bremner, P. M.; Diamond, M. R.; Haviland, H. F.; Goepfert, T. J.; Hervig, R. L.

title: Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter Landing Site Support and Characterization
abstract: We are in an exciting period of lunar exploration. Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter instrument teams are providing observations and data products to complement surface investigations and provide detailed characterization of landing sites before and after surface activities.
author: Banks, M. E.; Barker, M. K.; Bennett, K. A.; Dolgas, E.; Henriksen, M. R.; Horvath, T.; Manheim, M. R.; Mazarico, E.; Petro, N. E.; Retherford, K. D.; Robinson, M. S.; Smith, D. E.; Spence, H. E.; Sun, X.; Thomson, B. J.; Whizin, A. D.; Williams, J. -P.; Wilson, J. K.

title: Effects of Mineralogy and Maturity on the Far-ultraviolet Reflectance of Apollo Soils
abstract: We present far-ultraviolet (Lyman-alpha to 160 nm) bi-directional reflectance measurements of Apollo soils 10084, 68501, and 71061, showing how mineralogical differences and space weathering likely affect lunar soil far-UV reflectance.
author: Gimar, C. J.; Raut, U.; Poston, M. J.; Stevanovic, A.; Protopapa, S.; Greathouse, T. K.; Mayorga, L. C.; Retherford, K. D.; Qasim, D. N.; Grimes, J. T.

title: Farside: Radio investigations of the Dark Ages and Exoplanet Magneto-spheres from the Moon
abstract: Low-frequency < 30MHz observations from the Moon will probe for information from two of the most significant areas of astrophysics:understanding our Universe's early history and characterizing exoplanets. I will present plans for a studied concept.
author: Mahesh, N.; Bowman, J. D.; Burns, J. O.; Hallinan, G. H.; Jacobs, D. J.

title: More on the Continued Use of the Mean Earth (ME) Coordinate System for the Moon
abstract: The Findings from the 2023 LEAG white paper are reviewed, that the mean Earth/polar axis (ME) coordinate system should continue to be used for determining lunar surface coordinates, for lunar mapping and navigation.
author: Archinal, B.; Fassett, C.; Gaddis, L.; Hare, T.; Malaret, E.; Ostrach, L.; Park, R.

title: DIMPLE Concept of Operations Narrative: at the Lander
abstract: A narrative description of the Dating an Irregular Mare Patch with a Lunar Explorer (DIMPLE) payload concept of operations at the lander. Operations for the mobility service will happen in parallel with operations at the lander.
author: Anderson, F. S.; Bierhaus, E. B.; Braden, S. E.; Fagan, A. L.; Fausch, R. G.; Head, J. W.; Joy, K. H.; Levine, J.; Osterman, S.; Pernet-Fisher, J.; Peskosky, N. J.; Tartèse, R.; Wurz, P.; Yant, M.

title: On the Characterization of the Dusty Plasma Environment and Its Impact on Lunar Operations
abstract: To deep-dive survey literary research sources to better characterize an under-researched lunar dusty plasma domain as well identify both areas of research interest and instrument selection specific to their scientific inquiry.
author: Freeman, R. H.

title: Investigating the Lunar South Pole Thermal Environments In Situ with the LAFORGE Thermal Infrared Instrument aboard the CSA Lunar Rover Mission
abstract: The Lunar Advanced Filter Observing Radiometer for Geologic Exploration (LAFORGE) instrument is a multispectral thermal infrared imaging radiometer designed to maximize temperature accuracy, especially at temperatures below 100K.
author: Greenhagen, B. T.; Cahill, J. T. S.; Donaldson Hanna, K. L.; Elder, C. M.; Siegler, M. A.; Warren, T.; Ryan, K.; Clyde, B.

title: Systematic Grid Sampling Strategy in the Artemis III Malapert Massif Candidate Landing Region
abstract: We strongly advocate for the use of a grid sampling strategy, commonly used in exploration geology, in conjunction with station sampling to address the Artemis 3 Geology Team science objectives in the Malapert massif candidate landing region.
author: Sonke, A. J.; Coelho, T.; Lee, J.; De Fazio, V. M.; Robinson, M. S.

title: Enhanced Visualization of Candidate Artemis III Landing Site Using Image Processing Techniques
abstract: We attempt image processing methods to improve the amount of visual information that can be inferred from a candidate landing site. Here we use the high resolution image mosaic for Nobile Rim 1, and use image processing to enhance details.
author: Khatri, S.; Shubham, S.

title: Long-Term Variations of Temperature and H2SO4 Gas Mixing Ratio in the Venusian Atmosphere Investigated by Venus Express and Akatsuki Radio Occultation Measurements
abstract: We analyzed Venus Express and Akatsuki radio occultation data to investigate the long-term variations of temperature and H2SO4 gas mixing ratio around the cloud bottom. The comparison between our results and other measurements are also discussed.
author: Ando, H. A.; Noguchi, K. N.; Imamura, T. I.; Sagawa, H. S.; Oschlisniok, J. O.; Tellmann, S. T.; Pätzold, M. P.

title: Predicting CO Cameron-Band Auroral Emission at Venus Using VEx Observations
abstract: By utilizing an empirical relation, we independently predict and analyze the possible CO Cameron-band emission brightness at Venus using the electron observations from the Venus Express mission. This study is useful for future Venus mission design.
author: Xu, S.; Frahm, R.; Ma, Y. J.; Mitchell, D. L.; Luhmann, J. G.; Gerard, J. -C.; Soret, L.; Lillis, R. J.

title: Nitrogen Helium Filled Cloud-Top Gliding Self-Inflating Mini-Airships with Polysulphone UHMWPE Self-Inflating Composite Shell Tungsten Instrumentation Tungsten Carbide Coating
abstract: Polysulphone UHMWPE Tungsten Polymer Composite High-Temperature Memory Polymer Shell with He N2 on Spot-Inflation and Tungsten Instrumentation with Tungsten Carbide Coating on Gliding Winged Probes with N2 He self-inflation at CO2 H2SO4 Venus Clouds.
author: Ektate, S. E.

title: Venus Atmospheric Structure Investigation (VASI) on DAVINCI: 2024 Development Status
abstract: We report on the anticipated capabilities and implementation of instrumentation to measure the structure and dynamics of the Venus atmosphere during the entry and descent of the DAVINCI probe.
author: Lorenz, R. D.; Garvin, J. B.; Johnson, N.; Getty, S.; Arney, G.; Kohler, E.; Forget, F.; Lebonnois, S.; Izenberg, N.; Atkinson, D.; Crisp, D.; Li, X.; Imasuen, A.; Haglund, M.; Vidal, S.

title: "Venus Dementia" Revisited: Preservation of Scientifically and Historically Significant Data
abstract: A staggering volume of scientifically useful and historically significant datasets are not readily accessible to researchers or the general public. We discuss our efforts to preserve this data.
author: Austin, T. J.; O'Rourke, J. G.

title: Simulating Superimposed Topographic Signatures at Radially Fractured Centers (RFCs) on Venus Using Numerical Models of Dual Magma Reservoir Systems
abstract: 2D axisymmetric numerical models of a dual magma reservoir system are employed to simulate topographic signatures of Radially Fractured Centers (RFCs) on Venus. The parameter space is explored with a Monte Carlo approach and then further refined.
author: Gale, R. V.; Grosfils, E. B.

title: Correlation Between Whistler Wave Occurrences in the Venusian Ionosphere and Number of Sunspots
abstract: Using statistical analysis, we aim to correlate the occurrence of whistler waves in the Venusian ionosphere to the number of sunspots, leveraging the data from Venus Express for 2012. The result found a weak correlation between the two.
author: Shrivastava, K.; Pabari, J. P.

title: Detailed Mapping, Swarm Interactions, and Geological History of Onenhste's Dyke Swarms and Surrounding Coronae in Parga Chasmata, SE of Atla Regio, Venus
abstract: Mapping of 46,000 lineaments in Venus' Parga Chasmata links them to coronae and magmatic centers. The study reveals their ages and alignments, offering new insights into the evolution of coronae and the dynamics of rift systems.
author: Ben Marzoug, M.; El Bilali, H.; Ernst, R. E.; Buchan, K. L.; Head, J. W.; Hannour, N.

title: Graben Systems and Geological History of Mbokomu Mons Region, Along Parga Chasmata, SE of Atla Regio, Venus
abstract: More than 39,000 grabens (interpreted to overlie dyke swarms) were mapped in the Mbokomu Mons region, along Parga Chasmata, Venus, revealing radiating and circumferential swarms associated with Mbokomu Mons and coronae, Among, Repa, and two unnamed coronae.
author: Hannour, N.; El Bilali, H.; Ernst, R. E.; Buchan, K. L.; Head, J. W.; Ben Marzoug, M.

title: TPS Design to Manufacturing in Support of Rocket Lab's Probe Mission to Venus
abstract: This presentation describes the TPS design, manufacturing and integration challenges for the privately funded Rocket Lab' mission to Venus. The presentation will describe challenges and solutions associated with the smallest Venus probe.
author: Peterson, K.; Gasch, M.; Venkatapathy, E.

title: Relevant Environment Testing and Fabrication of Prototype Venus Aerobots
abstract: Overview of JPL and Aerostar's technology development efforts on a balloon platform for the Venus cloudlayer; including acid exposure testing, flight dynamics, aerial deployment trials, and fabrication.
author: Izraelevitz, J. S.; Emanuel, B.; Pauken, M. T.; Krishnamoorthy, S.; Goel, A.; Baines, K. H.; Byrne, P.; Cutts, J. A.; Tabb, R.; Turner, C.; Carlson, K.; Lachenmeier, T.; Hall, J. L.

title: Dyke Swarm History of the Eve Corona Region on the Southern Side of Alpha Regio, Venus, and Potential Implications for the Upcoming DAVINCI Mission
abstract: Detailed geological mapping of grabens in the Eve Corona region on Venus was conducted as an undergraduate thesis. Further work expanding into the adjacent Alpha Regio tesserae region will provide crucial data for imagery from NASA's DAVINCI mission.
author: Fardy, I. J.; Ernst, R. E.; El Bilali, H.

title: A Cold Case for a Hot Planet: Pioneer Venus Data Restoration
abstract: This project constituted of restoring Pioneer Venus Large Probe Neutral Mass Spectrometry data with NSSDCA, and interpolating Atmospheric Structure Experiment data corresponding to LNMS altitudes.
author: Belkhodja, I.; Williams, D.

title: Simulating Climates and JWST Observations of Two Potential ExoVenuses
abstract: We used a 3D climate model to simulate potential climate states of LHS 1140 c and TOI-1266 c. LHS 1140 c experienced snowfall on its nightside. We also demonstrate that JWST could detect their atmospheres in as little as 5 transit observations.
author: Ostberg, C. M.; Clarkson, O.; Miles, E. L.; Kane, S. R.; Way, M. J.

title: Utilization of a Radioisotope Power System to Enable Long-Term Venus Mission
abstract: The extreme environment of the surface of Venus has prevented long-term missions to the surface. Solar panels cannot operate due to the heat and atmosphere. Radioisotope thermoelectric generators, however, may be able to survive and thrive on Venus.
author: Wiley, J. R.; Matthews, J. R.; Gilbert, A. Q.

title: Glow: A Mission Concept to Explore Venus' Upper Atmospheric Dynamics by Monitoring Nightglows and Cloud Motion
abstract: The Glow mission concept is currently being developed for the NASA Small Innovative Mission for Planetary Exploration mission opportunity. Glow's goal is to understand the dynamical connection between Venus' lower and upper atmosphere circulation.
author: Sciamma-O'Brien, E.; Brecht, A.; McGouldrick, K.; Ennico Smith, K.; Ray, H.; Homan, J.; Colaprete, A.; Hoslclaw, G.; Hoffman, D.; Noe-Dobrea, E.; Courtney, M.

title: Extraction of Kinetic Scale Structures from Venus Magnetosphere Using Parker Solar Probe Data Flyby
abstract: The kinetic structures such as double layers and phase-space holes were observed during the 4th Venus flyby of Parker Solar Probe on February 20, 2021. These structures were found by using Parker Solar Probe FIELDS instrument high resolution data.
author: Sur, D.

title: The Behavior of the Oi 557.7 Oxygen Green Line and Discovery of CO B-A 483.5 nm Aurora on Venus
abstract: Here we present the behavior of Venus' oxygen green line aurora over the years as well as the discovery of a new aurora, the CO Angstrom band at 483.5 nm.
author: Gray, C.; Schmidt, C.; Lierle, P.

title: NASA-DARES 2025: The NASA Astrobiology Strategy for Decadal Advances in Research, Exploration, and Synthesis
abstract: This presentation from the NASA Astrobiology Program outlines the structure, scope, and goals of the forthcoming 2025 NASA Astrobiology Strategy for Decadal Advancements in Research, Exploration, and Synthesis (NASA-DARES 2025).
author: Harris, R. L.; Hays, L. E.; Grinspoon, D.; NASA Astrobiology Program
